Die meerderheid het beklemtoon dat die reg op menswaardigheid nie net afsonderlike grondwetlike erkenning in artikel 10 van die Grondwet gegee word nie, maar ook een van die grondliggende waardes van die Grondwet in artikel 1 is. Daarom is 'n versuim om die reg te handhaaf nie net 'n skending van artikel 10 nie, maar is ook 'n bedreiging vir 'n grondliggende waarde wat die legitimiteit van die Staat onderlê. Die meerderheid het verklaar dat vryheid van uitdrukking net so belangrik is as menswaardigheid en mens kan nie sê dat menswaardigheid vryheid van uitdrukking troef nie. Daarom het die Hof beslis dat die wet van laster vertolk moet word om uitvoering te gee aan die gepaste balans tussen die reg op vryheid van uitdrukking, aan die een kant, en 'n persoon se menswaardigheid aan die ander kant. Die Hof het op hierdie vertolking bevind dat die vereiste dat 'n opmerking ter verdediging van 'n eis vir laster billik moet wees, uitvoering gee aan die balans tussen die reg op vryheid van uitdrukking en waardigheid.
af.right_and_principle: Die sleutelkwessie wat die Konstitusionele Hof moes bepaal, was hoe amnestie wat aan die respondent deur die Nasionale Waarheids- en Versoeningskommissie toegestaan is vir misdade gepleeg tydens die stryd teen apartheid, 'n eis vir laster beïnvloed. Amnestie is aan die respondent toegestaan ingevolge die Wet op die Bevordering van Nasionale Eenheid en Versoening vir misdade wat in 1986 gepleeg is.
af.snippet: Die kernkwessie wat die Konstitusionele Hof moes bepaal, was hoe amnestie wat aan die respondent toegestaan is vir misdade wat (tydens die stryd teen apartheid) deur die Nasionale Waarheids- en Versoeningskommissie gepleeg is, 'n eis vir laster beïnvloed het.
af.title: The Citizen 1978 (Pty) Ltd and Others v McBride (CCT 23/10) [2011] ZACC 11

af.facts_and_issues:
Die applikante het die Konstitusionele Hof genader vir 'n bevel wat die bevele van die Hoogste Hof van Appèl (SCA) in twee verbandhoudende aangeleenthede tersyde stel met betrekking tot die geldigheid en die regmatigheid in die uitvoering van lasbriewe vir deursoeking en beslaglegging uitgereik ingevolge artikel 29 van die Wet op Nasionale Vervolgingsgesag 32 van 1998 (NVG-wet). Die applikant in die eerste aansoek was Thint (Pty) Ltd ('n maatskappy wat aanvanklik saam met mnr. Shaik en sy maatskappye beskuldig is in verband met bedrog- en korrupsie-aanklagte) en die applikante in die tweede aangeleentheid was mnr. Zuma en sy persoonlike prokureur, mnr. Hulley. In 2005 het die Nasionale Direkteur van Openbare Vervolging (NDOV) besluit om mnr. Zuma vir korrupsie-misdrywe (wat verband hou met mnr. Shaik en sy maatskappye) en ander bedrog- en belastingoortredings te vervolg. Gedurende Augustus en September 2005 is verskeie deursoekings- en beslagleggingsoperasies by die kantore van Thint, mnr. Hulley en by die koshuise en die voormalige kantore van mnr. Zuma uitgevoer op grond van deursoekings- en beslagleggingslasbriewe uitgereik ingevolge artikel 29(5) en 25 (6) van die NVG-wet.

In die aansoek om die deursoeking en beslagleggingslasbriewe het die ondersoekdirekteur gemeen dat die verrassingselement nodig is om te verseker dat geen bewyse op die perseel vernietig sal word nie. Mnr. Zuma en mnr. Hulley het die wettigheid van verskeie lasbriewe in die Durbanse Hooggeregshof betwis en aangevoer dat die vervolging nie die noodsaaklikheid van die deursoeking en beslaglegging aantoon nie; die lasbriewe versuim om voldoende besonderhede met betrekking tot die misdrywe te verskaf en prokureur-kliënt-privilegie is tydens die soek- en beslagleggingsoperasies moontlik geskend . Die Hooggeregshof het vyf lasbriewe ongeldig verklaar en die NDOV is beveel om die items waarop beslag gelê is terug te gee. Thint het 'n soortgelyke uitdaging in die Pretoriase Hooggeregshof geloods, maar was onsuksesvol. Die staat en Thint het die Hooggeregshofbevele na die SCA geappelleer wat onderskeidelik die bevel in die mnr. Zuma- en mnr. Hulley-aangeleentheid tersyde stel en die Thint-Hooggeregshofbevel in 'n aparte uitspraak bevestig. Na aanleiding van die SCA-bevele het mnr. Zuma, mnr. Hulley en Thint aansoek gedoen om verlof tot appèl na die Konstitusionele Hof.
af.interpretation:
Toe het die Hof oorweeg of die lasbriewe se bepalings of die uitvoering daarvan onvoldoende beskerming bied vir die applikante se regsprofessionele privilegie. Daar is bevind dat daar geen statutêre of grondwetlike vereiste is dat die lasbriewe uitdruklik na artikel 29(11) van die NVG-wet verwys nie, wat 'n meganisme verskaf vir die spoedige oplossing van eise van privilegie wat tydens 'n deursoeking gemaak word.

 

Verder is bevind dat daar niks onheilspellend is in die wyse van die staat se uitvoering van die lasbriewe nie, en spesifiek dat die deursoeking by mnr. Hulley se kantore wettiglik uitgevoer is. Nie een van die applikante het tydens die deursoekings enige aanspraak op bevoorregting gemaak nie. Boonop het die applikante sedert daardie deursoekings versuim om privilegie ten opsigte van enige spesifieke item of dokument waarop beslag gelê is, te eis ten spyte daarvan dat hulle voldoende tyd gehad het om dit te doen. Daar is bevind dat in die afwesigheid van enige bewyse van werklike benadeling vir hulle, die applikant se argument met betrekking tot regsprofessionele privilegie van die hand gewys moes word. Die meerderheid het dus bevind dat die artikel 35(3) nie oortree is nie. Die applikant se saak is van die hand gewys en die SCA se bevel is gehandhaaf.
af.right_and_principle: Die applikante het in hul aansoek om verlof tot appèl verskeie grondwetlike uitdagings geopper wat die bewering insluit dat mnr. Zuma se regte op 'n regverdige verhoor ingevolge artikel 35(3) van die Grondwet bedreig is omdat die lasbriewe nie tydens die deursoeking van mnr. Hulley se kantoor sy regsprofessionele privilegie voldoende beskerm het nie.
af.snippet: In hierdie geval is aangevoer dat mnr. Zuma se reg op 'n regverdige verhoor ingevolge artikel 35(3) van die Grondwet bedreig is omdat die lasbriewe nie sy regsprofessionele privilegie voldoende beskerm nie.
af.title: Thint (Pty) Ltd v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others; Zuma and Another v NDPP and Others (CCT 89/07) [2008] ZACC 13

af.facts_and_issues: The applicants were 133 residents of Winne Mandela informal settlement in Tembisa and a voluntary organisation supporting the residents. The residents were given a state housing subsidy that granted them ownership of a stand and the house to be constructed on it. This plan was not followed through and the applicants, some waiting for more than two decades, discovered that the Municipality had unlawfully given the stands and houses promised to them to other residents of the informal settlement instead. The matter was heard by the High Court (which found in favour of the residents), then by the Supreme Court of Appeal (which merely extended the period within which the Municipality had to provide the land and houses). The Municipality then applied to the High Court to have that period further extended. The residents sought constitutional damages from the High Court and, after that failed, they sought the same from the Constitutional Court.
af.interpretation:
First, the Court considered an application for direct leave to appeal for constitutional damages, which determines whether the court will hear the matter or not. Direct leave to appeal means that, instead of going from the High Court to the Supreme Court of Appeal and then to the Constitutional Court, as is the normal process, the applicants could go straight to the Constitutional Court to ask for constitutional damages. This happens mainly when the matter is urgent or is in the public interest. The Constitutional Court granted direct leave to appeal, meaning that they heard the matter even though it hadn't followed the normal pathway through the courts.

The respondents were allowed to present additional evidence that wasn’t initially submitted before the High Court. The respondents wanted to present evidence relating to events that occurred after the most recent High Court judgment on the matter (referred to as Thubakgale III) and which they argued was relevant to the current case. The Constitutional Court agreed and allowed additional evidence to be heard.

The Constitutional Court did not agree that constitutional damages were appropriate and dismissed the appeal.
af.right_and_principle: This case was about whether awarding constitutional damages was the appropriate relief for the infringement of a socio-economic right (in this case, the right of access to housing). Constitutional damages are a special kind of remedy in terms of which the Court can order the State to pay damages for violating constitutional rights.
af.snippet: This case was about whether awarding constitutional damages was the appropriate relief for the infringement of a socio-economic right.
af.title: Thubakgale and Others v Ekurhuleni Metropolitan Municipality and Others [2021] ZACC 45

af.facts_and_issues: Four communities whose land rights were affected by the Communal Land Rights Act [No. 11 of 2004] (CLARA) had mounted a two-pronged constitutional challenge to this legislation in the North Gauteng High Court, Pretoria. One part was challenging CLARA on the ground that its provisions undermined security of tenure. The other part was contending that the way CLARA was enacted was incorrect. The substantive challenge was partially successful, and the High Court declared certain provisions of CLARA invalid. Although it found that Parliament should have followed the procedure for the passing of Bills affecting the provinces prescribed by Section 76, it did not grant relief on that account because Parliament had committed an error in good faith and did not intend to suppress the views of the provinces. It accordingly dismissed this part of the application. The High Court referred the order of invalidity to the Constitutional Court for confirmation. In the Constitutional Court, the applicants sought confirmation of the order of invalidity and sought leave to appeal against the dismissal of their application to have CLARA declared entirely unconstitutional because of Parliament’s failure to enact it according to the procedure in Section 76. The applicants also asked for direct access to the Constitutional Court and an order declaring CLARA constitutionally invalid on the ground that Parliament failed to comply with its constitutional obligations to facilitate public involvement in the legislative process in terms of Sections 59(1)(a) and 72(1)(a) of the Constitution.
af.interpretation: The judgment of the High Court was set aside and replaced by a new one from the Constitutional Court. The new order was that the whole of the Communal Land Rights Act (CLARA) was invalid because this legislation did not satisfy the requirements of Section 76 of the Constitution.
af.right_and_principle:
The Constitutional Court needed to resolve the following major questions:
(a) Did Parliament follow the correct procedure in enacting CLARA?
(b) Did Parliament comply with its constitutional obligation to facilitate public involvement in the legislative process in enacting CLARA?
(c) Should the order of invalidity be confirmed?
(d) What relief, if any, were the applicant communities entitled to?
af.snippet: This case concerned whether Parliament had followed the correct legal process in enacting the Communal Land Rights Act [No. 11 of 2004] (CLARA).
af.title: Tongoane and Others v National Minister for Agriculture and Land Affairs and Others (CCT 100 of 2009) [2010] ZACC 10

af.facts_and_issues:
Die applikante het by die Konstitusionele Hof aansoek gedoen om verlof om teen 'n uitspraak van die Pretoriase Hooggeregshof te appelleer wat verband hou met die regte van vlugtelinge om in die private sekuriteitsbedryf in Suid-Afrika te werk. Die Wet op die Regulering van die Private Sekuriteitsbedryf 56 van 2001 (die Sekuriteitswet) vereis dat sekuriteitsdiensverskaffers by die Reguleringsowerheid vir die Private Sekuriteitsbedryf (die Owerheid) registreer. Artikel 23(1)(a) van die Sekuriteitswet lys burgerskap of permanente verblyf as 'n vereiste vir registrasie. Ten spyte van die bepalings van artikel 23(1)(a), staan artikel 23(6) aan die Owerheid die besluit toe om enige applikant as 'n sekuriteitsdiensverskaffer te registreer, op grond van goeie redes en op gronde wat nie teenstrydig is met die doel van die Veiligheidswet en die oogmerke van die Owerheid.

Al die applikante, behalwe die eerste applikant, het by die Owerheid aansoek gedoen om as sekuriteitsdiensverskaffers ingevolge die Sekuriteitswet geregistreer te word en is aanvanklik geregistreer. Die tweede tot sesde applikante het egter daarna 'n kennisgewing van die Owerheid ontvang dat hulle van plan is om hul registrasie terug te trek aangesien hulle nie burgers of permanente inwoners is nie. Die Owerheid het die tweede tot sesde applikante toegelaat om skriftelike vertoë te rig waarom hulle geregistreer moet word ten spyte van hierdie vereistes. Na oorweging van hul skriftelike voorleggings het die Owerheid egter hul aansoeke geweier en hul registrasie teruggetrek. Sommige applikante het ook na die appèlkomitee geappelleer, wat die appèl van die hand gewys het.
af.interpretation:
Die meerderheidsuitspraak wat Kondile AJ geskryf het, het sy aandag gevestig op die grondwetlikheid van artikel 23(1)(a) van die Sekuriteitswet. Kondile AJ, wat vir die meerderheid geskryf het, het die gelykheidsanalise begin deur eerstens te oorweeg of die bepaling tussen kategorieë mense onderskei het en of daar so 'n differensiasie is of daar 'n wettige rasionaal vir sodanige differensiasie is. Tydens hierdie eerste been van die analise, waar na die rasionele verband tussen die bepaling en die doel daarvan gekyk word, het die Hof beklemtoon dat die private sekuriteitsbedryf 'n spesiale omgewing is en op die spel is die veiligheid en sekuriteit van die publiek in die algemeen. Artikel 12 van die Grondwet bied aan elkeen die reg op vryheid en veiligheid van die persoon, wat die reg insluit om van alle vorme van geweld uit of openbare of private bronne vry te wees. In 'n samelewing vol geweldsmisdaad, kan die belangrikheid van die beskerming van hierdie reg nie oordryf word nie.

 

Die meerderheidsuitspraak het bevind dat die regulatoriese skema sorgvuldig ontwerp is met die doel om toetreders tot die private sekuriteitsbedryf te keur eerder as om 'n algemene verbod op die registrasie van vlugtelinge as privaat sekuriteitsdiensverskaffers daar te stel. Dit is nie te sê dat buitelandse burgers, insluitend vlugtelinge, inherent minder betroubaar is as Suid-Afrikaners nie. In 'n land waar xenofobie verhoogde lyding veroorsaak het, is dit belangrik om dit te beklemtoon en te verduidelik dat dit nie is dat die Owerheid nie vlugtelinge vertrou nie. Die Sekuriteitswet is ontwerp om geskiktheid vir registrasie tot mense wie se betroubaarheid objektief geverifieer kon word te beperk, en dit is makliker om die betroubaarheid van burgers en permanente inwoners te verifieer. Die aanhef tot die Wet erken dat die reg op sekuriteit van die persoon fundamenteel is vir die welstand en tot die sosiale en ekonomiese ontwikkeling van elke persoon. Die Hof het dus bevind dat die onderskeid tussen burgers en permanente inwoners aan die een kant en ander buitelanders in hierdie geval rasioneel is en 'n wettige regeringsdoel dien.

 

By die vasstelling van differensiasie het die meerderheidsuitspraak dan oorweeg of die differensiasie op diskriminasie neerkom. Die Hof het bevind dat die differensiasie in hierdie geval op gronde analoog was aan dié gelys in artikel 9(3) van die Grondwet, en dus diskriminasie daarstel. Die analise het toe gedraai of die diskriminasie onbillik is. Verskeie faktore is deur die Hof oorweeg oor die kwessie van billikheid, soos die feit dat terwyl vlugtelinge ten volle geregtig is om in Suid-Afrika te werk, artikel 22 van die Grondwet die reg om 'n werk te kies tot slegs burgers beperk. Die Hof was ook van mening dat vlugtelinge as sekuriteitsdiensverskaffers geregistreer kan word indien aan die vereistes van artikel 23(6) van die Veiligheidswet voldoen word en dat daar geen volledige uitsluiting van vlugtelinge van registrasie is nie. Die meerderheid het bevind dat artikel 23(1)(a) van die Sekuriteitswet nie onbillik teen die applikante diskrimineer nie en dus grondwetlik gesond is.

Mokgoro J en O'Regan J het in hul afwykende uitspraak bevind dat artikel 23(1)(a) van die Veiligheidswet onbillik diskrimineer op grond van vlugtelingstatus. Die gesamentlike afwykende uitspraak was nie oortuig dat die doel wat die Minister geïdentifiseer het, naamlik om te verseker dat sekuriteitsdienswerknemers betroubaar is, werklik deur die artikel bedoel is nie. Die andersdenkende regter het verklaar dat die bevel wat hy sou voorgestel het, was om te vereis dat vlugtelinge wat aan die ander vereistes van die Veiligheidswet kan voldoen, nie belet moet word om as sekuriteitsdiensverskaffers te registreer nie. Daardie vlugtelinge wat nie aan daardie vereistes kon voldoen nie, moet poog om vas te stel dat daar goeie redes bestaan vir hulle om geregistreer te word soos beoog deur artikel 23(6) van die Veiligheidswet.
af.right_and_principle:
Die applikante het by die Hooggeregshof aansoek gedoen om die besluite van die Owerheid en die Appèlkomitee te hersien en tersyde te stel en in die alternatief het hulle probeer om artikel 23(1)(a) van die Sekuriteitswet strydig met die Grondwet te verklaar op grond daarvan dat dit die reg op gelykheid in artikel 9 van die Grondwet skend aangesien dit onbillik teen die applikante diskrimineer weens hul vlugtelingstatus. Die Hooggeregshof het ingestem dat artikel 23(1)(a) van die Sekuriteitswet permanente inwoners en burgers voorkeurbehandeling bied, maar die hof het bevind dat die bepaling grondwetlik voldoen as dit met ander bepalings saamgelees word en met inagneming van die doel van die bepaling.

 

Die Konstitusionele Hof moes bepaal of die Owerheid se weiering om die applikante as sekuriteitsdiensverskaffers te registreer, op grond daarvan dat hulle nie permanente inwoners of burgers is nie, geregverdig is en of artikel 23(1)(a) van die Sekuriteitswet tot die mate dit vlugtelinge van die omvang daarvan uitsluit, onbillike diskriminasie in stryd met artikel 9 van die Grondwet is.
af.snippet: Die Konstitusionele Hof moes bepaal of die Owerheid se weiering om die applikante as sekuriteitsdiensverskaffers te registreer, op grond daarvan dat hulle nie permanente inwoners of burgers is nie, geregverdig is en of artikel 23(1)(a) van die Sekuriteitswet tot die mate dat dit vlugtelinge van die omvang daarvan uitsluit, onbillike diskriminasie in stryd met artikel 9 van die Grondwet is.
af.title: Union of Refugee Women and Others v Director, Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority and Others (CCT 39/06) [2006] ZACC 23

af.facts_and_issues: The matter was referred to the Constitutional Court to confirm an order of constitutional invalidity made by the Western Cape Division of the High Court and an appeal was made against certain parts of the High Court’s order. The second to sixteenth applicants in the matter were all clients of the Stellenbosch Law Clinic and had emoluments attachment orders issued against them by clerks of the court employed in various Magistrates’ offices. The clients had approached a company known as SA Multiloan in Stellenbosch for small loans. Later when they fell into arrears, the creditor provider demanded that they sign further documents which resulted in default judgments and emoluments attachment orders obtained by the credit providers. This allowed for the automatic deduction of the judgment debt from their salaries or wages.
af.interpretation:
The majority judgment, written by Cameron J, held that it was not possible to interpret section 65J of the Magistrates Courts Act as incorporating judicial oversight (as argued by Jafta J in his minority judgment). The majority held that section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act allows the issuing of an emolument’s attachment order where the debtor consents in writing; or if ‘the court has so authorised’. The majority reasoned that the conjunction ‘or’ makes it clear that an emoluments attachment order may be obtained through the debtor’s written consent even when a court has not authorised it.

Consequently, a debtor’s section 34 right of access to court is infringed by such an execution process not sanctioned by a court.

Additionally, the majority explained that section 65J(1) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act sets the scene for section 65J(2) and contemplates that a judgment creditor, not a court, causes an emoluments attachment order to be issued from a court. Once issued, section 65J(5) provides that the order may be executed ‘as if it were a court judgment’. The majority viewed this wording as demonstrating that the section permits execution without judicial oversight. The majority judgment concluded that the language of the provision clearly shows that it permitted judicially unsanctioned enforcement of judgment debts and was therefore unconstitutional, holding that a debtor’s section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any form of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court. The majority confirmed the High Court’s declaration of constitutional invalidity of certain words in section 65J(2).
af.right_and_principle:
The issue was whether a debtor's section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any type of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court.

The applicants approached the Law Clinic to institute proceedings in the High Court to have the emoluments attachments orders set aside. The Law Clinic challenged the constitutional validity of section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 32 of 1944. The Law Clinic argued that section 65J(2) of the Magistrate’s Court Act allowed for emoluments attachment orders to be obtained without judicial oversight. The High Court agreed and declared certain words in section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act unconstitutional to the extent that it failed to provide for judicial oversight over the issuing of an emoluments attachment order against a judgment debtor. The High Court also declared that section 45 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act does not permit a debtor to consent in writing to the jurisdiction of a magistrates’ court other than that in which that debtor resides or is employed.
af.snippet: The issue was whether a debtor's section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any type of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court.
af.title: University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others v Minister of Justice and Correctional Services and Others; Association of Debt Recovery Agents NPC v University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others (CCT 127/15) [2016] ZACC 32

af.facts_and_issues:
Mr Jacobs was in a motor vehicle accident and suffered severe head injuries that impaired his mental capacity. Seven years after the accident, Mr Jacobs had been placed under curatorship, and the curator of Mr Jacobs instituted an action on his behalf against the Road Accident Fund (RAF) for payment of damages. Both the High Court and Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) dismissed the action, because it was filed after the prescribed time period in the RAF Act had already lapsed. Section 23(1) of the RAF Act stated that this type of action must be filed within 3 years of the accident. This was an appeal to the Constitutional Court against the decision of the SCA.
The court looked at sections 23 (2)(b) and (c) of the Road Accident Fund Act, as well as section 13(1)(a) of the Prescription Act, to determine whether:
(i) the RAF Act, the Prescription Act and mental health legislation should be read together;
(ii) the RAF Act limits the right to access the court, and if so, whether the limitation was reasonable; and
(iii) the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
af.interpretation:
The court read together the provisions in the RAF Act, the Prescription Act and mental health legislation. The majority of the court found that the applicant was not protected against the 3-year prescription time for compensation claims since he was placed under curatorship after the expiry of the prescribed time. 

The court held that the prescription time, which limits the right to access courts in the RAF Act, was not reasonable for as long as a person remains mentally impaired. The court noted that sections 9(1) and 233 of the Constitution required it to interpret the provisions of RAF and the Prescription Act in a manner that is consistent with international law and the right to equal protection under the law. Consequently, the 3-year prescription time in the RAF Act would not be applicable to Mr Jacobs for as long as he remained mentally impaired.

The court upheld the appeal and dismissed the special plea of prescription.
af.right_and_principle: The right to equality in terms of s 9 of the Constitution was implicated. The Court had to determine whether the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
af.snippet: The court had to determine whether the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
af.title: Van Zyl N.O. v Road Accident Fund [2021] ZACC 44

af.facts_and_issues:
The Applicant, together with the three intervening parties, are provincial governments constitutionally tasked with implementing provincial legislation. However, there was relic law from the apartheid era, Proclamation R293 of 1962, issued in terms of the Administration Act of 1927. This Proclamation governed the setting-up of special African townships by the Minister of Bantu Administration and Development in areas under the African Native Trust. This Proclamation was one of the tools with which the apartheid state disposed Africans from landholding and created barriers to Africans owning any land. Instead, Africans could only hold rights to the lands through an insecure tenure system of Deeds of Grant and Certificates of Occupancy and letting for residential purposes. The township manager had the authority to cancel this tenure at any point. Special deeds registries were created to register the deeds of grant under the legislation.

When South Africa transitioned to democratic majority rule, the President, empowered by the Interim Constitution, passed Proclamation R9 of 1997 together with amendments to the Deeds Registry Act. The impact of these changes was to regularise and create a more uniform approach to registration of titles in immovable property. The President also delegated certain legislative competencies to the provincial legislations to ensure multi-level governance. 
Consequently, the North West passed the North West Act 7 which supposedly repealed the whole of Proclamation R293. Similar to other provincial governments, it considered the Proclamation to be unconstitutional. 

DVB Behuising (Pty) Ltd was aggrieved by the North West’s decision and applied to the High Court for an order upholding the constitutionality of the provision. It also argued that the repeal had a negative impact on its property business since its clients were left with an insecure form of land tenure. This order was granted at the High Court, and was the subject of the current appeal.
af.interpretation:
The action by the North West Government to revoke regulations 1 and 3 of Proclamation R293 was of no force or consequence. This was because the Constitution did not grant provincial governments the competence to make laws involving the registration of deeds of grant. The revocation was therefore not authorised by the Constitution.
Parliament should properly consider the issue of legislative competency of the provincial legislatures and governments with regard to land tenure and security of property rights. It is important for there to be a clear demarcation of what the provincial governments are allowed to legislate about within the sole limits of their jurisdiction and those issues that can only be legislated at a national level.
Parliament will also need to carefully consider the issue of competency by assignment through secondary legislation. In a society where the Constitution is the supreme law of the land, the authority for provinces to make legislation should be derived directly from the Constitution and not an executive Proclamation.
af.right_and_principle:
The main issue before the court was whether the Proclamation was in line with the values and provisions of the Interim Constitution. 

The court also had to consider whether provincial governments had the authority to legislate on deeds registration.
af.snippet: The court had to decide whether the Constitution allowed provincial governments the authority to legislate on registration of titles in immovable property.
af.title: Western Cape Provincial Government and Others; In Re: DVB Behuising (Pty) Limited v North West Provincial Government and Another (CCT 22/99) [2000] ZACC 2

af.facts_and_issues:
The Women’s Legal Centre (WLC) brought this action, arguing that the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act were inconsistent with the Constitution. These two laws failed to recognize Muslim marriages, and were therefore infringing on the fundamental rights of parties to Muslim marriages, especially Muslim women, and any children born of Muslim marriages. The WLC argued that the Acts specifically violated the rights to equality, dignity, and access to courts, and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount in every issue involving a child (sections 9, 10, 28 and 34 of the Constitution). The Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) agreed with the WLC and held that these Acts were constitutionally invalid, and the WLC then applied to the Constitutional Court to confirm the SCA’s order.
If the application was not successful, the applicants asked the court to confirm the order of the High Court, which required the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
af.interpretation:
The court determined three main issues:
(i) whether the SCA’s order of constitutional invalidity should be confirmed;
(ii) if the order was confirmed, whether it should have retrospective effect as ordered by the Supreme Court of Appeal (meaning that the Acts are regarded as always having been unconstitutional); and
(iii) whether to confirm the order of the High Court which required the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
The Constitutional Court conducted a thorough investigation and held that the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act were indeed inconsistent with the Constitution, even though the confirmation proceedings were not opposed.
The Court found that the laws unjustly discriminated against spouses in Muslim marriages and children born out of such marriages, based on their gender, religion and marital status. The court noted that there was no justification for the discrimination. Further, the Court held that it can reasonably be assumed that, where there is unfair discrimination, the right to human dignity is also violated, unless the opposite is proved.
The court held that the laws also unjustifiably violated the right of access to courts and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount. 
On the issue of retrospectivity, the court supported limited retrospectivity of the order, to ensure that other interested parties were adequately notified of the legal consequences of this order, going forward. 
Finally, the court found that the applicants had failed to establish an obligation on the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
Parliament was ordered by the court to remedy the defects identified in the Divorce Act and Marriage Act by either amending existing legislation, or making and passing new legislation by 28 June 2024, in order to ensure the recognition of Muslim marriages as valid marriages for all purposes in South Africa and to regulate the consequences arising from such recognition. It should also consider making amendments to other laws to ensure a balance of the right to freedom of religion, family life and protection of children with other constitutional rights.
af.right_and_principle: The rights implicated are the rights to equality, dignity, and access to courts, and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount in every issue involving a child (sections 9, 10, 28 and 34 of the Constitution).
af.snippet: This case concerned the constitutionality of the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act, which failed to recognise Muslim marriages.
af.title: Women's Legal Centre Trust v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others (CCT 24/21) [2022] ZACC 23

af.facts_and_issues: After a long history of litigation between the parties, the Applicant (Mr Zuma) had disobeyed an order of the Constitutional Court to appear before a commission of enquiry on State Capture. As a result, contempt of court proceedings were launched, but Mr Zuma refused to participate, and the Court granted a judgment and order for his arrest for contempt of court. This judgment sentenced the Applicant to 15 months of imprisonment. It is this judgment and order that the Applicant is seeking to have rescinded.
af.interpretation: The court stated that the matter could be heard directly at the Constitutional Court without having first being head in a lower court. The judgment and order sentencing the Applicant for contempt of court continues to stand.
af.right_and_principle:
The main legal question before the Court was whether the Applicant’s application met the requirements for rescission in rule 42 (1(a) of the Uniform Rules of Court. This rule requires that the following conditions be met:
(a) that the party was unaware of the proceedings before the court, or
(b) that the party was precluded from participating in the proceedings, and
(c) that the judgment was erroneously sought or granted by the court.
The Court also had to consider whether the requirements for rescission according to the common law were met.
af.snippet: This case was about Mr Jacob Zuma disobeying an order of the Constitutional Court to appear before a commission of enquiry on State Capture, and the resulting contempt of court proceedings.
af.title: Zuma v Secretary of Judicial Commission of Inquiry into Allegations of State Capture, Corruption and Fraud in Public Sector Including Organs of State and Others (CCT 52 of 2021) [2021] ZACC 28

en.facts_and_issues:
The applicants were the parents of children that went to the first respondent’s school and had signed contracts for their two children with the respondent. Contained in these contracts was a clause that allowed the respondent to cancel the contract at any time, for any reason, as long as a full term’s written notice was given.

After a series of incidents where the applicants behaved inappropriately in front of young children, the respondent terminated the applicants’ contracts with a written full-term notice. The applicants then approached the High Court for an interim order to allow the children to remain at Pridwin Preparatory School pending the determination of the main application which sought to have the decision of the headmaster to terminate the contract declared invalid and set aside.
en.interpretation:
With respect to the first issue, the Constitutional Court found that the constitutional obligations imposed upon Pridwin do not arise from the contract, but instead, arise directly from the Constitution and the application of section 8(2). The Court held that section 8(2) makes it expressly clear that the rights contained in the Bill of Rights such as the right to basic education, can, depending on the nature of the right, be applied to bind private parties. Thus, section 8(2) imposes constitutional obligations on private entities, such as Pridwin. In subjecting power exercised by private (non-State) parties to constitutional control, section 8(2) recognises the importance of private interactions and their potential to violate human rights and to perpetuate inequality and disadvantage.

The Court then found that independent schools provide ‘basic education’, in terms of section 29 of the Constitution, to learners as the nature of the entity providing education is not relevant to determining whether what is offered is “basic education”. Therefore, section 29(1)(a) is an overarching right to basic education that applies to all persons and is enjoyed by children at public and independent schools alike.

With respect to the second issue, the Court held that a decision to discontinue a learner’s education would be unconstitutional and therefore invalid if the school did not give an opportunity to the learners or their parents/guardian or representatives to make representations before the decision was made by the school to terminate the parent contract and remove the child from the school. The Court held that this is premised on the fact that section 29 of the Constitution places an obligation on all schools, both private and government schools, to not impair or interfere with the right to basic education. In this case, the school was unable to demonstrate appropriate reasons for limiting the rights of the applicants to basic education without providing an opportunity to the applicants to make representations to the school before the decision to remove the children from the school had been taken. The Court therefore held that the section 29 right was impaired due to the absence of a fair procedure being followed prior to the termination of the contract. Accordingly, it was declared that that the school had the obligation to consider the rights of the applicants’ children to have their views heard on the matter and to offer this opportunity to them. Therefore, the existence and enforcement of the clause in the contract was found to be unconstitutional and invalid.
en.right_and_principle: The Constitutional Court had to determine two issues. First, whether independent schools had constitutional duties and obligations that limited their exercise of contractual rights. Second, whether the clause in the contract was a constitutionally valid one as it did not afford the other party to the contract a fair hearing before the contract was terminated.
en.snippet: The issue in this case was whether the clause in the contract between the parents and the school was a Constitutionally valid one as it did not afford the other party to the contract to state their case before the contract was terminated. Secondly, whether independent schools had constitutional duties and obligations that limited their exercise of contractual rights
en.title: AB and Another v Pridwin Preparatory School and Others [2020] ZACC 12; 2020 (9) BCLR 1029 (CC); 2020 (5) SA 327 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues: The applicants applied for leave to appeal directly to the Constitutional Court against the order of the Pretoria High Court dismissal of a constitutional challenge to the Medicines and Related Substances Act 101 of 195 (the Act) relating to a new licencing scheme. The applicants challenged (i) section 22C(1)(a) of the Act to the extent that it authorised the Director-General of the Department of Health (the Director-General) to issue medicine dispensing licences to healthcare providers on prescribed conditions; and (ii) regulations further detailing the licensing scheme under the Act. According to the Act and the amended regulations, health care providers, such as medical practitioners and dentists, were not allowed to dispense or sell medicines unless they had been issued with a licence by the Director-General. The challenge related to (i) the authority of the Director-General to prescribe conditions for the issuance of licences, (ii) the linking of licences to healthcare providers’ premises and (iii) the factors which the Director-General had to consider when determining licence applications.
en.interpretation:
The Court determined the scope of section 22 of the Medicines and Related Substances Act and emphasised that the right goes further than merely a right to earn a living, but that the freedom to choose a vocation is an essential component of a society based on human dignity. Any limitations on the right to choose a profession would not be treated lightly. It was held that there were two components to section 22: (i) the right to choose a profession and (ii) the right to practise the chosen profession. On section 22, it was held that the regulation regulates the practice of the medical profession, but does not negatively impact the right to choose a profession.

The Court held that the right to freedom of movement in terms of section 21 of the Constitution is related to the right to practice a profession in terms of section 22 of the Constitution. The right to practise a profession includes the right to decide where to practise the profession. The Court also reasoned that the requirement of a licence does not take away the right to choose where to practise medicine; it only required that practices involving the dispensing of medicines be run from license-linked premises.

The Court concluded that the scheme for licensing which links licenses to particular premises therefore did not infringe a medical professional’s right to freedom of movement provided for in section 21 of the Constitution.
en.right_and_principle:
The applicants raised various constitutional challenges to section 22C (1)(a) of the Act and the regulations, which included the argument that regulation 18 (which provided that a licence must require a practitioner to practice from a specific approved premise) infringed section 22 of the Constitution and the constitutional right to freedom of movement enshrined in section 21 of the Constitution

The applicants alleged that the linking of licences to particular premises breached section 22 of the Constitution, relating to the freedom of trade, occupation and profession. The restriction did not merely regulate a profession but instead limited the choice of a profession. The applicants also alleged that the requirement to apply for a new licence when a medical practitioner moves to new premises breached the right to freedom of movement.
en.snippet: The applicants raised various constitutional challenges to section 22C (1)(a) of the Act and the regulations, which included the argument that regulation 18 (which provided that a licence must require a practitioner to practice from a specific approved premise) infringed section 22 of the Constitution and the constitutional right to freedom of movement enshrined in section 21 of the Constitution
en.title: Affordable Medicines Trust and Others v Minister of Health and Another [2005] ZACC 3; 2006 (3) SA 247 (CC); 2005 (6) BCLR 529 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues:
The University of the Free State formalised a bilingual (Afrikaans and English) language policy in 2003 after phasing it in since 1993. The effect (although not the intention) of the policy was, amongst other things, to separate lecture rooms for white and black students and racial tension.

After commissioning a report on the situation within the University under the 2003 policy, the University Council, after consulting stakeholders, adopted a new policy in 2016 (to be phased in over five years) which made English the primary medium of teaching and learning, with Afrikaans continuing to be used in an expanded tutorial system and selected courses.

In 2016, the University of the Free State replaced its 2003 bilingual (Afrikaans and English) language policy – which had had the unintended effect of, amongst other things, creating separate lecture rooms for white and black students and reported racial tension – with a policy to be phased in over five years which made English the primary medium of teaching and learning, with Afrikaans continuing to be used in an expanded tutorial system and selected courses. This new policy was rejected by the applicants who argued that proper research was not conducted, and that most white and some black Afrikaans-speaking students prefer to be taught in Afrikaans. The applicants saw no justification for the language policy-shift.
en.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court explained that every South African has the constitutional right to be taught in a preferred official language in our public educational institutions. But that the Constitution qualifies access to this right. The overarching condition is that the fulfilment of the promise of education in a language of choice must be reasonably practicable. What reasonable practicability means and entails was what the Court had to decide in this matter.

The Court noted that section 29(2) requires “(a) equity; (b) practicability; and (c) the need to redress the results of past racially discriminatory laws and practices,” to feature prominently in exploring the possibility of offering education in an official language of choice. These factors relate to equality, responsiveness and non-racialism.

These factors have to be read in light of the requirement is section 29(2) that the right to learn in one’s preferred language must be “reasonably practicable” for the educational institution. The Court held that reasonableness within the context of section 29(2) demands that equity, practicability and the critical need to undo the damage caused by racial discrimination, also be the intrinsic features of the decision-making process relating to effective access to education in a language of choice. For they are some of the decisive factors to which regard must be had even where “a learner already enjoys the benefit of being taught in an official language of choice”. Inequitable access and the unintended entrenchment or fuelling of racial disharmony would thus be the “appropriate justification” for taking away or diminishing the already existing enjoyment of the right to be taught in one’s mother tongue. At a conceptual level, dual medium institutions might well exist without necessarily nurturing or perpetuating unfair advantage or racial discrimination and its exceedingly harmful tendencies. When that is so, then the right to be taught in a language of choice could be effectively accessible and implemented.

The Court held that it would be unreasonable to slavishly hold on to a language policy that has proved to be the practical antithesis of fairness, feasibility, inclusivity and the remedial action necessary to shake racism and its tendencies out of their comfort zone. The right to education places an obligation on the state to take “reasonable measures” to make education “progressively available and accessible”, and the impermissibility of racial discrimination, intended or otherwise, in all our educational institutions. It is with the benefit of this perspective, that reasonable practicability must now be given meaning.

The Court explained that it may be practically possible or feasible to retain Afrikaans as a major medium of instruction; but – given that the link between racially segregated lectures and racial tensions had not been denied by any of the parties – it was not ‘reasonably practicable’ to maintain the 2003 bilingual policy if that policy endangered race relations and threatened to perpetuate racial discrimination. The Court ruled that the fuelling of racial tension was an ‘appropriate justification’ for limiting the existing access to the right to be taught in one’s mother tongue – in this case the right was already enjoyed by Afrikaans-speaking students at the University and was being limited by the shift to the primary English system.

Therefore, the Court found the adoption of the 2016 policy was lawful and valid.
en.right_and_principle: Section 29(2) of the Constitution entitles everyone to education in the language of their choice in public institutions where ‘reasonably practicable’, taking into account: (a) equity; (b) practicability; and (c) the need to redress the results of past racially discriminatory laws and practices.
en.snippet: This case was about whether the adoption of the language policy that discontinues the use of Afrkiaans as a primary medium of instruction, by the University of the Free State, is constitutionally valid and whether the University's policy is consistent with the Ministerial Language Policy Framework.
en.title: AfriForum and Another v University of the Free State [2017] ZACC 48; 2018 (2) SA 185 (CC); 2018 (4) BCLR 387 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues:
The Applicant (AK) was attacked, robbed, abducted and held captive, where she was repeatedly raped. The South African Police Services (SAPS) conducted four different searches for AK, but failed to locate and rescue her. AK was further raped and traumatized until she eventually escaped on the day after her abduction. The SAPS failed to positively connect anyone to the assault, abduction and rape of AK in the investigations that followed.
AK then instituted an action in the Gqeberha High Court. She sought to hold the Minister of Police liable, saying that the SAPS had negligently failed to conduct an effective search and investigation. The High Court ruled that the Minister was liable. The court said that the conduct of the SAPS was negligent because the searches fell below the Constitutional standard and the subsequent investigation was severely flawed. The Court also held that the negligent conduct of the SAPS was wrongful, and that not holding the SAPS liable would inhibit fundamental constitutional rights, especially in the context of the country’s scourge of gender-based violence. 
The Minister appealed to the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA), which overturned the High Court’s ruling, stating that AK had not established the requirements for delictual liability, i.e. negligence, causation and wrongfulness. The SCA held that the conduct of the SAPS during the search and investigation was not negligent and that the SAPS had used all available resources to search for AK and investigate her matter. The SCA also held that there was no causal link between the SAPS’s conduct and the damages suffered by AK.
The SCA further held that imposing liability on the SAPS in the circumstances would inhibit the SAPS in conducting future searches and investigations, and that imposing liability would open the floodgates of civil litigation. 
AK then approached the Constitutional Court and argued that the SCA was incorrect in its findings. The Minister acknowledged that the SAPS has a constitutional and statutory duty to protect the public, and specifically to prevent and investigate violence against women, but he contended that, in this case, there was no proof of negligence, causation and wrongfulness, so the SAPS could not be held liable.
en.interpretation:
AK succeeded in her appeal to the Constitutional Court. The Court held that the failure of the SAPS to conduct a reasonably effective search to find AK when she had been abducted, assaulted, and raped and, thereafter, to conduct a reasonably effective investigation to hold her perpetrators accountable, was wrongful under the law of delict and in light of the constitutional obligation on the state to suppress gender-based violence. The Constitutional Court also held that the SCA was incorrect in its findings on the law and the facts on negligence, causation, and wrongfulness, and had incorrectly upheld the appeal by the Minister against the Gqeberha High Court judgment. The order of the SCA was therefore set aside.
Parliament must consider the current scourge of gender-based violence and the possible ways to eradicate it.
Parliament must also consider the role of the SAPS and the resources available to the SAPS in eradicating gender-based violence and performing their duties overall.
en.right_and_principle: The Court had to consider this question: Is the failure of the SAPS to conduct a reasonably effective search to find AK when she had been abducted, assaulted, and raped and, thereafter, to conduct a reasonably effective investigation to hold her perpetrators accountable, wrongful under the law of delict and in light of the constitutional obligation on the state to suppress gender-based violence?
en.snippet: This case asked whether a failure by the police to conduct a reasonably effective investigation into a case of rape and kidnapping of a woman is wrongful under the law of delict, and in light of the constitutional obligation on the State to suppress gender-based violence.
en.title: AK v Minister of Police (CCT 94 of 2020) [2022] ZACC 14

en.facts_and_issues:
The matter was heard by the Constitutional Court on leave to appeal from the Labour Appeal Court. The applicants applied for the reinstatement of 103 of its members who were retrenched by the respondent. The applicant’s members were retrenched following a retrenchment agreement that was concluded by the respondents and two other unions at the mine, the National Union of Mines (NUM) and United Association of South Africa (UASA). The retrenchments took place after the respondents recognised NUM as the majority union within the company. Both the applicants and UASA became minority unions. The result was that the minority unions would be granted organisational and bargaining rights by the respondent. However, the applicants, unlike UASA, were not recognised for bargaining purposes. The retrenchment agreement was decided to the exclusion of the applicants even though it extended to its members and the agreement was made in accordance with section 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act.

The applicants approached the Labour Court and challenged both the constitutionality of section 23 (1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act as well as the dismissal of its members. The applicants argued that the collective agreement was constitutionally offensive, as it allowed for a majority union to conclude a collective agreement concerning a retrenchment process to the exclusion of minority unions in the workplace. The applicants sought to have sections 189(1)(a)- (c) and 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act declared unconstitutional and invalid but the Labour Court found there was no infringement of constitutional rights and also dismissed the other claims of the applicants. On appeal to the Labour Appeal Court, the applicants argued that sections 189(1)(a)- (c) and 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act had to be interpreted to oblige an employer to consult with minority unions despite a collective agreement with the majority union. The Court dismissed the appeal and held that the principle of majoritarianism has an important function in the Labour Relations Act to ensure orderly collective bargaining. Application for leave to appeal to the Constitutional Court followed.
en.interpretation:
The majority judgment penned by Froneman J, focused on the question whether section 23(1) of the Constitution was infringed and only lightly touched on the potential infringement of section 18 of the Constitution, the right to freedom of association. This was because only the section 23 infringement was raised in the applicant’s written submissions. In relation to the question whether section 23(1) of the Constitution was limited, the majority held that the Labour Relations Act gives effect to the right to fair labour practices and the Courts have consistently interpreted section 189 of the Labour Relation Act to exclude any need for individual and parallel consultation where a collective agreement exists. The right to individual consultation during the retrenchment process in these circumstances was found not to be supported by the Constitution nor the Labour Relations Act. The majority also held that the freedom of association challenge by the applicant failed as this would require the Court to adopt a proposition that the right to freely associate meant that every union must be treated equally, and enjoy all statutory entitlements, regardless of its size. It held further that an employee had the right to join a trade union of their preference, however this did not include the right that their preferred union be empowered in every way they desired.

The dissenting judgment by Jafta J, however disagreed with the majority judgment that the right to freedom of association challenge was not properly pleaded and held that in the context of labour relations this right enables workers to join unions of their own choice. This right is fortified by the right to form or join a trade union of one’s choice guaranteed by section 23(2)(a) of the Constitution. Jafta J further stated that there is no justification for placing majoritarianism beyond the rights guaranteed by the Constitution. The dissenting judgment concluded that the limitation of the applicants’ right to freedom of association was neither reasonable nor justifiable as no other reasons, besides the principle of majoritarianism, were raised justifying the limitation.
en.right_and_principle:
The applicant maintained that section 189(1) of the Labour Relations Act infringed on minority union and non-unionised employee’s constitutional right to fair labour practices in section 23(1) of the Constitution as it excluded these employees from the consultation process during the retrenchment process where a collective agreement was concluded with the majority union. The applicant also raised various other constitutional rights in their application for leave to appeal including infringement of the right to freedom of association in terms of section 18 of the Constitution.

The Court had to determine whether any constitutional rights are limited when an employer consults with a majority union to the exclusion of minority unions.
en.snippet: The Court had to determine whether any constitutional rights are limited when an employer consults with a majority union to the exclusion of minority unions.
en.title: Association of Mineworkers and Construction and Others v Royal Bafokeng Platinum Limited and Others [2020] ZACC 1; (2020) 41 ILJ 555 (CC); 2020 (4) BCLR 373 (CC); [2020] 5 BLLR 441 (CC); 2020 (3) SA 1 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues: The applicants applied to the Constitutional Court seeking leave to appeal against a judgment and order of the Labour Appeal Court which held that a collective agreement was binding even on employees who were not members of the unions party to the agreement provided that those unions had the majority of the employees as their members in the workplace. The applicants argued that section 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act unjustifiably limited its members’ rights to fair labour practices, including the right to bargain collectively through the applicant, the right to strike and the right to freedom of association.
en.interpretation:
The collective agreement was extended in terms of section 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act (LRA). It stipulated that a collective agreement was binding even on employees who were not members of the unions party to the agreement provided that those unions had the majority of the employees as their members in the workplace. The Court held that any infringement of the right to strike was reasonable and justifiable based on the principle of majoritarianism. Majoritarianism is a policy choice which allows the will of the majority to prevail over that of the minority. The principle of majoritarianism, in this context, benefitted orderly collective bargaining. That majoritarianism was functional to enhance collective bargaining was internationally recognized. The Court found that the conclusion of an agreement under section 23(1)(d) constituted the exercise of public power and was subject to review under the principle of legality. The principle required that all exercises of public power including non-administrative action follow minimum standards of lawfulness. For these reasons, the Court decided that the agreement validly extended to the applicant’s members and the relevant statutory provisions were constitutionally consistent.

The Court, in a unanimous decision, held that section 23(1)(d)of the LRA did not infringe the right to freedom of association as the LRA enforces the majoritarian system which grants minority unions freedom of association. Minority unions had recruiting rights which the applicant had as well as organisational and deduction rights. The Court held further that the applicants had bargaining rights although they lost the right to strike while the agreement was in force. The Court said none of the non-signatory unions or employees lost any of their organisational and collective bargaining entitlements. The Court held that through affording these rights, this meant that the LRA, though premised on majoritarianism, was not a tool of oppression and did not suppress minority unions. It held that the Act gave enough scope for minority unions to organise within the workforce and canvas support to challenge the domination of established unions. The Court held that section 23(1)(d) promoted and served the goals of collective bargaining, which was a legitimate legislative end.
en.right_and_principle: The applicants argued that, section 23(1)(d) of the Labour Relations Act unjustifiably limited its members’ rights to fair labour practices, including the right to bargain collectively through the applicant, the right to strike and the right to freedom of association. The issue before the Court was whether a collective agreement concluded between the Chamber of Mines, on behalf of certain gold mining companies and the majority trade unions could be extended to bind the members of the applicant even though they had majority representation at certain individual mines but not in the company’s workforce as a whole.
en.snippet: The issue before the Court was whether a collective agreement concluded between the Chamber of Mines, on behalf of certain gold mining companies and the majority trade unions could be extended to bind the members of the applicant even though they had majority representation at certain individual mines but not in the company’s workforce as a whole.
en.title: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union and Others v Chamber of Mines of South Africa and Others [2017] ZACC 3; (2017) 38 ILJ 831 (CC); 2017 (3) SA 242 (CC); 2017 (6) BCLR 700 (CC); [2017] 7 BLLR 641 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues: Mr A, a foreign national, had entered and stayed in South Africa illegally. He was arrested and detained, and remained in detention for various periods. Eventually he brought an application to the High Court seeking an order preventing his deportation until he was given the opportunity to make an application for asylum. Mr A. said that he was at risk of getting the death penalty if he was deported to his home country. The court of first instance found that Mr A. did not qualify for the protection provided by the Refugees Act, because he had delayed in applying for asylum after entering the country. Mr A. then brought an urgent application to the Constitutional Court to assert his rights in terms of the Refugees Act and prevent his impending deportation.
en.interpretation:
The court had to determine whether the amendments to the Refugees Act were applicable to Mr A. The amendments had resulted in more stringent regulations, such as requiring an asylum seeker to obtain an asylum transit visa before entering the country. The failure to show good cause for not obtaining such a visa could then result in an asylum seeker not qualifying for refugee status in South Africa. As a result of these amendments, the court needed to provide clarity on the applicability of the principle of non-refoulement as laid down in the Ruta case.   In the Ruta matter, this Court described non-refoulement as “the concept that one fleeing persecutions or threats to ‘his or her life, physical safety or freedom’ should not be made to return to the country inflicting it”.

The court also considered whether an illegal foreigner, who claimed to be a refugee and expressed an intention to apply for asylum, should be permitted to apply in terms of the Refugees Act, and whether a delay between an illegal foreigner’s arrival in the country and his expression of an intention to apply for asylum prevented him from applying for refugee status. The court held that, while a delay in applying is relevant in determining whether an application is authentic, such a delay could not function as an absolute disqualification from initiating the asylum application process, and that the amendments to the Refugees Act did not change section 2, which provides for the principle of non-refoulement.

Lastly, the court also had to determine whether Mr A.’s continued detention was lawful or justified in terms of section 36 of the Constitution. The court held that certain periods of Mr A.’s detention were unlawful, such as when he had paid the required fine, and the periods when his detention was not authorized by a court order.

The court ordered the respondents to take all reasonable steps, within 14 days from the date of the order, to give effect to Mr A.’s intention to apply for asylum in terms of section 21(1B) of the Refugees Amendment Act.
en.right_and_principle: Section 36 provides criteria for circumstances when rights enshrined in the Bill of Rights may be limited. Rights contained in the Bill of Rights are not absolute and may be limited. Such limitation must conform to the criteria set out in section 36 of the Constitution in order to be justifiable.
en.snippet: This case was about whether an illegal foreigner who takes a long time to apply for asylum is entitled to the protection of the Refugees Act and, in particular, the principle of non-refoulement. It also concerned whether the detention of such a foreigner was justified in terms of section 36 of the Constitution.
en.title: A v Minister of Affairs and Another (CCT 115 of 2021) [2021] ZACC 50

en.facts_and_issues: In the context of the deep-sea hake trawl fishing sector, the applicant, Bato Star Fishing (Pty) Ltd, applied for an allowance of 12 000 tonnes in catch for the 2002-2005 fishing seasons. It was only allocated a quota of 873 tonnes by the respondent, the Chief Director (Department of Environmental Affairs and Tourism). Aggrieved, Bato Star Fishing challenged the decision of the Respondent to allocate it a quota of 873 tonnes.
en.interpretation:
The question was whether the decision by the Chief Director of the Department of Environmental Affairs and Tourism to grant Bato Star an 873 tonnes fishing quota for 2002-2005, as opposed to a greater tonnage allowance, was unreasonable or procedurally unfair (and therefore invalid) administrative action under PAJA and section 33 of the Constitution.

The Constitutional Court acknowledged that it would be improper to intervene in the decision-making of other branches of government unless justified, given that the judiciary is not best placed or ordinarily empowered to take legislative or executive decisions. Ultimately, after analysing the relevant factors, the Court determined that it could not intervene and invalidate the Chief Director’s decision because it was not unreasonable. Similarly, the Court found that the Chief Director had properly applied their mind to Bato Star’s application for a 12 000 tonnes fishing quota by individually rating all applications according to the relevant criteria. Finally, the Court found that the decision was procedurally fair because it was based on the applicable policy which was made publicly available.

The Court emphasised that PAJA (under section 33 of the Constitution) had largely replaced the common law as a source of administrative law, and that parties must therefore rely on PAJA first and foremost, except in exceptional circumstances, when challenging the constitutionality of conduct or a decision made by public officials.

The Court outlined that what a ‘reasonable’ decision is dependent on the circumstances of each case, taking into account a range of factors including the nature of the decision, the expertise of the decision-maker, the nature of the competing interests involved, policy considerations, the impact of the decision, whether the decision will reasonably result in the achievement of the goal, is reasonably supported by the facts or reasons for it and whether a balance between factors has been struck by the decision-maker.

Courts needed to respect the roles and constitutional authority of other branches of government when reviewing decisions, especially where the decision involves special expertise or skill – courts should not ‘take-over’ from other branches. However, this did not mean that a court should ‘rubber-stamp’ and automatically approve of unreasonable decisions merely because the case is complex.

Ngcobo J (all other judges concurring) wrote separately to discuss the need for transformation and the achievement of equality generally and in the fishing sector.
en.right_and_principle: Section 33 of the Constitution and the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 2000 (PAJA), respectively enshrine and give effect to the right to just administrative action. The right to just administrative action entitles persons to lawful, procedurally fair and reasonable decision-making (action) by public officials (and sometimes even private persons).
en.snippet: The Court discussed what a reasonable decision was in the context of administrative action.
en.title: Bato Star Fishing (Pty) Ltd v Minister of Environmental Affairs and Tourism and Others [2004] ZACC 15; 2004 (4) SA 490 (CC); 2004 (7) BCLR 687 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues:
Mr Booi was employed by Amathole District Municipality. He was charged with misconduct and was dismissed following a disciplinary hearing. He then referred a dismissal dispute to the South African Local Government Bargaining Council, where the arbitrator found him not guilty of the charges and held that the dismissal was unfair, and ordered that he be reinstated. The Municipality approached the Labour Court, which upheld the arbitrator’s findings; however, the Labour Court held that the order of reinstatement was not reasonable since the applicant’s conduct was destructive to the prospect of a continued employment relationship. The Labour Court substituted the arbitration award with an order of compensation, and Mr Booi approached the Constitutional Court to seek reinstatement. 
The Constitutional Court unanimously granted condonation and leave to appeal and upheld the appeal. In terms of section 193 (2)(b) of the LRA, the primary remedy for a finding of unfair dismissal is an order of reinstatement, unless the circumstances surrounding the dismissal are such that a continued employment relationship would be intolerable.
en.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court emphasised that, where a dismissal had been found to be substantively unfair, reinstatement would be the primary remedy according to section 193(1) of the LRA, unless the employment relationship has irretrievably broken down according to section 193(2)(b) of the LRA. The Constitutional Court determined that the language, context, and purpose of section 193(2)(b) dictate that the bar of intolerability is high to protect labour rights. Further, the court said that the evidentiary burden to establish intolerability is heightened where the dismissed employee has been exonerated of all charges.

The Constitutional Court considered that the arbitrator acted in terms of section 193(2), considered all evidence, found that it does not established intolerability, and decided to order the primary remedy of reinstatement; therefore, the arbitrator’s decision should not be readily interfered with by a review court. The Constitutional Court emphasised that arbitration awards are intended to be final and binding.

The applicant had instructed his legal representatives to secure payment of compensation in terms of the Labour Court’s judgement. This conduct may have created the impression that the applicant had acquiesced in the judgement and would not later seek to appeal it. The Constitutional Court stressed that widespread unemployment, poverty, and exploitation of employees in South Africa are hurdles that the constitutional project seeks to overcome and because the matter related to fair labour practices and job security, the Constitutional Court determined that the doctrine of peremption could not be strictly enforced. The doctrine of peremption is based on the principle that no person can be allowed to take up two positions inconsistent with one another.
en.right_and_principle:
The Constitutional Court needed to determine the proper approach to section 193(2)(b). 

The Constitutional Court also needed to determine whether the Labour Court was entitled to interfere with the arbitrator’s decision.
en.snippet: This case was a review of an order by the Labour Court which interfered with an arbitrator's decision.
en.title: Booi v Amathole District Municipality and Others [2021] ZACC 36

en.facts_and_issues:
The Applicant, Ms Bwanya, was in a committed romantic relationship with Mr Ruch, who later died. The relationship involved living together and reciprocal duties of support, and the Applicant emotionally supported the deceased whilst he took on the financial responsibilities of the home. They regarded their relationship as a permanent commitment and they presented publicly to friends and family as spouses. In fact, they intended to get married before Mr Ruch passed away. 
On his death, the deceased left a will in which he nominated his mother as the sole heir to his estate. However, his mother had predeceased him in 2013 thus his estate was treated as intestate. The Applicant lodged two claims against the estate on the basis of being the deceased’s life partner. However, the executor excluded her from inheriting under the Intestate Succession Act, and also rejected her claim for spousal maintenance under the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act. 
The Applicant approached the High Court, challenging the constitutionality of section 1(1) of the Intestate Succession Act and section 1 of the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act, because those sections exclude permanent heterosexual life partners. The High Court found the section of the Intestate Succession Act to be unconstitutional for unfair discrimination against permanent heterosexual life partners, but found that the discrimination under the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act was fair and constitutionally justifiable. 
The Applicant then directly approached the Constitutional Court seeking an order of invalidity of both sections from both Acts.
en.interpretation:
The court decided that Section 1 of the Maintenance Act is inconsistent with the Constitution, as it does not include permanent life partners of a heterosexual romantic relationship in which reciprocal duties of support had been made by the partners and the surviving spouse did not receive a share of the deceased’s estate sufficient to maintain themselves.
The meaning of ‘survivor’ in the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act must include the surviving partner in an opposite-sex long-term commitment in which there was mutual commitment to support each other and where the survivor had not received any fair share of the deceased partner’s estate.
The definitions of 'spouse' and 'marriage' under section 1 of the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act did not meet the requirements of the Constitution because of how they excluded permanent partners in committed heterosexual relationships with mutual support duties. The partners from these relationships should be regarded as spouses for purposes of the Act, and their partnership is to be considered a marriage under the Act.
Interpretations of the definitions of ‘spouse’ under the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act are to also encompass partners from a permanent romantic commitment under which the partners agree to mutually support each other.
Likewise, the definition of ‘marriage’ must include the surviving partners from the relationship defined above.
Parliament was tasked to craft a law that remedies the invalidity found by the Court within a period of 18 months after which the orders will become binding as a form of law.
Section 1(1) of the Intestate Succession Act is constitutionally null and void for its failure to include the words ‘partner in a permanent life partnership in which the partners have undertaken reciprocal duties of support’ after the word ‘spouse.’
As a result of the above, the section of the Succession Act defining the word ‘spouse’ must include the phrase ‘“or partner in a permanent life partnership in which the partners have undertaken reciprocal duties of support”. This means that whenever the word spouse appears in the Act, it will also include the added phrase. For a period of 18 months, Parliament had leeway to take measures to fix the invalidity in the Intestate succession Act. It could achieve this by amending the relevant section. However, should it fail to do so after the period has lapsed, the order of the court becomes binding law to be read into the Act when it is interpreted.
en.right_and_principle: The principal issue is whether section 1(1) of the Intestate Succession Act and section 1 of the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act are constitutional, because those sections exclude permanent heterosexual life partners from inheriting and benefiting when their partner dies.
en.snippet: The right to equality in the Constitution demands that there should be no unfair discrimination in legislation. This case is about whether section 1(1) of the Intestate Succession Act and section 1 of the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act are constitutional, because those sections exclude permanent heterosexual life partners from inheriting and benefiting when their partner dies.
en.title: Bwanya v Master of the High Court, Cape Town and Others (CCT 241/20) [2021] ZACC 51

en.facts_and_issues: The applicant was sexually assaulted by a man who was awaiting trial for the attempted rape of another woman. Despite the seriousness of the alleged crime and the fact that the man had a prior rape conviction, the police and the prosecutor had recommended that the man be released without bail. The applicant sued the Minister for damages, arguing that the police and prosecutors had negligently failed to comply with a legal duty they owed to her to take steps to prevent the man from harming her. The High Court dismissed the applicant's claim and the Supreme Court of Appeal affirmed, holding that the police and prosecution did not owe her a legal duty of protection in terms of South African law. The applicant sought relief from the Constitutional Court to determine whether the police and prosecutors owed a duty of care to a victim of sexual violence, and, if so, whether that standard of care was breached.
en.interpretation:
The Court held that the police have positive obligations to protect the fundamental rights and freedoms contained in the Bill of Rights. These fundamental rights include dignity, freedom and security. The police, therefore, had to reasonably protect women from sexual violence, and their failure to do so could result in liability.

The Court emphasised South Africa’s duty under international law to prohibit all gender-based discrimination.
