These factors are not a closed list. On considering these factors, the Court held that gay people were a vulnerable minority group in society. The Court also emphasized that “sexual orientation” as referred to in section 9(3) must be given a wide interpretation. Sodomy laws criminalised gay men’s intimate, private relationships and this degraded them and was held to constitute a limitation of their fundamental rights to dignity and privacy. On the right to privacy, the Court explained that this constitutional right allows people to enjoy a degree of private intimacy and autonomy free from outside interference and that giving expression to sexuality is at the heart of this private intimacy. Any intrusion upon consensual acts which cause no harm within this sphere breaches the right to privacy. The fact that both the rights to equality and privacy were breached emphasized how severely the rights of gay persons had been violated.

The Court then turned to section 36(1) to determine whether this limitation could be upheld as a justifiable limitation. The Court held that no legitimate purpose existed for this limitation and considering the harmful and severe impact of these provisions on gay men, the limitation could not be justified.

The Court concluded that the common law offence of sodomy, its inclusion in certain statutory schedules, and the relevant section of the Sexual Offences Act were not reasonable or justifiable limitations on the rights of gay men to equality, dignity and privacy. The common law offence and the relevant statutory provisions were accordingly found to be unconstitutional and invalid.

In a separate concurring judgement, Sachs J, held that the scope of what is constitutionally permissible had expanded and now included a wide range of perspectives to acknowledge, accommodate and accept differences. The decision of the Court should thus be seen as part of a growing acceptance of diversity in South Africa.
en.right_and_principle: The majority judgment written by Ackermann J, reiterated the stages of enquiry to determine whether there was a violation of section 9. As “sexual orientation” was listed as a prohibited ground in terms of section 9(3) it was presumed in terms of section 9(5) that the differentiation constituted “unfair discrimination” - unless it could be shown that the discrimination was fair. The Court held that although no party argued that the discrimination was fair, the Court still had to determine whether the discrimination was fair.
en.snippet: The issue was whether the offence of sodomy was an infringement of section 9 of the Constitution.
en.title: National Coalition for Gay and Lesbian Equality and Another v Minister of Justice and Others [1998] ZACC 15; 1999 (1) SA 6; 1998 (12) BCLR 1517

en.facts_and_issues: A question arose about whether certain people fell under the jurisdiction of the MIBCO (Motor Industry Bargaining Council) or the Metal and Engineering Industries Bargaining Council (MEIBC). A Commissioner of the Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration (CCMA) issued a demarcation award in terms of s 62 of the Labour Relations Act. The Labour Court then reviewed and set aside this award, and replaced it with its own ruling. On appeal, the Labour Appeal Court confirmed this order. The National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa (NUMSA) then sought leave to appeal to the Constitutional Court. The appeal was against the whole judgment and order of the Labour Appeal Court.
en.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court decided that it had the jurisdiction to hear the matter and allowed the application to proceed in the interest of justice.
The Constitutional Court had to answer the following questions:
1. whether the Labour Court has the authority to determine demarcation disputes;
2. whether the matter should be remitted to the CCMA or whether the Labour Court could substitute its decision for that of the commissioner; and 
3. whether on the merits, the judgment of the Labour Appeal Court can be faulted.
The Constitutional Court found that the Labour Court had inherent powers to substitute the CCMA award with an appropriate order. It held that the Labour Appeal Court correctly approached the appeal before it, and the Labour Court’s judgment regarding the assignment of the respondent entities to the MIBCO was correct.
en.right_and_principle: This case concerned whether the Labour Court has the power to review and substitute a demarcation award issued by a Commissioner of the CCMA in proceedings conducted in terms of s 62 of the Labour Relations Act (LRA).
en.snippet: This case concerned whether the Labour Court has the power to review and substitute a demarcation award issued by a Commissioner of the CCMA in proceedings conducted in terms of s 62 of the Labour Relations Act (LRA).
en.title: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa v Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration and Others [2021] ZACC 47

en.facts_and_issues: The matter was heard by the Constitutional Court following a decision in the Labour Appeal Court. The applicant represented 204 employees of the respondents who were dismissed after participating in a strike at shared premises of the three respondents. The applicant referred the unfair dismissal claim for conciliation to a bargaining council in terms of the Labour Relations Act 66 of 1995, but cited only one of the respondents. The dispute remained unresolved and the matter was referred to the Labour Court. The third respondent raised an objection in the Labour Court, that the applicant failed to allege that the third respondent was the employer of the claimants and the applicants subsequently brought a joinder application to join the other two respondents to the matter. The first and second respondent opposed the joinder application and held that the applicant had to first refer the dispute against them for conciliation. The Labour Court allowed the joinder, but this was set aside by the Labour Appeal Court. The applicant appealed against this decision to the Constitutional Court.
en.interpretation:
The majority judgment by Cameron J dismissed the appeal and held that the statutory provisions made it clear that referral for conciliation is a precondition to the Labour Court, which could easily have been complied with by the applicant. The applicant was obliged to give all three employers (respondents) individually notice as they were three separate legal entities. The Court found that the close association between the companies, and the fact that other respondents knew about the referral citing the third respondent, was not sufficient. The purpose of the statutory provision is to put each employer party individually on notice that it may be liable to adverse legal consequences if the dispute involving it is not effectively conciliated. But the referral cited only the third respondent as the sole target in the intended litigation. This sent out the opposite message to the other two companies.

The minority judgment by Nkabinde J, disagreed with the majority’s interpretation of section 191 of the Labour Relations Act and held that this section had to be specifically read in light of section 23(1) of the Constitution which provides that “everyone has the right to fair labour practices” and the right to access to courts in section 34. The minority held that the Court had to take into account the purpose of the Labour Relations Act which was to ensure the “advancement of social justice and labour peace” and the Court should not follow a legalistic approach to the interpretation of section 191 as the purpose of the Labour Relations Act might be defeated by such an interpretation.
en.right_and_principle: The constitutional issue the Court had to determine related to the interpretation of section 191 of the Labour Relations Act, which gave effect to section 23 of the Constitution. The applicant argued that the referral did not need to mention every employer involved and that employers could be joined later in the proceedings. The applicant held that this interpretation of section 191 would give effect to the constitutional rights to fair labour practices in terms of section 23 of the Constitution, access to courts in terms of section 34 and that the Court is mandated in terms of section 39(2) when interpreting legislation to give effect to the objects of the Bill of Rights.
en.snippet: The constitutional issue the Court had to determine related to the interpretation of section 191 of the Labour Relations Act, which gave effect to section 23 of the Constitution.
en.title: National Union of Metal Workers of South Africa v Intervalve (Pty) Ltd and Others [2014] ZACC 35; 2015 (2) BCLR 182 (CC); [2015] 3 BLLR 205 (CC); (2015) 36 ILJ 363 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues:
This matter comprises four consolidated applications by unions, representing their respective members employed in the public sector.
On 31 October 2017, the Committee of Ministers (COM), including the Minister of Public Service and Administration and Minister of Finance, tasked the Department of Public Service and Administration with negotiating wage increases for the 2018-2021 period with trade union representatives of public sector employees.
The National Treasury (Treasury) set aside R128.5 billion for pay increases for all public service employees from 2018/2019 to 2020/2021. Of this amount, R110 billion was allocated to funding pay increases for employees under the  Public Service Co-ordinating Bargaining Council (PSCBC).
The State’s initial offer was within the budgeted R128.5 billion, which the unions rejected, Another offer was made and rejected. 
The parties produced a three-year draft wage agreement exceeding the budgeted amount by R30.2 billion. The  State, however, asked  Treasury to approve a R15 billion increase of the budgeted amount for pay increases. The Minister of Finance rejected this request. He proposed the restriction of bonuses, offering voluntary retirement and the curtailment of overtime payments to free up funds for the requested increase.
Negotiations resumed later, and the unions insisted on giving effect to the three-year draft wage agreement exceeding the budgeted amount by R30.2 billion.
The COM reconvened to receive clarity on the state of the negotiations. The State informed them that there were three options regarding the existing, three-year draft wage agreement namely withdrawing the offer, confirming the offer unconditionally, or confirming the offer subject to measures that would bring it within the budget. 
The COM then approached Cabinet for guidance.  Cabinet resolved that the parties should deliberate on the financial implications of the draft wage agreement. The State did not withdraw the draft agreement and Cabinet ordered the Public Service and Administration and the Department of Public Service and Administration (DPSA) to regularise the offer and conclude the agreement. 
Treasury informed the COM that the State was not in a position to implement the draft agreement. 
The State subsequently agreed with the relevant trade union representatives, incorporating the collective agreement. This agreement was signed by a majority of the public service trade union representatives and became binding on all parties. 
According to the state, the agreement was conditional on the implementation of various cost-cutting measures but it admitted that the applicants refused to allow a clause to be incorporated into the agreement.  According to the applicants,  the collective agreement was never intended to have such a condition. 
Because of the deterioration of South Africa’s economy, the then Minister of Finance noted that public sector wages had increased significantly over the last 10 years and stressed the urgent need for cost-cutting measures. 
The State proposed a revised wage increase, but the unions refused to revise the agreement and again insisted on its implementation. Clause 3.3 was not implemented and the trade unions referred a dispute to the PSCBC, which remained unresolved. 
The unions then referred the dispute for arbitration. The arbitration was, however, postponed as the unions applied to compel the State to enforce clause 3.3 in the Labour Court. The State launched a counter-application for declaratory relief about the legality of the collective agreement and its enforcement. 
The parties agreed to ask the Labour Appeal Court (LAC) to hear the matter as a court of first instance and the court agreed. The LAC had to determine whether clause 3.3 contravened regulations 78 and 79 of the Public Service Regulations and declared the enforcement of clause 3.3 unlawful for violating sections 213 and 215 of the Constitution.
The applicants, each then lodged separate applications to the Constitutional Court challenging the order and judgment of the LAC. The DPSA and the Minister of Finance opposed the applications.
The applicants submitted that the LAC failed to consider the doctrine of estoppel which prevents the State from reneging on contractual obligations. Further, the sanctity of contracts must be upheld, and allowing the respondents to escape their obligations undermines the purpose of and the enforceability of collective agreements. 
The DPSA and the Minister of Finance contended that organs of state are bound by the law and that the collective agreement did not comply with the mandatory statutory provisions. Further, no written commitment was made by Treasury, and no written agreements were forthcoming from other departments.
en.interpretation:
The Court observed that regulations 78(2) and 79(c) of the Public Service Regulations created jurisdictional facts which must exist before the Minister negotiates and concludes collective agreements for the State. In the absence of the said jurisdictional facts, the Minister acts without legal authority. 
The Court held that the jurisdictional facts were not present. Further, non-compliance with the requirements of regulations 78 and 79 rendered the resultant collective agreement between the State and the trade unions invalid and unlawful, thus unenforceable.
en.right_and_principle: The issue was whether a collective agreement between the unions and the State was enforceable, after the Labour Court had declared it inconsistent with ss 213 and 215 of the Constitution, read together with regulations 78(2) and 79(c) of the Public Service Regulations. Section 213  of  the  Constitution  provides  for  payments  from  the  National  Revenue Fund only insofar as money has been appropriated by an Act of Parliament, or is a direct charge authorised by the Constitution or under national legislation.
en.snippet: This matter comprises four consolidated applications by unions, representing their respective members employed in the public sector, and the enforceability of a collective agreement between the State and the unions concerning wage increases.
en.title: NEHAWU v Minister of Public Service and Administration and Others; SADTU and Others v Department of Public Service and Administration and Others (CCT 21/21) [2022] ZACC 6 (28 February 2022)

en.facts_and_issues: The Constitutional Court declared the Electoral Act 73 of 1998 unconstitutional to the extent that individuals can only be elected to the National Assembly and Provincial Legislature through membership of their political parties. It is, however, important to note that the Constitutional Court did not determine what electoral system would be most appropriate as doing so would be in breach of the principle of separation of powers in terms of which lawmaking falls within the mandate of Parliament. Therefore, the Court’s order was suspended for two years so that Parliament itself would have time to remedy the Electoral Act’s defect.
en.interpretation:
The first question was approached holistically by the Court which held that that section 19(3)(b) of the Constitution must be read not only in conjunction with the right to freedom of association but also with other political rights in section 19 of the Constitution. The Court found that the choice to form a political party in terms of section 19(1) equally includes the right not to join a political party. If section 19(3)(b) is read that only by joining a political party an individual can exercise the right to stand for public office, then it conflicts with section 19(1), which equally protects the choice not to join a political party.

On the second issue, concerning the right to freedom of association, the Court held, after considering both foreign and international law, that the right equally includes the right not to be forced to join an association. Accordingly, the right is infringed by the Electoral Act which requires party membership to be elected to the National Assembly and Provincial Legislatures. The question then became whether the limitation of the right to freedom of association by the Electoral Act could be justified as a reasonable limitation in terms of section 36 of the Constitution. The Court found that the respondents were unable to justify the limitation and therefore the Electoral Act was held to be unconstitutional to the extent that it excluded independent candidates to contest national and provincial elections.

In Constitutional Court judgment section 1(d) of the Constitution was specifically considered as the Western Cape High Court, where the matter was first heard, held that the founding values of section 1(d) do not necessarily support the applicant’s case. The founding values emphasise that the Republic of South Africa is “one, sovereign, democratic state” which is founded on various core values such as human dignity, non-racialism, the supremacy of the Constitution and a multi-party system of democratic governance. It is important to note that these founding values form the premise of our constitutional order and in terms of the Constitution a high threshold is required to amend these provisions.

The majority of the Constitutional Court agreed with the applicants by finding that section 1(d) of the Constitution says nothing about the exclusivity of multi-party representation. A multi-party democracy allows different political groups to organise and participate in an election but this does not mean only political groups can do so. In this regard, the majority relied on the Constitutional Court judgment of United Democratic Movement v President of the Republic of South Africa 2003 (1) SA 495 (CC).

The dissenting judgment was written by Froneman J, who disagreed with the reasoning and outcome of the majority judgment. Essentially, he disagreed with the majority’s interpretation of ”to stand for public office and, if elected, to hold office” in section 19(3)(b) of the Constitution and held that it was not shown that the Constitution prescribes something other than political parties in its fundamental multi-party system of democratic governance.
en.right_and_principle: The constitutional challenge in the judgment required a consideration of two issues. First, the meaning of section 19(3)(b) of the Constitution , which states that “Every adult citizen has the right (b) to stand for public office and if, elected, to hold office” had to be determined. Secondly, the Court had to determine whether section 57A of the Electoral Act, read with schedule 1A of the Act (which, in effect, required a citizen to be a member of a political party to contest national and provincial elections) unjustifiably limited an individual’s right to freedom of association, provided for in section 18 of the Constitution .
en.snippet: The constitutional challenge in the judgment required a consideration of two issues. First, the meaning of section 19(3)(b) of the Constitution , which states that “Every adult citizen has the right (b) to stand for public office and if, elected, to hold office” had to be determined. Secondly, the Court had to determine whether section 57A of the Electoral Act, read with schedule 1A of the Act (which, in effect, required a citizen to be a member of a political party to contest national and provincial elections) unjustifiably limited an individual’s right to freedom of association, provided for in section 18 of the Constitution .
en.title: New Nation Movement NPC and Others v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others [2020] ZACC 11; 2020 (8) BCLR 950 (CC); 2020 (6) SA 257 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues: The matter was heard by the Constitutional Court on appeal from a judgment delivered by the High Court, Johannesburg. The applicants who were HIV positive were involved in clinical trials. During these clinical trials, they raised concerns about illnesses and fatalities among the patients. One of the concerns raised was that the consent forms for their trials were not explained to them. The second respondent was appointed to investigate the applicants' allegations. The second respondent then appointed a third party to conduct the investigation. The third-party issued a report (the Strauss report) containing the applicants' names, distributed to a few people. A published biography revealed the names and HIV status of the applicants. The applicants asked the respondents to remove their names from the book, but they refused. The applicants subsequently instituted a claim for damages in the High Court.
en.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court granted leave to appeal and held that it would be in the interests of justice to hear the matter as it involved the balancing of the right to freedom of expression on the one hand and the rights to privacy and dignity on the other hand. As the applicants’ claim was centred under the common law action, the actio iniuriarum for pain and suffering, the Court determined the matter on that action.

The majority judgment written by Madala J, first considered whether the applicants’ HIV status was a private fact and whether publication thereof was wrongful. The Court states that the right to privacy covers the right to live life as one pleases. Private facts were described as matters that, if divulged, would cause mental distress and injury to anyone in the same circumstances and are wished to be kept private. The respondents argued that the applicants’ names had been disclosed in the Straus Report, and as the report was not marked “confidential”, their HIV status was not a private fact.

The Court emphasised that information about person’s health is highly sensitive and personal in nature and raises an expectation that a person’s right to privacy in relation to this information will not be interfered with. The Court highlighted that an individual’s HIV status deserves protection against unwarranted disclosure due to the negative social connotations associated with the disease and potential discrimination. Parties must balance the need for access to information against the right to privacy in all cases and not only when other fundamental rights are at play.

The Court held that there must be a compelling social need for this expectation of privacy to be violated. No public interest justified the violation of the applicants’ right to privacy in this case.

The Court also held that the respondents did not establish if the applicants had given consent despite having time to do so, and they could have used pseudonyms which would not have taken away from the book's authenticity. The need for access to medical information was not sufficient to breach the applicants' right to privacy. The Court held that publication constituted a wrongful publication of a private fact. The Court also held that the publication violated the applicants’ right to dignity and psychological integrity. The respondents were found liable for damages from the moment of publication of the book.

In a separate concurring judgment by Sach J, it was pointed out that even though the respondents believed that the applicants had placed their medical status in the public domain, the sensitive nature of the information meant that the respondents had to exercise extra care in verifying this belief.

Langa CJ concurred with the two judgments above but disagreed that the respondents had a further duty to verify the information and ensure that the applicants had consented.

O’Regan J disagreed with the other judgments. She agreed that there was limited consent but found that imposing an additional duty on the respondents to ensure that the applicants had consented to the original publication of their names would impose a significant burden on the respondents' right to freedom of expression. O’Regan J also held that the common law must be developed with regard to media defendants and that it would be appropriate to require the media, when publishing private facts without consent, to establish whether the publication is reasonable or that they have not acted negligently in the circumstances. In this case, the publication could not be considered to be reasonable.
en.right_and_principle:
The applicants claimed their rights to privacy, dignity and psychological integrity had been violated. The High Court held that the first and second respondents were not liable for any damages at the time of publication as they assumed consent had been given.

Although the High Court dismissed the claim, the Court ordered that the applicants’ names be removed, and they were awarded partial monetary compensation. The applicants applied for leave to appeal to the Supreme Court of Appeal, which was dismissed with costs, and subsequently applied to the Constitutional Court.
en.snippet: The issue was whether the right to privacy of the applicants had been infringed when their names were revealed in association with their HIV status.
en.title: NM and Others v Smith and Others [2007] ZACC 6; 2007 (5) SA 250 (CC); 2007 (7) BCLR 751 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues:
Mr Oriani-Ambrosini, a member of the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) and the National Assembly, brought a dispute regarding the Rules of the National Assembly. The Rules required a member to acquire permission from the Assembly before introducing a Bill. The applicant argued that the requirement for members of the Assembly to seek permission to introduce a Bill violated the Constitution. The respondent was Maxwell Vuyisile Sisulu, also an MP, who was cited in his capacity as the Speaker.
 
The High Court and the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) dismissed the matter. Both courts upheld the constitutionality of majority decision-making as a legitimate democratic principle.
en.interpretation:
The Court held that Rule 243, the only rule regulating the introduction of Bills in the Assembly, does not require that a member who introduces a Bill in an individual capacity must first obtain the Assembly's permission. This rule is silent on a process followed by members acting in an individual capacity. Proof of the Assembly's permission is required where members and committees act on behalf of the Assembly and the procedure in terms of Rule 236 or Rule 238. Both these rules bear no relevance to the position of members acting in an individual capacity.
The Court held that a member of the National Assembly is not required to seek permission from the Assembly when introducing a Bill in their individual capacity, and the Rules, therefore, did not violate the Constitution.
en.right_and_principle:
The Court interpreted the applicability of the Rules of the National Assembly and Sections 55, 57 and 73 of the Constitution to determine whether:
(a) A member of the National Assembly is required to seek the Assembly’s permission to introduce a Bill.
(b) The Rules prevent a member of the National Assembly from presenting a Bill in an individual capacity.
en.snippet: This case concerned whether an MP is required to seek permission from the Assembly when introducing a Bill in their individual capacity.
en.title: Oriani-Ambrosini, MP v Sisulu, MP Speaker of the National Assembly (CCT 16/12) [2012] ZACC 27 (09 October 2012)

en.facts_and_issues:
The South African Medicines and Medical Devices Regulatory Authority Act 132 of 1998 granted the President the power to determine the date to bring it the Act into operation by proclamation.

The President issued a proclamation to bring the Act into operation, which proclamation was published in the Government Gazette. However, the system of schedules relating to medicinal substances which was necessary for the Act to be effective was not in place at the time the proclamation was issued (and the Act was brought into operation upon the publication of the proclamation).
en.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court found that the proclamation issued by the President was premature, irrational and therefore invalid because the decision to issue the proclamation without having the necessary schedules in place was not rationally connected to the purpose of bringing an effective Act into operation which would govern the manufacture, sale and possession of medicinal substances.

The implication of the Court’s reasoning and application of the Constitution in this case is that all public power, including power exercised by the President and National Executive, must be exercised both lawfully and rationally in order to be consistent with the constitutional principle of legality and to constitute a valid exercise of power.

(1) The Court confirmed that there was only one system of law under the Final Constitution and that the Constitution is supreme. Even the common law derives its force from the Constitution and is subject to the requirements of the Constitution. Therefore, the common law cannot be separated and applied independently of the Constitution.

(2) The Court explained that the principle of legality (enshrined in section 1(c) of the Constitution (‘the rule of law’)) required that all exercises of public power must be both lawful and rational. Rationality entails that an exercise of power must be related to the purpose for which the power was conferred and not be arbitrary. When determining whether an exercise of public power was rational or not, it is irrelevant that the person or body exercising the power acted in good faith. The lawfulness and rationality requirements are minimum requirements applicable to all exercises of public power and if these minimum requirements are not met, then the exercise of the power is invalid.

(3) The Court held that the President’s decision – to bring the Act into operation through the proclamation – was irrational. The issuance of the proclamation was for the purpose of bringing the Act into operation, but without the necessary regulatory infrastructure in place, the Act could not be implemented and was ineffective even if brought into operation. Therefore, the purpose for which the President exercised the power could not be achieved effectively and the proclamation was declared to be invalid as its issuance was irrational.

The previous legislation that governed the control of medicinal substances (that was to be replaced by the new Act) was to remain in force until the President determined a new date for bringing the new Act into force.
en.right_and_principle: The President after realising this error approached the courts on his own accord to set aside the decision to issue the proclamation and bring the Act into operation.
en.snippet: The Court had to decide whether the proclamation issued by the President was premature, irrational and therefore invalid.
en.title: Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association of South Africa and Another: In re Ex Parte President of the Republic of South Africa and Others [2000] ZACC 1; 2000 (2) SA 674; 2000 (3) BCLR 241

en.facts_and_issues: The applicant, the Port Elizabeth Municipality (the Municipality) required an eviction order against 68 people who erected and occupied 29 shacks on privately owned land within the municipal area. On the municipality’s version, the occupiers had been living on the land for periods ranging from two to eight years and had not applied to the municipality for housing. The occupiers indicated that they were willing to leave the property if given reasonable notice and provided suitable alternative land to which they could move. The occupiers were told they could move to a place referred to as Walmer Township (Walmer), however they rejected the proposal saying the area was crime-ridden and over-crowded and further that they feared they would have no security of occupation there and find themselves liable to further eviction. The municipality argued that if alternative land was made available to them, they would be disrupting the housing programme and forcing the municipality to grant them preferential treatment. The Municipality applied to the South Eastern Cape Local Division of the High Court for an eviction order against the occupiers and the Court ordered the occupiers to vacate the land and authorised the Sheriff to demolish the structures. The occupiers then appealed the High Court’s order to the SCA. The SCA held that the availability of alternative land was a key factor in the matter and considering that it was unclear whether Walmer was owned by the State or privately, the High Court should not have made this order without confirming whether there would be security of tenure for the occupiers when relocated.
en.interpretation:
In a unanimous judgment by Sachs J, the court held that when dealing with constitutionally protected rights, it is important to uphold the values of human dignity, equality and freedom. One of the provisions of the Bill of Rights that has to be interpreted with these values in mind, is section 25, which provides the right to property. This matter accordingly turned on determining the constitutional relationship between section 25 and section 26. Sections 25 and 26 create an overlap between land rights and socio-economic rights and it is the duty of the state to fulfil both rights. The court held that the provisions of section 25, subsections 4-9 must be borne in mind whenever section 25 was being construed; this is because under the Constitution, the protection of property as an individual right was not absolute but subject to societal considerations. The Court also held that the state has a duty to satisfy both property and housing rights provided for in sections 25 and 26 of the Constitution and must seek to balance these rights Section 26(3) of the Constitution demonstrates special constitutional consideration for a person’s home and acknowledges that a home is more than just a shelter from the elements, but is also an area of personal intimacy and family security.

The Court furthermore held that the Prevention of Illegal Eviction from and Unlawful Occupation of Land Act 19 of 1998 (PIE) cannot simply be looked at as a legislative mechanism to re-establish common law property rights. The first part of the title of PIE emphasised a shift in focus from preventing illegal squatting to preventing illegal evictions. Under PIE squatting was decriminalised and evictions were subject to requirements in line with the Bill of Rights. The provisions of PIE must be considered against the values of South Africa’s new constitutional dispensation. In making its decision, the court must consider all relevant circumstances, including the manner in which occupation was effected, its duration and the availability of suitable alternative accommodation or land, the motivation for settling on land, the degree of desperation of people who have sought land, and whether people occupied land with a plausible belief that they have permission to be there (as opposed to those who deliberately invade land to deliberately disrupt the organised housing programme and place themselves at the front of the queue). Regarding suitable alternative accommodation, the Court emphasised that this will vary from municipality to municipality and depends on the number of people facing eviction in each case and whether the municipality is able to secure suitable accommodation for unlawful occupiers without prejudicing the claims of lawful occupiers and those in line for formal housing.

The Court held that considering the period which the occupiers have lived on the land, the fact that eviction is not necessary for the land to be used productively and that this is a relatively small group of people who appear to be genuinely homeless and in need, it would not be just and equitable to order the eviction. The application for leave to appeal was dismissed with costs.
en.right_and_principle: The Constitutional Court had to determine whether the decision of the SCA to set aside the eviction order should be overturned. The Municipality sought confirmation from the Court that the Municipality is not constitutionally bound to provide alternative accommodation of land when it seeks an eviction of unlawful occupiers.
en.snippet: This case dealt with an eviction order which the unlawful occupiers believed to be invalid because of the Prevention of Illegal Eviction from and Unlawful Occupation of Land Act.
en.title: Port Elizabeth Municipality v Various Occupiers [2004] ZACC 7; 2005 (1) SA 217 (CC); 2004 (12) BCLR 1268 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues: The Limpopo Provincial Legislature passed the Financial Management of the Limpopo Provincial Legislature Bill (2009) and it submitted the Bill to the Premier for his assent and signature. The Premier raised concerns regarding the constitutionality of the Bill and he referred the Bill back to the Provincial Legislature for reconsideration in light of his concerns. The Provincial Legislature then sent the Bill back to the Premier, stating that the Bill was constitutional. The Premier then referred the Bill to the Constitutional Court for a decision on its constitutionality.
en.interpretation:
The legislative powers of the provinces are laid out by the Constitution. The Constitutional provisions on public administration or financial matters do not provide for provincial legislatures to pass Bills on the provinces’ own financial management.
The Financial Management of the Limpopo Provincial Legislature Bill, 2009 [A06-2009] is, therefore, unconstitutional since the Limpopo Provincial Legislature is not empowered to pass legislation regarding its own financial management.
Parliament should always consider the functional areas of provincial legislative competence, and what types of matters can only be legislated by the National Assembly, when drafting new legislation.
en.right_and_principle: The Court had to consider this question: Does the Constitution give the Provincial Legislature of Limpopo (Provincial Legislature) the authority to enact legislation dealing with its own financial management?
en.snippet: This case concerned whether the Constitution gives the Provincial Legislatures the authority to enact legislation dealing with their own financial management.
en.title: Premier: Limpopo Province v Speaker: Limpopo Provincial Legislature and Others (CCT 94/10) [2011] ZACC 25

en.facts_and_issues: The Western Cape government made an application to the Constitutional Court to have certain provisions of the Public Service Act, which was introduced by the Public Service Amendment Act of 1998 declared unconstitutional. This was on the basis that the provisions disregarded the executive authority of the provinces and undermined provincial authority. Under the old scheme, the public service was divided into departments at the national level and into provincial administrations at the provincial level. Departments under provincial administrations did not have the same status as national departments. Administrative responsibility for a provincial administration, including all its departments, vested in the head of the provincial administration, the provincial Director-General. Under the new scheme, a head of a provincial department is accorded the same broad functions and responsibilities as the head of a national department. Provincial departmental heads are no longer accountable to the provincial Director-General, but to the member of the Executive Council (the MEC) under whose portfolio the department fell.
en.interpretation:
The Court held that the Constitution expressly requires national legislation to structure the public service. The structure prescribed by the Public Service Amendment Act did not infringe the executive authority of the provincial Premiers, nor did it encroach upon the functional or institutional integrity of the provinces.

The Court found in one respect the Public Service Amendment Act conferred a power on the national Minister that was inconsistent with the Constitution. The national Minister was empowered to transfer functions from a provincial administration after consultation with the MEC concerned. The Court concluded that this permitted the Minister to order the transfers of functions against the wishes of the provincial government. The Court held that this power was inconsistent with the Constitution to the extent that it empowered the Minister to make such transfers without the consent of the Premier.
en.right_and_principle: The Premier of the Western Cape argued that the amendments infringed the executive authority of the province and interfered with its provincial autonomy by encroaching on the functional and institutional integrity of the province. The national government denied this and argued that the Constitution vested the power to structure the public service with Parliament, not with the provinces.
en.snippet: The Court had to decide whether amendments infringed the executive authority of the province and interfered with its provincial autonomy by encroaching on the functional and institutional integrity of the province; or whether the Constitution vested the power to structure the public service with Parliament, not with the provinces.
en.title: Premier, Western Cape v President of the Republic of South Africa and Another [1999] ZACC 2; 1999 (3) SA 657; 1999 (4) BCLR 383

en.facts_and_issues:
The President, in terms of his constitutional powers, pardoned and granted release to certain categories of people. One of the categories was “certain mothers in prison on 10 May 1994, with minor children under the age of 12 years.”

The respondent, a single father of a child under the age of 12, challenged the constitutionality of the pardon stating that it unfairly discriminated against him and his son on the grounds of sex or gender in violation of what was at the time section 8 of the Interim Constitution.
en.interpretation:
The first issue that the Court had to address was whether the powers of the President to pardon can be reviewed by a court of law. The Court found that the powers afforded to the applicant were executive in nature and as such subject to be reviewed by a court of law.

The Court found that that section 82(1) of the Interim Constitution contained non-statutory powers which included the power to grant pardons. These powers did not derive their authority from any legislation.

These powers were not legislative or judicial. Therefore, they are executive in nature as there is no fourth branch of government. This was supported by section 83 of the Interim Constitution which refers to section 82 powers as “executive acts”.

Therefore, when the President exercises constitutional powers in terms of section 82(1) of the Interim Constitution, he acts as an executive organ of government.

Since all organs of state are subject to the Constitution, which is the supreme law of the land, all exercises of presidential power are subject to the provisions of the Interim Constitution, which include the Bill of Rights. Therefore, the President’s exercise of constitutionally derived powers can be reviewed by courts of law.

The Court found that the powers afforded to the President under section 82 could be exercised without the approval of the Cabinet but the President needed to consult with the Executive Deputy Presidents (as per section 82(1) of the Interim Constitution) before exercising this power. The President was not however bound by their views.

The Court added that the section 82(1) of the Interim Constitution placed specific matters within the power of the President. It emphasised that this did not mean that if a President were to abuse this power vested in him or her under section 82(1)(k) a court would be powerless, for it was implicit in the Interim Constitution that the President will exercise that power in good faith. If, for instance, a President were to abuse his or her powers by acting in bad faith the Court saw no reason why a court should not intervene to correct such action and to declare it to be unconstitutional.

The Respondent sought to review the exercise of the President’s power on the basis that it violated the Bill of Rights by unfairly discriminating against him on the basis of sex or gender. The Court held that the pardoning of certain mothers with children under the age of 12 targeted a particular group of prisoners and was therefore discriminatory on the combined basis of sex and parenthood of children below the age of 12. A finding that discrimination occurred is not the end of the inquiry as the Interim Constitution only prohibits discrimaintion that is unfair. To determine whether the discrimination was unfair the Court looked at the impact of the discrimination. According to the Court, the impact on fathers of young children who were not released was found not to significantly compromise the dignity and worth of the men.

Further, the pardon did not discriminate unfairly because the discretion to pardon was with the applicant and the pardon did not prevent fathers from directly applying to the applicant to be pardoned.

The Court concluded that the President had exercised his discretion fairly and in a manner that was consistent with the Interim Constitution. The Court found that although discrimaintion had occurred, it was justified because it did not significantly affect the dignity and worth of the discriminated group.
en.right_and_principle: The question that arose was whether the conduct of the President towards the Respondent was discriminatory on the basis of gender or sex and therefore, violated section 8 of the Interim Constitution. The Court also considered the status of the President’s powers to pardon offenders in terms of section 82(1) of the Interim Constitution, which had, before the end of aparthied, been considered an unreviewable power of the Head of State.
en.snippet: The question that arose was whether the conduct of the President towards the Respondent was discriminatory on the basis of gender or sex and therefore, violated section 8 of the Interim Constitution. The Court also considered the status of the President’s powers to pardon offenders in terms of section 82(1) of the Interim Constitution, which had, before the end of aparthied, been considered an unreviewable power of the Head of State.
en.title: President of the Republic of South Africa and Another v Hugo [1997] ZACC 4; 1997 (6) BCLR 708; 1997 (4) SA 1

en.facts_and_issues:
This matter was referred to the Constitutional Court to confirm an order of constitutional invalidity made by the South Gauteng High Court, Johannesburg in relation to certain provisions of the Films and Publication Act 65 of 1996 as amended by the Films and Publication Amendment Act 3 of 2009.

The amended Films and Publication Act, required publishers, except for newspapers, to submit for prior approval to an administrative body certain publications that displayed certain sexual conduct that violated or disrespected the right to human dignity, was degrading or constituted incitement to cause harm.

Anyone wishing to publish such material had to submit it to the administrative body to whether to grant or deny publication permission. If permission is denied, then the material may not be published and this is a prior restraint which inhibits expression before it is disseminated. The applicants argued that the amendments to the Films and Publication Act included definitions which were overbroad and that the restraint in publication amounted to self-censorship.
en.interpretation:
In the majority judgment written by Skweyiya J, the Court emphasised that at the core of this matter is the balancing of the right to freedom of expression in light of the State’s objective to regulate publications through classification in order to protect children from exposure to age-inappropriate material and to ban child pornography

Skweyiya J stated that case law recognises that restraints on publication by a court order must be approached cautiously and should only be allowed in narrowly prescribed circumstances. p>The majority judgment pointed out that the provisions of concern relating to expressions of sexual conduct did not fall within the categories of expression not protected by the Constitution. Therefore, expressions of sexual conduct constitute protected expression in terms of section 16(1) of the Constitution . The prior classification requirement set out by the amended Films and Publication Act was limited the right to freedom of expression as any regulation of constitutionally protected forms of expression amounts to a limitation. The next issue was whether this limitation was a justifiable limitation in terms of section 36(1) of the Constitution.

On the limitation analysis in terms of section 36(1) , the majority judgment emphasised that the nature of freedom of expression embraces the freedom to form one’s own views on information or expression received.

The Court highlighted that the purpose of the provision was an important one: to protect children from exposure to inappropriate materials and to prevent child pornography.

On analysing the nature and extent of the limitation, the majority judgment pointed out that the administrative body was now the decision-maker in respect of publication as the administrative body, and not the publisher, would determine if an expression should be made public or not. The publisher’s ability to freely exercise his right to freedom of expression is curtailed as the administrative body is in control of the decision.

The majority judgment also found that there were less restrictive means to achieve the purpose of the limitation in terms of the limitation analysis.

On balancing the various considerations in terms of section 36(1) the majority judgment found that administrative classification before publication was not a justifiable limitation on the right to freedom of expression and declared the provisions unconstitutional and invalid

Van der Westhuizen J agreed with the majority’s order but provided different reasoning. Van der Westhuizen J held the provisions were constitutionally invalid because it embodied a system of prior restraint that was based on vague and overly broad criteria.
en.right_and_principle: The question before the Constitutional Court was whether these amendments in the Films and Publication Act were in line with the Constitution or whether they limited the right to freedom of expression found in section 16(1) and if so, whether it was a justifiable limitation or not.
en.snippet: The question before the Constitutional Court was whether these amendments in the Films and Publication Act were in line with the Constitution or whether they limited the right to freedom of expression found in section 16(1) and if so, whether it was a justifiable limitation or not.
en.title: Print Media South Africa and Another v Minister of Home Affairs and Another

en.facts_and_issues:
In 2018, President Cyril Ramaphosa was questioned in Parliament about a payment of R500 000 into an account which allegedly belonged to his son, Mr Andile Ramaphosa. The funds were allegedly paid by the late Mr Gavin Watson, who was the CEO of Africa Global Operations (AGO). The President explained that his son was involved in business with AGO. Later, the President explained to the Speaker that the payment was in fact made on behalf of the late Mr Watson to the CR17 campaign.
Two complaints were directed to the Public Protector regarding the relationship between the President and AGO and the alleged breach of the Executive Ethics Code (the Code) by the President. The Public Protector found that the President deliberately misled the National Assembly (NA) and exposed himself to a situation involving the risk of a conflict between his official duties and his private interests, or used his position to enrich himself and his son.
The President applied to the High Court, asking the court to review and set aside the Public Protector’s report. AmaBhungane Centre for Investigative Journalism filed a conditional application to challenge the Code, and was granted leave to intervene as a respondent. 
The High Court had difficulties with the Public Protector’s finding that the President misled Parliament. It noted that the Public Protector misunderstood and misapplied the law on which this complaint was based. In addition, the High Court held that the Public Protector’s view that the President breached the Code by failing to disclose donations to the CR17 campaign was irrational and held that her conclusion on the issue of money laundering was wrong.
The Public Protector applied for direct leave to appeal to the Constitutional Court.
en.interpretation:
The majority judgment held that the Public Protector misunderstood the Code, and her finding that the President’s acknowledgement that he gave an incorrect answer in Parliament was enough to conclude that he had violated the Code. The Constitutional Court was in no doubt that the Public Protector was wrong to conclude that the President deliberately misled Parliament, and had used “wilful” and “inadvertent” interchangeably when the two terms are actually opposites. Because the Public Protector’s report revealed that, on the facts placed before her, the President did not wilfully mislead Parliament, he could not have violated the Code.

The Public Protector was also not empowered by law to investigate money laundering allegations.

The majority judgment also agreed that the Public Protector’s failure to afford the President a hearing before the decision on the remedial action was taken, made the remedial action invalid.
en.right_and_principle: This case concerned the President's compliance with the Executive Ethics Code, which prescribes standards and rules aimed at promoting open, democratic and accountable government and with which Cabinet members, Deputy Ministers and MECS must comply in performing their official responsibilities.
en.snippet: The Public Protector made a finding that President Ramaphosa had violated the Executive Code of Ethics by wilfully misleading Parliament, and the President sought to have the finding reviewed and set aside.
en.title: Public Protector and Others v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others (CCT 62/20) [2021] ZACC 19 (01 July 2021)

en.facts_and_issues: The applicant (Public Protector) investigated an agreement that was entered into by the respondent (the Reserve Bank) and Bankorp Limited during the apartheid era. In her final report, the applicant directed that the Chairperson of the Parliamentary Portfolio Committee take steps to amend the Constitution to remove the respondent’s primary objective of protecting the value of the currency and to amend its consulting obligations with the Minister of Finance. The report also recommended that the Special Investigating Unit approach the President and take steps to recover misused public funds from ABSA Bank Limited who had purchased Bankorp. The Public Protector first took this case to the High Court, where she lost and the High Court ordered her to personally pay 15% of the costs of the Reserve Bank on a punitive attorney and client scale.
en.interpretation:
The Court found that fears that the Public Protector has about the impact of a personal costs order on the institution of the Public Protector are unwarranted. Personal costs orders are not granted against public officials who conduct themselves appropriately. They are granted when public officials fall egregiously short of what is required of them. There can be no fear or danger of a personal costs award where a public official acts in accordance with the standard of conduct required of them by the law and the Constitution. Additionally, the Court held that the immunity which the Public Protector enjoys under section 5(3) of the Public Protector Act 23 of 1994 is one which she enjoys against personal liability only when she acts in good faith.

The Court held that holding public officials personally responsible for costs in cases against them is a constitutional mechanism that ensures that they act in good faith and in line with the relevant laws and the Constitution. The applicant had acted in bad faith and had exceeded the bounds of her powers and as such, she was not afforded protection under the Public Protector Act. The applicant also failed to engage with the respondent and allow them to make representations before publishing her final report. That the applicant had misrepresented herself under oath and her behaviour was found to be contradictory was further confirmation that she had acted in bad faith.

The majority judgement written by Khampepe J and Theron J (Basson AJ, Cameron J, Dlodlo AJ, Froneman J, Mhlantla J and Petse AJ concurring) agreed with the High Court that the behaviour of the applicant was in bad faith and fell short of the standards imposed by her office. As a result, the personal costs order made against her was justified.
en.right_and_principle: One of the issues in this case was whether the independence of the Public Protector would be compromised if personal costs were granted against her – as that meant that she would always operate in fear of personal adverse costs orders and would not be able to freely perform her constitutional obligations.
en.snippet: This case concerned the lawfulness of various search and seizure operations that were carried out at the officers of Mr Zuma's attorney and Thint, and at the residences and former offices of Mr Zuma. Messrs Zuma and Hulley and Thint applied to the Constitutional Court for an order for the return of their documents, arguing that Ngoepe JP should not have issued the warrants because the state failed to disclose various material facts. They argued that the warrants were overbroad and vague and effectively authorised an unbounded search of the relevant premises, contrary to their right to privacy in terms of section 14 of the Constitution. Finally, they asserted that Mr Zuma’s right to a fair trial in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution had been threatened because the warrants did not sufficiently protect his legal professional privilege.
en.title: Public Protector v South African Reserve Bank [2019] ZACC 29; 2019 (9) BCLR 1113 (CC); 2019 (6) SA 253 (CC)

en.facts_and_issues:
This was an application for confirmation of the Supreme Court of Appeal’s (SCA) declaration that section 10 of the Promotion of Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act (Equality Act) was unconstitutional. It highlighted the importance of balancing the rights to freedom of expression, dignity and equality with regard to regulating hate speech.

This application arose out of an article written by the applicant (the late Mr Qwelane, an employee of Media 24), titled “Call me names – but gay is not okay”. The article appeared to be attacking homosexual people by comparing them to animals.

The first Respondent (the South African Human Rights Commission (SAHRC)) instituted proceedings in the High Court, alleging that the article constituted hate speech, which was prohibited by section 10(1) of the Equality Act. Mr Qwelane argued that the article was a fair exercise of the right to freedom of expression, as guaranteed by s 16 of the Constitution. He went further and said that section 10(1) of the Equality Act prohibited speech that is allowed under section 16(2) (c) of the Constitution, and that it was therefore an unfair limitation of the right to free expression. 

The High Court, however, held that section 10(1) was in line with section 16(2) (c) of the Constitution.

Aggrieved by the decision, Mr Qwelane appealed to the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA). The SCA agreed with him and held that the challenged section was unconstitutional, because the words “reasonably construed to demonstrate a clear intention to be hurtful” introduced a standard of assessment of speech which is subjective to the person hearing or reading it, which is contrary to the objective standard imposed by section 16(2) (c) of the Constitution. The SCA also said that it is too vague, since it is difficult to define what “hurtful” means.
en.interpretation:
On whether section 10(1)(a) – (c) of the Equality Act must be read separately or together, the court held that the provisions should be interpreted by reading them together (conjunctively), to be in line with the constitutional standard required of laws. 

On whether the term 'hurtful' was impermissibly vague, the court said that a conjunctive reading of the provision could refer to a variety of factors or types of hurt (emotional, psychological and physical), which would require a claimant of hate speech to prove all these factors. The removal of the term “hurtful” in the provision would make it clearer.

The Court was also asked to decide whether the impugned provision and the fact that sexual orientation is a prohibited ground of discrimination led to an unjustifiable limitation of s 16 of the Constitution. The court noted that the prohibition of hate speech beyond the provisions of section 16 of the Constitution is only permissible when it is in accordance with the conditions for limitation in section 36 of the Constitution.

The court held that the inclusion of sexual orientation as one of the prohibited grounds of discrimination in the Constitution was a limitation of freedom of speech, but that this limitation was necessary to protect the rights of the LGBTQIA+ community, as it would not be possible to protect their rights without prohibiting hate speech based on sexual orientation.

In light of this, the Court had to decide on an appropriate remedy and whether Mr Qwelane’s statement constituted hate speech.
en.right_and_principle:
This case concerned balancing the rights to freedom of expression, dignity and equality with regard to regulating hate speech.
The court was asked to determine whether section 10(1) of the Equality Act required a subjective or objective assessment of hate speech. The court held that the provision required an objective assessment that considered the circumstances surrounding the expression, and not mere inferences or assumptions that were made by the targeted group. The wordings in the provision should be interpreted as plainly as a reasonable reader would.
Parliament must consider how to balance the right to freedom of speech against the right to be protected against hate speech on any of the prohibited grounds, such as sexual orientation. 
Legislation should be clear to enhance justice in its application and to be in line with the Constitution.
en.snippet: This case concerned balancing the rights to freedom of expression, dignity and equality with regard to regulating hate speech.
en.title: Qwelane v South African Human Rights Commission and Another (CCT 13 of 2021) [2021] ZACC 22

en.facts_and_issues:
Between June 2017 and May 2018, the SAPS conducted a series of raids and searches of multiple buildings in the Johannesburg inner city. Most of the searches were conducted in terms of section 13(7) of the SAPS Act and were typically done together with JMPD and/or Department of Home Affairs officials. During these raids, the occupants of the buildings were ordered to go outside whilst their homes were being searched. The occupants were also searched, fingerprinted, and ordered to produce their identity documents. 

Following this, the occupants launched an application in the High Court in Johannesburg. They wanted a declaration that all of section 13(7)  of the SAPS Act was unconstitutional because it infringes on the constitutional rights to dignity and privacy. The court held that only section 13(7)(c) of the SAPS Act is unconstitutional – by allowing the police to do searches on private homes without a warrant,  it is too broad and could be used arbitrarily to infringe on the right to privacy.

The occupants then approached the Constitutional Court for a confirmation of the High Court’s order of invalidity of section 13(7)(c), but they also sought leave to appeal against the High Court’s refusal to declare the entire section 13(7) of the SAPS Act unconstitutional. They argued that sections 13(7)(a) & (b) lay the ground for the warrantless searches in section 13(7)(c), so if section 13(7)(c) is unconstitutional, sections 13(7)(a) & (b) are equally unconstitutional. 

The Minister of Police and others argued that the purpose of section 13(7) is not restricted  to authorising warrantless searches of private homes, and it extends to other spaces. They submitted that declaring section 13(7) as unconstitutional therefore defeats its purpose. They further argued that although there is a limitation of rights, it is reasonable and justifiable, and the High Court correctly limited its declaration of unconstitutionality to section 13(7)(c).
en.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court agreed with the High Court ruling that only section 13(7)(c) of the SAPS Act is unconstitutional.  Parliament should therefore, cure the invalidity to align the SAPS Act with the Constitution. The portion of section 13(7)(c) that authorises warrantless searches was struck down and replaced with the following:
“….and within the cordoned-off area, search any person, premises or vehicle, or any receptacle or object of whatever nature in terms of sections 21 and 22 of the Criminal Procedure Act 51 of 1977 and seize any article referred to in section 20 of the Criminal Procedure Act 51 of 1977”.
This means that warrantless searches are now prohibited under the SAPS Act unless:
(a) the person concerned consents to the search for and the seizure, or
(b) the police officers conducting the search reasonably believe that:
(i) the warrant will be granted if they apply for one
(ii) the delay in obtaining such warrant would defeat the object of the search.
The Constitutional Court also said that the High Court correctly ruled that Section 13(7)(a) & (b) of the SAPS Act are constitutional. The appeal against that part of the order of the High Court in the Constitutional Court was therefore unsuccessful.
en.right_and_principle: The court had to decide whether section 13(7) of the South African Police Service Act (SAPS Act) is unconstitutional because it infringes on the right to privacy. This section empowers the police to cordon-off and conduct searches and seizures without warrants to restore public order or to ensure public safety in a particular area.
en.snippet: This case concerned whether section 13(7) of the South African Police Service Act (SAPS Act) infringed on the right to privacy and was therefore unconstitutional.
en.title: Residents of Industry House, 5 Davies Street, New Doornfontein, Johannesburg and Others v Minister of Police and Others (CCT 136 of 2020) [2021] ZACC 37

en.facts_and_issues: Mr Soobramoney (the appellant) in this matter was a 41-year-old unemployed man. His kidneys failed in 1996 and his condition had been diagnosed as irreversible. He asked to be admitted to the dialysis program of the Addington Hospital (a government hospital). He required dialysis two to three times a week. Due to his financial circumstances, he applied to a provincial state hospital to receive the treatment. However, the hospital only had 20 dialysis machines available and because of the limited resources had a strict policy regarding access to renal dialysis. Only patients that suffered from acute renal failure and were eligible for a kidney transplant were given access. Due to the nature of his illness, the appellant was denied treatment and he applied to the Durban High Court for an order directing Addington Hospital to provide him with ongoing dialysis and treatment and interdicting the hospital from refusing him admission to the renal unit. The Durban High Court dismissed the application and the appellant urgently applied to the Constitutional Court to hear the matter.
en.interpretation:
First, the Court considered section 27(3) of the Constitution. The Court emphasised that the right to not be refused emergency medical treatment related to the right to receive immediate medical attention following a sudden catastrophe and not to be turned away from a hospital that is able to provide the necessary treatment. The appellant had a chronic and irreversible medical condition and needed renal dialysis two to three times a week and this did not constitute an emergency in terms of section 27(3) of the Constitution. The Constitutional Court, therefore, dismissed the appeal and held that there was no breach of the constitutional obligation resting on the state in this matter.

Secondly, the Court considered the constitutional obligation resting on the State to provide everyone access to healthcare services in terms of section 27 of the Constitution from chronic renal failure and required dialysis treatment. The Court affirmed that the rights that individuals enjoy in terms of section 27 of the Constitution are dependent upon the resources available for such purposes, and that the corresponding rights themselves are limited by the lack of resources. The Court found that the provincial health department’s resources were already severely strained and that if the Court were to decide that treatment had to be provided to Mr Soobramoney it would also have to be provided to all others in a similar position and the resources available to the hospital could not accommodate the demand. Furthermore, the cost of providing renal dialysis twice a week to a single patient is R60 000 per annum and to expand the programme to cover everyone who requires renal dialysis would make substantial inroads into the health budget and prejudice other obligations which the state has to meet.

The Court held that the responsibility for making the difficult decisions of fixing the health budget and deciding upon the priorities that needed to be met lay with political organs and the medical authorities and added that the Court would be slow to interfere with such decisions if they were rational and taken in good faith. The Court concluded that it had not been shown that the state’s failure to provide renal dialysis facilities for all persons suffering from chronic renal failure constitutes a breach of its constitutional obligations.

Therefore, the Court found that the government hospital’s refusal to provide him with dialysis did not violate section 27(1) of the nor section 27(3) of the Constitution.
en.right_and_principle: The Constitutional Court had to decide Mr Soobramoney had a right to receive ongoing renal dialysis from a state hospital in terms of section 27, which provides everyone with the right to access healthcare services, and section 27(3) of the Constitution which provides that “No one may be refused emergency medical treatment”. The appellant wanted the Court to order that the hospital be obliged to provide him treatment and held that the State had an obligation in terms of section 27(3) and section 11 of the Constitution, which provides everyone with the right to life.
en.snippet: The Constitutional Court had to decide Mr Soobramoney had a right to receive ongoing renal dialysis from a state hospital in terms of section 27, which provides everyone with the right to access healthcare services, and section 27(3) of the Constitution which provides that “No one may be refused emergency medical treatment”.
en.title: Soobramoney v Minister of Health (Kwazulu-Natal) (CCT 32/97) [1997] ZACC 17

en.facts_and_issues: The applicant was appealing a judgment made by the Supreme Court of Appeal where the court granted permission only to broadcast visuals of the respondents pending trial, but without sound. The Supreme Court of Appeal held that the competing rights of the applicant to freedom of expression and of the respondents to a fair trial needed to be balanced. In the circumstances, the respondents' right to a fair trial took precedence over the applicant’s right to freedom of expression. The Supreme Court of Appeal held that television and radio broadcast would inhibit interactions between the parties’ counsel and judges and importantly it might deter witnesses from testifying in the case.
en.interpretation:
The majority judgment written by Langa CJ held that the public should as far as possible be informed of what goes on in the courts. The right to freedom of expression in section 16 encompasses the right of the media not only to gather footage and deliver it to the public but also to broadcast that footage. However, as the majority pointed out, this case did not concern the banning on reporting or closing the court to the public, but it rather centred around whether broadcasting should be extended to include full audio recordings and broadcasting of the entire appeal proceedings.

The majority judgment on considering the test adopted by the Supreme Court of Appeal, emphasised that the Constitutional Court was not asked whether it would have allowed radio and television broadcasting in the circumstances but rather whether the Supreme Court of Appeal in making its decision did not act judicially in exercising its discretion or misdirected itself on the facts.

The majority judgment found that the Supreme Court of Appeal in exercising its discretion did not err in finding that the right to a fair trial took precedence in these particular circumstances. The majority judgment also pointed out that although the Constitution does not recognise a hierarchy of rights there will be circumstances where the Court in exercising its constitutional discretion to regulate its own process is justified in giving precedence to one right over another

Moseneke DCJ dissented from the majority judgment. Moseneke DCJ held that the test used by the Supreme Court of Appeal in deciding not to allow the applicant to broadcast the sound of the proceedings valued the right to a fair trial above that of freedom of expression. This was viewed as an inappropriate test because there is no hierarchy of rights and prejudiced the rights of broadcasters. Secondly, Moseneke DCJ found that by banning sound, the Supreme Court of Appeal had failed to consider if there were less restrictive means available to protect the respondents’ right to a fair trial.
en.right_and_principle: The issue before the Constitutional Court was whether the Court should interfere with the Supreme Court of Appeal’s discretion in terms of section 173 of the Constitution to regulate its own process and order that full audio recordings and broadcasting of the appeal proceedings be allowed.
en.snippet: The issue before the Constitutional Court was whether the Court should interfere with the Supreme Court of Appeal’s discretion in terms of section 173 of the Constitution to regulate its own process and order that full audio recordings and broadcasting of the appeal proceedings be allowed.
en.title: South African Broadcasting Corporation Limited v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others

en.facts_and_issues: On 6 February 2009, Mr Masuku (as a representative of the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU)), made certain statements regarding the conflict between Israel and Palestine in the Middle East. As a result, the South African Jewish Board of Deputies (SAJBD) lodged a complaint with the South African Human Rights Commission (HRC), alleging that the statements amounted to hate speech. The matter was heard in the Equality Court, where it was determined that the statements did constitute hate speech as defined in section 10(1) of the Promotion of Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act1 (Equality Act). An appeal was lodged to the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) which found that the statements made by Mr Masuku did not amount to hate speech because none of the statements transgressed the boundaries of section 16 (2) of the Constitution. The decision was then appealed in the Constitutional Court (CC).
en.interpretation:
The  CC had to decide:
(a) whether the Supreme Court of Appeal was mistaken in its reliance on section 16(2) of the Constitution, rather than the relevant provisions of the Equality Act, in the light of the principle of subsidiarity;
(b) if so, what the proper interpretation of section 10(1) of the Equality Act is; and
(c) in the light of that interpretation, whether the HRC has established that the statements made by Mr Masuku constitute hate speech in terms of section 10(1) of the Equality Act.
Mr Masuku’s statement amounted to hate speech in terms of the Equality Act. Mr Masuku and COSATU were ordered to make an unconditional apology to the Jewish community within 30 days of the order.
en.right_and_principle: Equality, in terms of s 9 of the Constitution, and hate speech in terms of section 10 of the Promotion of Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act 4 of 2000.
en.snippet: The Court determined whether a statement amounted to hate speech in terms of the Equality Act.
en.title: South African Human Rights Commission obo South African Jewish Board of Deputies v Masuku and Another (CCT 14/19) [2022] ZACC 5

en.facts_and_issues:
This matter was heard by the Constitutional Court on leave to appeal from a judgment of the Supreme Court of Appeal.

The applicants organised a gathering of thousands of people to register certain employment related concerns of its members within the security industry. The gathering was the conclusion of a delayed strike action during which approximately 50 people allegedly lost their lives. It was also alleged that during the strike action private property and property of the City of Cape Town was damaged in the amount of R1.5 million.

In preparation for the gathering, the applicants had taken steps to meet the procedural requirements set out in the Regulation of Gatherings Act 205 of 1993. They gave notice of the gathering to the local authority and appointed marshals to manage the crowd. It also advised its members to refrain from any unlawful and violent behavior and requested the local authority to clear the roads of vehicles and erect barricades along the prescribed route on the day of the gathering. In spite of these precautionary measures, the gathering resulted in riot damage. The respondents claim that as a consequence of this gathering, their shops were vandalised and looted, and their property was damaged. The respondents instituted action for damages against the applicants in terms of section 11(1) of the Regulations of Gatherings Act. Section 11(1) of the Regulations of Gatherings Act provides for liability for riot damage against the convener of such gathering and section 11(2) provides a limited defence to such convener of the riot damage on the basis that the damage “was not reasonably foreseeable” and that it took all “reasonable steps to prevent the act in question”.

In the High Court, the applicants denied liability for the riot damage and challenged the constitutionality of the words “and was not reasonably foreseeable” in section 11(2)(b) of the Regulations of Gatherings Act. The applicants argued that the section was not rational, and it constituted an unjustifiable limitation of the right to freedom of assembly in section 17 of the Constitution.
