The High Court found that section 17 of the Constitution does not extend to gatherings which were not peaceful and therefore section 11(2)(b) of the Regulations of Gatherings Act does not implicate section 17. Furthermore, the High Court held that if section 11(2)(b) limited section 17, it was justifiable considering the right of individuals to dignity and freedom from violence. The applicants appealed to the Supreme Court of Appeal but the Court dismissed the appeal.
en.interpretation:
Mogoeng CJ, writing for the majority considered the rationality attack on the defence contained in section 11(2). The applicants’ argued that it was not rational for a convener of a gathering to take all reasonable steps to prevent an act or omission even if that act or omission was not reasonably foreseeable. Mogoeng CJ, considered the meaning of the provision and held that there is a connection between the steps that a convener takes, within its power, and preventing harm that is reasonably foreseeable. If appropriate steps are adopted when planning a gathering and these steps are reasonable to prevent foreseeable outcomes, the taking of such steps would render any act or omission that resulted in riot damage to be classified as reasonably unforeseeable. The defence was therefore found to be rational.

Mogoeng CJ, then turned to considered whether the provision limited section 17 of the Constitution. Mogoeng J held that section 11(2) of the Regulation of Gatherings Act does limit section 17 of the Constitution as it requires conveners of gatherings to adhere to the requirements and can potentially increase the cost of organising a protest which could bar under-resourced organisations from being able to protest. The question was whether this limitation could be justified in terms of section 36(1) of the Constitution as a reasonable and justifiable limitation.

On conducting the limitation analysis in terms of section 36 of the Constitution, and looking at the importance of the right to assemble, the Court emphasised that the right to freedom of assembly is central to our constitutional democracy. It exists to give a voice to less powerful people in society and groups that do not wield political or economic power and other vulnerable persons. The right may be the only mechanism for such persons to express their concerns. Bearing in mind the significance of this right, the purpose of the limitation must be important enough to justify the limitation. The Court held that the purpose of the limitation, to protect individuals, especially those who themselves are under-resourced, who suffer damages caused by protests, is a crucial one. The Court reasoned that the public has no means to control protests whereas organisers are in a position to control and manage protests. Organizations have a choice between exercising the right to assemble or abandoning protests in order to prevent reasonably foreseeable damage. Conversely, victims of riot damage have no choice regarding what may happen to them or their property. Therefore, the Court held that the justification provided for by the law was viable and that the limitation on the right to freedom of assembly in section 17 of the Constitution was held to be reasonable and justifiable. The Court emphasized that the Regulation of Gatherings Act does not nullify the right to freedom of assembly, but imposes strict conditions on the right in order to prevent injury to persons or property.

In a concurring judgment, Jafta J held that the appeal should be dismissed, on the basis that the applicants had failed to prove that section 11(2) of the Regulations of Gatherings Act limited the right to freedom of assembly. Jafta J held that the applicants failed on their pleadings to formulate their constitutional challenge adequately and should have centered their constitutional challenge on section 11(1) of the Regulations of Gatherings Act, which imposes liability for damage caused due to a protest.
en.right_and_principle: Aggrieved by the outcome of the Supreme Court of Appeal, the applicants appealed to the Constitutional Court. The Court had to determine whether the defence created in terms of section 11(2) of the Regulations of Gatherings Act was rational and if so, whether the defence limited section 17 of the Constitution and whether such limitation was justifiable.
en.snippet: The Court had to determine whether the defence created in terms of section 11(2) of the Regulations of Gatherings Act was rational and if so, whether the defence limited section 17 of the Constitution and whether such limitation was justifiable.
en.title: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union and Another v Garvas and Others

en.facts_and_issues: The Constitutional Court had decided in a previous judgment that the Electoral Act was unconstitutional to the extent that it did not allow for the election of independent candidates to the National Assembly or Provincial Legislatures. It suspended the declaration for 24 months to allow Parliament to remedy the issue. Before this time had expired, the Speaker of the National Assembly (representing Parliament) applied to the Constitutional Court to have the suspension extended for a further period of six months, as Parliament was unable to enact an amendment within the given time. The respondents opposed the application, arguing that there was no valid reason for the further delay.
en.interpretation:
Part of the Electoral Act was declared unconstitutional by the Court on 11 June 2020. This decision, known as New Movement II (because it was the second matter before the Constitutional Court dealing with the same issue between the same parties), suspended the declaration of constitutional invalidity for 24 months to give Parliament time to fix the problem. The problem was that the Electoral Act only allowed adult citizens that were members of political parties to be elected to the National Assembly and Provincial Legislatures. This hindered independent candidates with no political party affiliation.
The 24-month period ended on 10 June 2022 and Parliament had still not fixed the problem. The applicants to the matter at hand (the Speaker of the National Assembly and the National Council of Provinces—representing Parliament) wanted the Court to allow a further six-month extension so that they could introduce a Bill that could fix the problem. A Bill is a proposed piece of legislation that hasn’t been officially passed yet. Parliament was opposed by the respondents (New Nation Movement NPC and others), who argued that there was no reason for further delay.
The Court decided to further suspend a declaration of constitutional invalidity of the Electoral Act 73 of 1998 for an additional six months, giving Parliament time to amend the Electoral Act, on 10 June 2022 and gave reasons for its decision on 29 June 2022. The first part of the decision was so urgent that there was a delay in the Constitutional Court providing its reasons.
Parliament was given an additional six months to remedy the constitutional invalidity of the Act. Parliament seeks to pass an amendment to the Electoral Act that will fix the problem of independent candidates not being able to be elected to the National Assembly and Provincial Legislatures. The issue must now be fixed by 10 December 2022.
en.right_and_principle: This matter can be understood as the second part of a ‘two-part’ decision. The Constitutional Court had to consider whether to further suspend a declaration of constitutional invalidity of the Electoral Act (73 of 1998) for an additional six months, giving Parliament more time to amend the Electoral Act. Although the Court has decided that the Electoral Act is unconstitutional, it has suspended the declaration thereof giving Parliament the time to fix the problem as this is sometimes considered a more effective solution to an unconstitutional piece of legislation.
en.snippet: This matter can be understood as the second part of a ‘two-part’ decision. The Constitutional Court had to consider whether to further suspend a declaration of constitutional invalidity of the Electoral Act 73 of 1998 for an additional six months, giving Parliament more time to amend the Electoral Act.
en.title: Speaker of National Assembly and Another v New Nation Movement NPC and Others (CCT 110/19) [2022] ZACC 24

en.facts_and_issues: The matter was referred to the Constitutional Court in terms of section 172(2) of the Constitution to confirm the declaration of constitutional invalidity of section 51(1) the Criminal Law Amendment Act 105 of 1997 made by the Eastern Cape High Court. Section 51(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, obliged a High Court to sentence people convicted of certain serious offences to life imprisonment, unless under section 51(3)(a) “substantial and compelling circumstances” justified the imposition of a lesser sentence. The Eastern Cape High Court declared the section to be constitutionally invalid on the basis that it was inconsistent with both section 35(3)(c) of the Constitution which made provisions for the right to be tried before an ordinary court and the constitutional doctrine of the separation of powers.
en.interpretation:
On the question whether the doctrine of the separation of powers was infringed, the Court held that the legislature and the executive share interests in the punishment imposed by courts and that punishment was not at the exclusive discretion of the courts. Both the executive and the legislature share an interest in the nature and severity of punishment. It is the purview of the legislature to determine which acts should be criminalised and punished. The separation here was not absolute as this legislative function is checked by the courts to ensure its constitutional compliance. The executive had a duty to ensure that citizens are protected from persons who break the law. In order to carry out these obligations the executive and legislature must have the power under the Constitution to do so.

The powers of the legislature are not unlimited and the Court pointed out that legislation by its nature is general (and not specific to individual cases) and the power of the legislature should be balanced with that of the judiciary to apply and adapt a principle in an individual case. It would go against the rule of law to require the judiciary to impose a punishment which is out of proportion to the crime committed.

It was held that the legislature does not have the power to compel courts to impose sentences which are inconsistent with the Constitution. The Court held that section 51(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment does not oblige courts to impose a sentence which would limit an offender’s section 12(1)(e) constitutional right not to be treated in a cruel, inhuman or degrading way and therefore there was no infringement of the doctrine of separation of powers. The Court held further that there was no infringement of the rights contained in section 35(3)(c) of the Constitution and declined to confirm the order of invalidity by the Eastern Cape High Court.
en.right_and_principle: The Court discussed the doctrine of separation of powers and explained that separation of powers under the Constitution is not absolutely strict and embodies a system of checks and balances with the aim of preventing an over-concentration of power in any one branch of government. Intrusion by one branch of government into the domain of another is unavoidable and necessitates a dialogue between the branches. Thus, there is no absolute separation between the judiciary and the legislature and executive.
en.snippet: The applicants applied for confirmation of the constitutional invalidity of section 51(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 105 of 1997 by the Eastern Cape High Court under the provisions of section 172(2) of the Constitution. Challenge to section 51(1), read with section 51(3)(a) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, obliged High Courts to sentence people convicted of certain serious offences to life imprisonment, unless substantial and compelling circumstances justified the imposition of a lesser sentence.
en.title: S v Dodo (CCT 1/01) [2001] ZACC 15

en.facts_and_issues: The matter was heard by the Constitutional Court for confirmation of an order of constitutional invalidity made by the Pretoria High Court. The case concerned the constitutionality of the criminalisation of: (a) prostitution (carnal intercourse for reward); and (b) the keeping or managing of a brothel. Both forms of conduct were offences created in terms of the Sexual Offences Act 23 of 1957. The appellants (a brothel-owner, a brothel-employee and a sex worker) were convicted in the Magistrates’ Court for contravening the Sexual Offences Act. The appellants maintained that certain provisions of the Sexual Offences Act were unconstitutional. The High Court found section 20(1) (aA) of the Sexual Offences Act, which criminalised sex for reward, unconstitutional and invalid but dismissed the appellants’ appeal in respect of the provisions of the Sexual Offences Act which criminalised the keeping or managing of a brothel. The appellants appealed this part of the High Court’s order to the Constitutional Court and the State also opposed the confirmation of constitutional invalidity made by the High Court.
en.interpretation:
The majority judgment penned by Ngcobo J in the Constitutional Court, firstly held that this matter should have been decided in terms of the Interim Constitution.[The decision and the analysis of the Court still remain relevant].

In relation to the challenge to section 26 of the Interim Constitution, the majority held that the two subsections must be read together to determine if there was an infringement on the right. Section 26(1) of the Interim Constitution guaranteed every person “the right to freely engage in economic activity and to pursue a livelihood in the national territory”. Section 26(2) held that this does not preclude the designing of measures “to promote the protection or the improvement of the quality of life, economic growth, human development, social justice, basic conditions of employment, fair labour practices or equal opportunity for all, provided such measures are justifiable in an open and democratic society based on freedom and equality”.

The Court emphasised that section 26(2) requires there to be a rational connection between the law and the purpose for which it was enacted and if the purpose is sanctioned by subsection 2, the second question is whether it is justifiable in an open and democratic society based on freedom and equality. In this matter the Court held that the legislature was mandated to “combat social ills” and the means chosen to regulate this fell within the scope of Parliament. Parliament had a wide discretion in choosing how to combat social problems, including through the creation of new offences. Furthermore, the courts must give effect to legislative choices made by Parliament except where the choices are not in line with the Constitution. The Court emphasised that it cannot declare legislation invalid merely because it views it as ineffective or because there were better means of addressing the problem. The majority held that sex work and brothel keeping were not protected by section 26 of the Interim Constitution.

The minority judgment by O’Regan J and Sachs J, acknowledged that the challenges to section 26 of the Interim Constitution provides two possible interpretations. One interpretation is that it only relates to lawful economic activity; the other is that it relates to all forms of economic activity. However, the minority recognised that the question whether the right could be claimed only if it related to lawful economic activity did not need to be resolved at this time.

In relation to the other constitutional challenges raised, the majority and minority judgments agreed that the appeal against the High Court’s order concerning brothels should be dismissed. The majority held that section 20(1)(aA) was not unconstitutional and did not confirm the High Court’s order of constitutional invalidity and that sex work did not unfairly discriminate on the basis of gender. The minority agreed that criminalisation of sex work did not infringe the rights to human dignity and economic activity, and that any limitation on privacy was reasonably justifiable. However, the minority judgement found that the criminalisation of sex work reinforces double standards and gender stereotypes by making patrons accomplices to the crime at most and in contrast, making the sex worker the primary offender and this constituted unfair discrimination
en.right_and_principle:
Various constitutional challenges were raised against the Sexual Offences Act. It was argued that the provisions infringed on the rights to equality, freedom and security of person, dignity and the right to economic activity in terms of section 26 of the Interim Constitution.

Section 26 of the Interim Constitution which provided for the right to economic activity corresponds largely with section 22 of the 1996 Constitution which guarantees the right to freedom of trade, occupation and profession.
en.snippet: Various constitutional challenges were raised against the Sexual Offences Act. It was argued that the provisions infringed on the rights to equality, freedom and security of person, dignity and the right to economic activity in terms of section 26 of the Interim Constitution.
en.title: S v Jordan and Others (Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Task Force and Others as Amici Curiae (CCT 31/01) [2002] ZACC 22

en.facts_and_issues: In the High Court, the applicants filed an application to challenge the constitutionality of sections 15 and 16 of the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences and Related Matters) Amendment Act 32 of 2007 (the Act). They argued it was unconstitutional to the extent that it criminalized consensual sexual conduct between children. The North Gauteng High Court declared the relevant sections unconstitutional and therefore invalid. An application for confirmation of invalidity was launched before the Constitutional Court.
en.interpretation:
The Court held that in respect of whether the criminalization of consensual sexual conduct between children violated section 28 of the Constitution, it was necessary to firstly determine the scope of section 28.

The Court held that section 28(2) of the Constitution fulfils at least two separate roles. First, it is as a guiding principle in each case that deals with a particular child. Secondly, it is a standard against which to test provisions or conduct which affect children in general. The Court added that the best-interests principle is not only limited to scenarios where legislation is inflexible, the principle also applies in circumstances where a statutory provision is shown to be against the best interests of children in general, for whatever reason. As a matter of logic what is bad for all children will be bad for one child in a particular case. Thus, if there is evidence that exposing children to the criminal justice system for engaging in consensual sexual behaviour has a negative impact on them generally, then a Court may declare the scheme to be contrary to the best interests of the child in terms of section 28(2), and therefore invalid.

Therefore, section 28 is both a self-standing right and a guiding principle in respect of all matters affecting the child. What is in the best interests of the child in each case will require a consideration of various factors. Further, it is not necessary that the specific interests of the child in the case before the court are affected, but rather whether the interests of children in general are affected. Legislation would be inconsistent with this right if it is demonstrated to be against the interests of children in general.

In a unanimous judgment, the Constitutional Court found that sections 15 and 16 of the Act were unconstitutional in that they infringed the rights of adolescents (12- to 16-year olds) to dignity and privacy, and further in that they violated the best-interests principle contained in section 28(2) of the Constitution. The Court held that the sections infringed the best-interests principle in many ways. Most importantly, the offences created by the provisions ran the risk of exposing children to the harmful effects of the criminal justice system and could undermine support structures by deterring adolescents from seeking help and could create a breakdown in parental care.

 

Relying on expert evidence, the Court concluded that the provisions criminalized what constituted developmentally normal conduct for adolescents, and adversely affected the very children the Act sought to protect. The effects of the provisions were found not to be rationally related to the State’s purpose of protecting children. The Court then found that the infringement of the best-interests principle cannot be justified in terms of section 36 of the Constitution as was no evidence that criminalising such consensual sexual behaviour would deter adolescents from engaging in it.

Therefore, the Constitutional Court declared the sections 15 and 16 of the Act invalid to the extent that they criminalized consensual sexual conduct between adolescents.

 

The Constitutional Court suspended the declaration of invalidity for 18 months to allow Parliament to amend the provisions. The Court further ordered a suspension on all investigations, arrests, prosecutions and criminal and ancillary proceedings (regarding adolescents) in relation to sections 15 and 16 of the Act, until Parliament remedied the defects identified. Finally, the Minister was ordered to take the necessary steps to ensure that the details of any adolescent convicted of an offence in terms of sections 15 or 16 of the Act will not appear in the National Register for Sex Offenders and that such an adolescent will have his or her criminal record removed.
en.right_and_principle: The applicants argued at the Constitutional Court that sections 15 and 16 of the Act unjustifiably infringe children’s constitutional rights to dignity, privacy and bodily and psychological integrity, as well as the principle in section 28(2) of the Constitution that a child's best interests must be of paramount importance in all matters concerning the child. The respondents argued that the sections do not infringe the constitutional rights of children and are rationally related to the legitimate government purpose of protecting children from the risks associated with engaging in sexual activity
en.snippet: The applicants argued at the Constitutional Court that sections 15 and 16 of the Act unjustifiably infringe children’s constitutional rights to dignity, privacy and bodily and psychological integrity, as well as the principle in section 28(2) of the Constitution that a child's best interests must be of paramount importance in all matters concerning the child.
en.title: Teddy Bear Clinic for Abused Children and Another v Minister of Justice and Constitutional Development and Another (CCT 12/13) [2013] ZACC 35

en.facts_and_issues:
The respondent (Mr McBride) worked as an operative of the armed wing of the political party, the African National Congress (Umkhonto we Sizwe) and he had been convicted for his role in carrying out a car bomb attack in 1986 that killed three people and injured 69 others. The respondent was found guilty of multiple murders and was sentenced to death. In 1997 he applied for amnesty under the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act 34 of 1995 and amnesty was granted to him in 2001.

In 2003 the respondent was a candidate for the position of Ekurhuleni Metro Police Chief. The appellant (The Citizen) in September and October 2003 published various articles and editorials questioning the respondent’s candidacy and expressed the view that he was a “criminal” and “murderer”. Some of the articles failed to mention that the respondent was granted amnesty by the National Truth and Reconciliation Commission and the respondent sued the appellant and other journalists for defamation in the Witwatersrand Local Division (South Gauteng High Court, Johannesburg), arguing that the articles impaired his dignity by labeling him a “criminal” and a “murderer” when he he was granted amnesty for these crimes.
en.interpretation:
The majority held that amnesty granted in terms of the Act did not make the fact that the respondent committed murder untrue and the Act did not prohibit frank public discussion. The court affirmed that one can defend a claim of defamation if they can convince the court that the comment was ‘fair’. The majority emphasised that ”fair” means that “criticism is protected even if extreme, unjust, unbalanced, exaggerated and prejudiced, so long as it expresses an honestly-held opinion, without malice, on a matter of public interest on facts that are true”. The Constitutional Court therefore found in favor of the appellant (The Citizen) regarding calling Mr McBride a criminal and murderer. In addition, the Court found that the appellant had defamed the respondent by claiming falsely that he was not remorseful for his actions and awarded the respondent damages on this aspect.

As the matter essentially concerned a defamation claim and the defences raised thereto, a key issue the Constitutional Court had to decide was, how to find a balance between two constitutional rights, namely The Citizen’s right to freedom of expression, on the one hand, and Mr McBride’s right to human dignity on the other. The majority emphasised that the right to human dignity is not only given separate constitutional recognition in section 10 of the Constitution but is also one of the founding values of the Constitution in section 1. Therefore, a failure to uphold the right is not only a violation of section 10 but is also a threat to a founding value underpinning the legitimacy of the State. The majority stated that freedom of expression is just as important as human dignity and one cannot say that human dignity trumps freedom of expression. Therefore, the Court held that the law of defamation must be interpreted to give effect to the appropriate balance between the right to freedom of expression, on the one hand, and a person’s human dignity on the other. The Court held on this interpretation that the requirement that a comment must be “fair” in defence to a claim for defamation gives effect to the balance between the right to freedom of expression and dignity.
en.right_and_principle: The key issue the Constitutional Court had to determine was how amnesty granted to the respondent for crimes committed during the struggle against apartheid by the National Truth and Reconciliation Commission affected a claim for defamation. The respondent was granted amnesty in terms of the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act for crimes committed in 1986.
en.snippet: The key issue the Constitutional Court had to determine was how amnesty granted to the respondent for crimes committed (during the struggle against apartheid) by the National Truth and Reconciliation Commission affected a claim for defamation.
en.title: The Citizen 1978 (Pty) Ltd and Others v McBride (CCT 23/10) [2011] ZACC 11

en.facts_and_issues:
The applicants approached the Constitutional Court for an order setting aside the orders made by the Supreme Court of Appeal in two connected matters relating to the validity and the lawfulness in the execution of warrants for search and seizure issued in terms of section 29 of the National Prosecuting Authority Act 32 of 1998 (NPA Act). The applicant in the first application was Thint (Pty) Ltd (a company which was initially indicted with Mr Shaik and his companies in relation to fraud and corruption charges) and the applicants in the second matter were Mr Zuma and his personal attorney, Mr Hulley. In 2005, the National Director of Public Prosecutions (NDPP) decided to prosecute Mr Zuma for corruption offences (which related to Mr Shaik and his companies) and other fraud and tax offences. During August and September 2005 various search and seizure operations were conducted at the offices of Thint, Mr Hulley and at the residences and the former offices of Mr Zuma on the basis of search and seizure warrants issued in terms of section 29(5) and 25(6) of the NPA Act.

In the application for the search and seizure warrants, the investigating director held that the element of surprise was necessary to ensure that no evidence would be destroyed on the premises. Mr Zuma challenged and Mr Hulley challenged the lawfulness of various warrants in the Durban High Court and held that the prosecution failed to show the need for the search and seizure, the warrants failed to provide sufficient detail relating to the offences and attorney-client privilege was potentially violated during the search and seize operations. The High Court declared five warrants invalid and the NDPP was ordered to return the items seized. Thint launched a similar challenge in the Pretoria High Court but was unsuccessful. The State and Tint appealed the High Court orders to the SCA which respectively set aside the order in the Mr Zuma and Mr Hulley matter and confirmed the Thint High Court order in a separate judgment. Following the SCA orders Mr Zuma, Mr Hulley and Thint applied for leave to appeal to the Constitutional Court.
en.interpretation:
Then the Court considered whether the warrants’ terms or their execution provided insufficient protection for the applicants’ legal professional privilege. It was held that there was no statutory or constitutional requirement for the warrants to have referred expressly to section 29(11) of the NPA Act, which provides a mechanism for the speedy resolution of claims of privilege made during a search.

Furthermore, it was held that there was nothing untoward in the manner of the state’s execution of the warrants, and specifically that the search at Mr Hulley’s offices was carried out lawfully. None of the applicants made any claim of privilege during the searches. Moreover, since those searches, the applicants have failed to claim privilege in respect of any particular item or document seized, despite having had adequate time to do so. It was held that in the absence of any evidence of actual prejudice to them, the appalicants’ argument relating to legal professional privilege had to be dismissed. The majority therefore found the section 35(3) had not been breached. The applicants’ case was dismissed and the SCA’s order was upheld.
en.right_and_principle: The applicants raised various constitutional challenges in their application for leave to appeal which included the assertion that Mr Zuma’s rights to a fair trial in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution had been threatened because the warrants did not sufficiently protect his legal professional privilege during the search of Mr Hulley’s office.
en.snippet: In this case, it was argued that Mr Zuma’s right to a fair trial in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution had been threatened because the warrants did not sufficiently protect his legal professional privilege.
en.title: Thint (Pty) Ltd v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others; Zuma and Another v NDPP and Others (CCT 89/07) [2008] ZACC 13

en.facts_and_issues: The applicants were 133 residents of Winne Mandela informal settlement in Tembisa and a voluntary organisation supporting the residents. The residents were given a state housing subsidy that granted them ownership of a stand and the house to be constructed on it. This plan was not followed through and the applicants, some waiting for more than two decades, discovered that the Municipality had unlawfully given the stands and houses promised to them to other residents of the informal settlement instead. The matter was heard by the High Court (which found in favour of the residents), then by the Supreme Court of Appeal (which merely extended the period within which the Municipality had to provide the land and houses). The Municipality then applied to the High Court to have that period further extended. The residents sought constitutional damages from the High Court and, after that failed, they sought the same from the Constitutional Court.
en.interpretation:
First, the Court considered an application for direct leave to appeal for constitutional damages, which determines whether the court will hear the matter or not. Direct leave to appeal means that, instead of going from the High Court to the Supreme Court of Appeal and then to the Constitutional Court, as is the normal process, the applicants could go straight to the Constitutional Court to ask for constitutional damages. This happens mainly when the matter is urgent or is in the public interest. The Constitutional Court granted direct leave to appeal, meaning that they heard the matter even though it hadn't followed the normal pathway through the courts.

The respondents were allowed to present additional evidence that wasn’t initially submitted before the High Court. The respondents wanted to present evidence relating to events that occurred after the most recent High Court judgment on the matter (referred to as Thubakgale III) and which they argued was relevant to the current case. The Constitutional Court agreed and allowed additional evidence to be heard.

The Constitutional Court did not agree that constitutional damages were appropriate and dismissed the appeal.
en.right_and_principle: This case was about whether awarding constitutional damages was the appropriate relief for the infringement of a socio-economic right (in this case, the right of access to housing). Constitutional damages are a special kind of remedy in terms of which the Court can order the State to pay damages for violating constitutional rights.
en.snippet: This case was about whether awarding constitutional damages was the appropriate relief for the infringement of a socio-economic right.
en.title: Thubakgale and Others v Ekurhuleni Metropolitan Municipality and Others [2021] ZACC 45

en.facts_and_issues: Four communities whose land rights were affected by the Communal Land Rights Act [No. 11 of 2004] (CLARA) had mounted a two-pronged constitutional challenge to this legislation in the North Gauteng High Court, Pretoria. One part was challenging CLARA on the ground that its provisions undermined security of tenure. The other part was contending that the way CLARA was enacted was incorrect. The substantive challenge was partially successful, and the High Court declared certain provisions of CLARA invalid. Although it found that Parliament should have followed the procedure for the passing of Bills affecting the provinces prescribed by Section 76, it did not grant relief on that account because Parliament had committed an error in good faith and did not intend to suppress the views of the provinces. It accordingly dismissed this part of the application. The High Court referred the order of invalidity to the Constitutional Court for confirmation. In the Constitutional Court, the applicants sought confirmation of the order of invalidity and sought leave to appeal against the dismissal of their application to have CLARA declared entirely unconstitutional because of Parliament’s failure to enact it according to the procedure in Section 76. The applicants also asked for direct access to the Constitutional Court and an order declaring CLARA constitutionally invalid on the ground that Parliament failed to comply with its constitutional obligations to facilitate public involvement in the legislative process in terms of Sections 59(1)(a) and 72(1)(a) of the Constitution.
en.interpretation: The judgment of the High Court was set aside and replaced by a new one from the Constitutional Court. The new order was that the whole of the Communal Land Rights Act (CLARA) was invalid because this legislation did not satisfy the requirements of Section 76 of the Constitution.
en.right_and_principle:
The Constitutional Court needed to resolve the following major questions:
(a) Did Parliament follow the correct procedure in enacting CLARA?
(b) Did Parliament comply with its constitutional obligation to facilitate public involvement in the legislative process in enacting CLARA?
(c) Should the order of invalidity be confirmed?
(d) What relief, if any, were the applicant communities entitled to?
en.snippet: This case concerned whether Parliament had followed the correct legal process in enacting the Communal Land Rights Act [No. 11 of 2004] (CLARA).
en.title: Tongoane and Others v National Minister for Agriculture and Land Affairs and Others (CCT 100 of 2009) [2010] ZACC 10

en.facts_and_issues:
The applicants applied to the Constitutional Court for leave to appeal a judgment made by the Pretoria High Court relating to the rights of refugees to work in the private security industry in South Africa. The Private Security Industry Regulation Act 56 of 2001(“the Security Act”) required security service providers to register with the Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority (“the Authority”). Section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act listed citizenship or permanent residence as a requirement for registration. Despite the provisions of section 23(1)(a), section 23(6) granted the Authority the decision to register any applicant as a security service provider, on good cause shown and on grounds which are not in conflict with the purpose of the Security Act and the objects of the Authority.

All of the applicants, except for the first applicant, applied to the Authority to be registered as security service providers in terms of the Security Act and were initially registered. However, the second to sixth applicants subsequently received a notice from the Authority that they intended to withdraw their registration as they were not citizens or permanent residents. The Authority allowed the second to sixth applicants to make written representation as to why they should be registered despite these requirements. However, after considering their written submissions, the Authority denied their applications and withdrew their registration. Some applicants also appealed to the Appeal Committee, which dismissed the appeal.
en.interpretation:
The majority judgment written by Kondile AJ turned its attention to the constitutionality of section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act. Kondile AJ, writing for the majority, started the equality analysis by firstly considering, whether the provision differentiated between categories of people and if there was such differentiation whether there was a legitimate rationale for such differentiation. During this first leg of the analysis, looking at the rational connection between the provision and its purpose, the Court emphasised that the private security industry was a special environment and at stake was the safety and security of the public at large. Section 12 of the Constitution provides everyone with the right to freedom and security of the person, which includes the right to be free from all forms of violence from either public or private sources. In a society rife with violent crime, the importance of protecting this right could not be exaggerated.

The majority judgment held that the regulatory scheme was carefully designed for the purpose of screening entrants to the private security industry rather than constituting a blanket ban on the registration of refugees as private security service providers. That is not to say that foreign nationals, including refugees, are inherently less trustworthy than South Africans. In a country where xenophobia has caused increased suffering, it was important to stress this and explain that it was not that the Authority did not trust refugees. The Security Act was designed to limit eligibility for registration to people whose trustworthiness could be objectively verified, and it was easier to verify the trustworthiness of citizens and permanent residents. The preamble to the Act acknowledges that the right to security of the person is fundamental to the well-being and to the social and economic development of every person. The Court therefore held that the differentiation between citizens and permanent residents on one hand and other foreigners in this instance, was rational and served a legitimate government purpose.

On establishing differentiation, the majority judgment then considered whether the differentiation amounted to discrimination. The Court held that in this instance, the differentiation was on grounds analogous to those listed in section 9(3) of the Constitution, and therefore constituted discrimination. The analysis then turned to whether the discrimination was unfair. Various factors were considered by the Court on the question of fairness, such as the fact that while refugees were fully entitled to work in South Africa, section 22 of the Constitution limited the right to choose a job to citizens only. The Court also considered that refugees could be registered as security service providers if the requirements of section 23(6) of the Security Act were met and that there was no complete exclusion of refugees from being registered. The majority found that section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act did not unfairly discriminate against the applicants and was therefore constitutionally sound.

In their dissenting judgment, Mokgoro J and O'Regan J held that section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act discriminated unfairly on the basis of refugee status. The joint dissenting judgment was not convinced that the purpose identified by the Minister to ensure that security service employees were trustworthy was really intended by the section. The dissenting judgment stated that the order it would have proposed was to require that refugees who could meet the other requirements of the Security Act should not be barred from registration as security service providers. Those refugees who could not meet those requirements should seek to establish that “good cause” exists for them to be registered as contemplated by section 23(6) of the Security Act.
en.right_and_principle:
The applicants applied to the High Court to review and set aside the decisions of the Authority and the Appeal Committee and in the alternative they sought to declare section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act inconsistent with the Constitution on the basis that it violated the right to equality in section 9 of the Constitution as it unfairly discriminated against the applicants due to their refugee status. The High Court agreed that section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act afforded permanent residents and citizens preferential treatment, but the Court found the provision to be constitutionally compliant if read in conjunction with other provisions and taking into account the purpose of the provision.

The Constitutional Court had to determine whether the Authority’s refusal to register the applicants as security service providers, on the basis that they are neither permanent residents nor citizens, was justified and whether section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act to the extent it excluded refugees from its scope constituted unfair discrimination in violation of section 9 of the Constitution.
en.snippet: The Constitutional Court had to determine whether the Authority’s refusal to register the applicants as security service providers, on the basis that they are neither permanent residents nor citizens, was justified and whether section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act to the extent it excluded refugees from its scope constituted unfair discrimination in violation of section 9 of the Constitution.
en.title: Union of Refugee Women and Others v Director, Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority and Others (CCT 39/06) [2006] ZACC 23

en.facts_and_issues: The matter was referred to the Constitutional Court to confirm an order of constitutional invalidity made by the Western Cape Division of the High Court and an appeal was made against certain parts of the High Court’s order. The second to sixteenth applicants in the matter were all clients of the Stellenbosch Law Clinic and had emoluments attachment orders issued against them by clerks of the court employed in various Magistrates’ offices. The clients had approached a company known as SA Multiloan in Stellenbosch for small loans. Later when they fell into arrears, the creditor provider demanded that they sign further documents which resulted in default judgments and emoluments attachment orders obtained by the credit providers. This allowed for the automatic deduction of the judgment debt from their salaries or wages.
en.interpretation:
The majority judgment, written by Cameron J, held that it was not possible to interpret section 65J of the Magistrates Courts Act as incorporating judicial oversight (as argued by Jafta J in his minority judgment). The majority held that section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act allows the issuing of an emolument’s attachment order where the debtor consents in writing; or if ‘the court has so authorised’. The majority reasoned that the conjunction ‘or’ makes it clear that an emoluments attachment order may be obtained through the debtor’s written consent even when a court has not authorised it.

Consequently, a debtor’s section 34 right of access to court is infringed by such an execution process not sanctioned by a court.

Additionally, the majority explained that section 65J(1) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act sets the scene for section 65J(2) and contemplates that a judgment creditor, not a court, causes an emoluments attachment order to be issued from a court. Once issued, section 65J(5) provides that the order may be executed ‘as if it were a court judgment’. The majority viewed this wording as demonstrating that the section permits execution without judicial oversight. The majority judgment concluded that the language of the provision clearly shows that it permitted judicially unsanctioned enforcement of judgment debts and was therefore unconstitutional, holding that a debtor’s section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any form of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court. The majority confirmed the High Court’s declaration of constitutional invalidity of certain words in section 65J(2).
en.right_and_principle:
The issue was whether a debtor's section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any type of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court.

The applicants approached the Law Clinic to institute proceedings in the High Court to have the emoluments attachments orders set aside. The Law Clinic challenged the constitutional validity of section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 32 of 1944. The Law Clinic argued that section 65J(2) of the Magistrate’s Court Act allowed for emoluments attachment orders to be obtained without judicial oversight. The High Court agreed and declared certain words in section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act unconstitutional to the extent that it failed to provide for judicial oversight over the issuing of an emoluments attachment order against a judgment debtor. The High Court also declared that section 45 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act does not permit a debtor to consent in writing to the jurisdiction of a magistrates’ court other than that in which that debtor resides or is employed.
en.snippet: The issue was whether a debtor's section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any type of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court.
en.title: University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others v Minister of Justice and Correctional Services and Others; Association of Debt Recovery Agents NPC v University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others (CCT 127/15) [2016] ZACC 32

en.facts_and_issues:
Mr Jacobs was in a motor vehicle accident and suffered severe head injuries that impaired his mental capacity. Seven years after the accident, Mr Jacobs had been placed under curatorship, and the curator of Mr Jacobs instituted an action on his behalf against the Road Accident Fund (RAF) for payment of damages. Both the High Court and Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) dismissed the action, because it was filed after the prescribed time period in the RAF Act had already lapsed. Section 23(1) of the RAF Act stated that this type of action must be filed within 3 years of the accident. This was an appeal to the Constitutional Court against the decision of the SCA.
The court looked at sections 23 (2)(b) and (c) of the Road Accident Fund Act, as well as section 13(1)(a) of the Prescription Act, to determine whether:
(i) the RAF Act, the Prescription Act and mental health legislation should be read together;
(ii) the RAF Act limits the right to access the court, and if so, whether the limitation was reasonable; and
(iii) the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
en.interpretation:
The court read together the provisions in the RAF Act, the Prescription Act and mental health legislation. The majority of the court found that the applicant was not protected against the 3-year prescription time for compensation claims since he was placed under curatorship after the expiry of the prescribed time. 

The court held that the prescription time, which limits the right to access courts in the RAF Act, was not reasonable for as long as a person remains mentally impaired. The court noted that sections 9(1) and 233 of the Constitution required it to interpret the provisions of RAF and the Prescription Act in a manner that is consistent with international law and the right to equal protection under the law. Consequently, the 3-year prescription time in the RAF Act would not be applicable to Mr Jacobs for as long as he remained mentally impaired.

The court upheld the appeal and dismissed the special plea of prescription.
en.right_and_principle: The right to equality in terms of s 9 of the Constitution was implicated. The Court had to determine whether the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
en.snippet: The court had to determine whether the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
en.title: Van Zyl N.O. v Road Accident Fund [2021] ZACC 44

en.facts_and_issues:
The Applicant, together with the three intervening parties, are provincial governments constitutionally tasked with implementing provincial legislation. However, there was relic law from the apartheid era, Proclamation R293 of 1962, issued in terms of the Administration Act of 1927. This Proclamation governed the setting-up of special African townships by the Minister of Bantu Administration and Development in areas under the African Native Trust. This Proclamation was one of the tools with which the apartheid state disposed Africans from landholding and created barriers to Africans owning any land. Instead, Africans could only hold rights to the lands through an insecure tenure system of Deeds of Grant and Certificates of Occupancy and letting for residential purposes. The township manager had the authority to cancel this tenure at any point. Special deeds registries were created to register the deeds of grant under the legislation.

When South Africa transitioned to democratic majority rule, the President, empowered by the Interim Constitution, passed Proclamation R9 of 1997 together with amendments to the Deeds Registry Act. The impact of these changes was to regularise and create a more uniform approach to registration of titles in immovable property. The President also delegated certain legislative competencies to the provincial legislations to ensure multi-level governance. 
Consequently, the North West passed the North West Act 7 which supposedly repealed the whole of Proclamation R293. Similar to other provincial governments, it considered the Proclamation to be unconstitutional. 

DVB Behuising (Pty) Ltd was aggrieved by the North West’s decision and applied to the High Court for an order upholding the constitutionality of the provision. It also argued that the repeal had a negative impact on its property business since its clients were left with an insecure form of land tenure. This order was granted at the High Court, and was the subject of the current appeal.
en.interpretation:
The action by the North West Government to revoke regulations 1 and 3 of Proclamation R293 was of no force or consequence. This was because the Constitution did not grant provincial governments the competence to make laws involving the registration of deeds of grant. The revocation was therefore not authorised by the Constitution.
Parliament should properly consider the issue of legislative competency of the provincial legislatures and governments with regard to land tenure and security of property rights. It is important for there to be a clear demarcation of what the provincial governments are allowed to legislate about within the sole limits of their jurisdiction and those issues that can only be legislated at a national level.
Parliament will also need to carefully consider the issue of competency by assignment through secondary legislation. In a society where the Constitution is the supreme law of the land, the authority for provinces to make legislation should be derived directly from the Constitution and not an executive Proclamation.
en.right_and_principle:
The main issue before the court was whether the Proclamation was in line with the values and provisions of the Interim Constitution. 

The court also had to consider whether provincial governments had the authority to legislate on deeds registration.
en.snippet: The court had to decide whether the Constitution allowed provincial governments the authority to legislate on registration of titles in immovable property.
en.title: Western Cape Provincial Government and Others; In Re: DVB Behuising (Pty) Limited v North West Provincial Government and Another (CCT 22/99) [2000] ZACC 2

en.facts_and_issues:
The Women’s Legal Centre (WLC) brought this action, arguing that the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act were inconsistent with the Constitution. These two laws failed to recognize Muslim marriages, and were therefore infringing on the fundamental rights of parties to Muslim marriages, especially Muslim women, and any children born of Muslim marriages. The WLC argued that the Acts specifically violated the rights to equality, dignity, and access to courts, and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount in every issue involving a child (sections 9, 10, 28 and 34 of the Constitution). The Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) agreed with the WLC and held that these Acts were constitutionally invalid, and the WLC then applied to the Constitutional Court to confirm the SCA’s order.
If the application was not successful, the applicants asked the court to confirm the order of the High Court, which required the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
en.interpretation:
The court determined three main issues:
(i) whether the SCA’s order of constitutional invalidity should be confirmed;
(ii) if the order was confirmed, whether it should have retrospective effect as ordered by the Supreme Court of Appeal (meaning that the Acts are regarded as always having been unconstitutional); and
(iii) whether to confirm the order of the High Court which required the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
The Constitutional Court conducted a thorough investigation and held that the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act were indeed inconsistent with the Constitution, even though the confirmation proceedings were not opposed.
The Court found that the laws unjustly discriminated against spouses in Muslim marriages and children born out of such marriages, based on their gender, religion and marital status. The court noted that there was no justification for the discrimination. Further, the Court held that it can reasonably be assumed that, where there is unfair discrimination, the right to human dignity is also violated, unless the opposite is proved.
The court held that the laws also unjustifiably violated the right of access to courts and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount. 
On the issue of retrospectivity, the court supported limited retrospectivity of the order, to ensure that other interested parties were adequately notified of the legal consequences of this order, going forward. 
Finally, the court found that the applicants had failed to establish an obligation on the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
Parliament was ordered by the court to remedy the defects identified in the Divorce Act and Marriage Act by either amending existing legislation, or making and passing new legislation by 28 June 2024, in order to ensure the recognition of Muslim marriages as valid marriages for all purposes in South Africa and to regulate the consequences arising from such recognition. It should also consider making amendments to other laws to ensure a balance of the right to freedom of religion, family life and protection of children with other constitutional rights.
en.right_and_principle: The rights implicated are the rights to equality, dignity, and access to courts, and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount in every issue involving a child (sections 9, 10, 28 and 34 of the Constitution).
en.snippet: This case concerned the constitutionality of the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act, which failed to recognise Muslim marriages.
en.title: Women's Legal Centre Trust v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others (CCT 24/21) [2022] ZACC 23

en.facts_and_issues: After a long history of litigation between the parties, the Applicant (Mr Zuma) had disobeyed an order of the Constitutional Court to appear before a commission of enquiry on State Capture. As a result, contempt of court proceedings were launched, but Mr Zuma refused to participate, and the Court granted a judgment and order for his arrest for contempt of court. This judgment sentenced the Applicant to 15 months of imprisonment. It is this judgment and order that the Applicant is seeking to have rescinded.
en.interpretation: The court stated that the matter could be heard directly at the Constitutional Court without having first being head in a lower court. The judgment and order sentencing the Applicant for contempt of court continues to stand.
en.right_and_principle:
The main legal question before the Court was whether the Applicant’s application met the requirements for rescission in rule 42 (1(a) of the Uniform Rules of Court. This rule requires that the following conditions be met:
(a) that the party was unaware of the proceedings before the court, or
(b) that the party was precluded from participating in the proceedings, and
(c) that the judgment was erroneously sought or granted by the court.
The Court also had to consider whether the requirements for rescission according to the common law were met.
en.snippet: This case was about Mr Jacob Zuma disobeying an order of the Constitutional Court to appear before a commission of enquiry on State Capture, and the resulting contempt of court proceedings.
en.title: Zuma v Secretary of Judicial Commission of Inquiry into Allegations of State Capture, Corruption and Fraud in Public Sector Including Organs of State and Others (CCT 52 of 2021) [2021] ZACC 28

xh.facts_and_issues:
Abamangali yayingabazali babantwana ababengena kwisikolo sommangalelwa nababesayine izivumelwano zabantwana babo ababini nommangalelwa. Kwezi zivumelwano kwakukho isolotya elalivumela ummangalelwa ukuba asichithe isivumelwano nanini na, ngaso nasiphi isizathu, ukuba nje kwakunikelwe isaziso esibhaliweyo sethemu epheleleyo. 

Emva kothotho lweziganeko apho abamangali baye baziphatha ngendlela engafanelekanga phambi kwabantwana abancinci, ummangalelwa wachitha izivumelwano zabamangali ngesaziso esibhaliweyo sethemu epheleleyo. Emva koko abamangali baya kwiNkundla Ephakamileyo ukuze bafumane umyalelo wexeshana wenkundla ovumela abantwana ukuba baqhubeke besePridwin Preparatory School de kwenziwe isigqibo kwisicelo esiyintloko sokuba isigqibo senqununu sokuchitha isivumelwano sigqalwe njengesingasebenziyo size sibekelwe bucala.
xh.interpretation:
Malunga nengxaki yokuqala, iNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yagqiba ekubeni iimbopheleleko ezibekwa ngumgaqo-siseko ePridwin aziveli kwisivumelwano, kodwa kunoko, zivela ngokungqalileyo kuMgaqo-siseko nasekusetyenzisweni kwecandelo 8(2). Le Nkundla yathi icandelo 8(2) liyenza icace gca into yokuba amalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo anjengelungelo lemfundo esisiseko, anako ukusetyenziswa nakwizikolo ezingezizo ezikarhulumente, kuxhomekeka kuhlobo lwelungelo elo. Ngenxa yoko, icandelo 8(2) libeka iimbopheleleko zomgaqo-siseko kwanakwimibutho yabucala, enjengePridwin. Ngokwenza igunya elisetyenziswa yimibutho yabucala (engeyiyo ekaRhulumente) lilawulwe ngumgaqo-siseko, icandelo 8(2) ligqala ukubaluleka kwentsebenziswano yabucala nento yokuba inganako ukuwanyhasha amalungelo abantu ize iqhubele phambili ukungalingani nokuhleleleka.

Emva koko le Nkundla yagqiba ekubeni izikolo ezizimeleyo zinikela ‘ngemfundo esisiseko’, ngokwecandelo 29 loMgaqo-siseko, kubafundi kuba uhlobo lwesikolo alubalulekanga xa kugqitywa enoba into elinikela ngayo “yimfundo esisiseko”. Ngoko, icandelo 29(1)(a) lilungelo eligubungela yonke into lemfundo esisiseko elisebenza kubo bonke abantu nelifunyanwa ngabantwana abakwizikolo zikarhulumente nabakwezizimeleyo ngokulinganayo.

Ngokuphathelele ingxaki yesibini, le Nkundla yathi isigqibo sokuyekisa imfundo yomfundi besiya kuba siyangqubana nomgaqo-siseko ibe ngenxa yoko asisebenzi ukuba isikolo asinikanga umfundi okanye abazali/abagcini okanye abameli bakhe ithuba lokuzithethelela ngaphambi kokuba kwenziwe isigqibo sisikolo sokuchitha isivumelwano nokukhupha umntwana esikolweni. Le Nkundla yathi le nto isekelwe kwisibakala sokuba icandelo 29 loMgaqo-siseko libeka imbopheleleko kuzo zonke izikolo, kokubini izikolo zabucala nezikarhulumente, yokunganqandi okanye yokuphazamisani nelungelo lemfundo esisiseko ngaphandle kokunikela ngethuba lokuba abamangali bazithethelele esikolweni ngaphambi kokuba kwenziwe isigqibo sokukhupha abo bantwana esikolweni. Le Nkundla ngoko yathi ilungelo lecandelo 29 lalinqandiwe ekubeni kwakungalandelwanga inkqubo efanelekileyo ngaphambi kokuba kuchithwe eso sivumelwano. Ngenxa yoko, kwagqitywa ekubeni isikolo sasinembopheleleko yokuqwalasela amalungelo abantwana babamangali okuba kuviwe izimvo zabo ngalo mba neyokubanika eli thuba. Ngoko, ubukho nokunyanzeliswa kwesolotya lesivumelwano kwafunyaniswa kungqubana nomgaqo-siseko kwaye kungasebenzi.
xh.right_and_principle: INkundla Yomgaqo-siseko kwakufuneka yenze isigqibo. Okokuqala, ngaba izikolo ezizimeleyo zazinemisebenzi neembopheleleko zomgaqo-siseko ezazisikela umda ukusebenzisa kwazo amalungelo okwenza izivumelwano. Okwesibini, ngaba isolotya elikwisivumelwano lalisebenza na ngokomgaqo-siseko ekubeni lalinganiki umntu ekwenziwe naye isivumelwano ithuba lokuveza elakhe icala ngaphambi kokuba isivumelwano sichithwe.
xh.snippet: Ingxaki kweli tyala yayikukuba isolotya elalikwisivumelwano esiphakathi kwabazali nesikolo lalisebenza na ngokoMgaqo-siseko ekubeni lalinganiki omnye oyinxalenye yesi sivumelwano ithuba lokuveza elakhe icala ngaphambi kokuba isivumelwano sichithwe. Okwesibini, ngaba izikolo ezizimeleyo zazinemisebenzi neembopheleleko zomgaqo-siseko ezazisikela umda ukusebenzisa kwazo amalungelo okwenza izivumelwano.

xh.facts_and_issues: Abamangali bafaka isicelo semvume yokubhenela ngokungqalileyo kwiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko nxamnye nomyalelo weNkundla Ephakamileyo owawuchitha ibango lokuba uMthetho Wamayeza Namachiza Anxulumeneyo (Medicines and Related Substances Act) 101 Wowe-1995 (uMthetho) uyangqubana nomgaqo-siseko malunga nenkqubo entsha yokukhupha iilayisensi. Abamangali baphikisa (i) icandelo 22C(1)(a) lalo Mthetho xa kufikwa kumba wokugunyazisa kwalo uMalathisi Jikelele weSebe Lezempilo (uMalathisi Jikelele) ukuba anikele ngeelayisensi zokukhupha amayeza kubaboneleli ngeenkonzo zempilo ngokuxhomekeke kwimiqathango ethile; kunye (ii) nemiyalelo enikela ngeenkcukacha ezingakumbi zenkqubo yokukhupha iilayisensi phantsi kwalo Mthetho. Ngokutsho kwalo Mthetho nemiyalelo ehlaziyiweyo, ababoneleli ngeenkonzo zempilo, abanjengabasebenzi bezempilo noogqirha bamazinyo, babengavunyelwanga ukuba bakhuphe okanye bathengise amayeza ngaphandle kokuba babenikwe ilayisensi nguMalathisi Jikelele. Kwakuphikiswa (i) igunya loMalathisi Jikelele lokubeka imiqathango yokukhutshwa kweelayisensi, (ii) ukudityaniswa kweelayisensi neendawo abasebenzela kuzo ababoneleli ngeenkonzo zempilo kunye (iii) neenkalo ekwakufuneka uMalathisi Jikelele aziqwalasele xa egqiba ngezicelo zelayisensi.
xh.interpretation:
Le Nkundla yagqiba ngomkhamo wecandelo 22 yaza yagxininisa ukuba elo lungelo ligqithela ngaphaya kokuba lilungelo nje lokufumana indlela yokuziphilisa, kodwa inkululeko yokukhetha umsebenzi norhwebo liyinkalo ebaluleke kakhulu yoluntu olusekelwe kwisidima somntu. Nakuphi na ukusikelwa umda kwelungelo lokukhetha umsebenzi kwakungayi kuthathwa njengento engenamsebenzi. Kwathiwa kwakukho iinkalo ezimbini kwicandelo 22: (i) ilungelo lokukhetha umsebenzi kunye (ii) nelungelo lokwenza loo msebenzi umntu ayikhethileyo. Kwicandelo 22, kwathiwa lo myalelo ulawula ukwenziwa komsebenzi wezonyango, kodwa awunafuthe libi kwilungelo lokukhetha umsebenzi.

Le Nkundla yathi ilungelo lenkululeko yokuhamba-hamba ngokwecandelo 21 loMgaqo-siseko linxibelelene nelungelo lokwenza umsebenzi ngokwecandelo 22 loMgaqo-siseko. Ilungelo lokwenza umsebenzi liquka ilungelo lokugqiba ngendawo omawuwenze kuyo loo msebenzi. Le Nkundla yaphinda yacacisa isithi imfuneko yelayisensi ayilihluthi ilungelo lokukhetha indawo omawuwenzele kuyo umsebenzi wezamayeza; ifuna nje ukuba imisebenzi edibene nokukhutshwa kwamayeza yenziwe kwiindawo zokusebenzela ezinelayisensi. Le Nkundla yagqiba kwelokuba inkqubo yokukhupha iilayisensi edibanisa iilayisensi naloo ndawo kusetyenzelwa kuyo ayilinyhashi ilungelo lomsebenzi wezamayeza lenkululeko yokuhamba-hamba elibekwe kwicandelo 21 loMgaqo-siseko.
xh.right_and_principle:
Abamangali baphakamisa amabango ahlukeneyo okungqubana nomgaqo-siseko kwecandelo 22C (1)(a) loMthetho nemiyalelo, phakathi kwezinye izinto besithi umyalelo 18 (owawusithi ilayisensi imele ifune ukuba ingcali isebenzele kwindawo ethile egunyazisiweyo) wawungqubana necandelo 22 loMgaqo-siseko nelungelo elikumgaqo-siseko lenkululeko yokuhamba-hamba eligxininiswe kwicandelo 21 loMgaqo-siseko.

Abamangali bathi ukudityaniswa kweelayisensi nendawo ekusetyenzelwa kuyo kwakungqubana necandelo 22 loMgaqo-siseko, eliphathelele inkululeko yokurhweba, yokusebenza neyomsebenzi. Lo mqathango wawunganeli nje ukulawula umsebenzi kodwa wawusikela umda ukhetho lomsebenzi. Abamangali baphinda bathi imfuneko yokuba kufakwe isicelo xa umsebenzi wezonyango efudukela kwenye indawo aza kusebenzela kuyo yayingqubana nelungelo lenkululeko yokuhamba-hamba.

xh.facts_and_issues:
IYunivesithi YaseFreyistata yayenza yasemthethweni inkqubo-mgaqo yokuba neelwimi ezimbini (iAfrikansi nesiNgesi) ngowama-2003 emva kokuyisebenzisa ngokuthe ngcembe ukususela ngowe-1993. Umphumo owabakho (nangona ungeyonjongo) wale nkqubo-mgaqo, phakathi kwezinye izinto, waba kukuba namagumbi okufundisa ahlukeneyo abafundi abamhlophe nawabantsundu kwaza kwakho ukujongana ngezikhondo zamehlo ngokwebala.

Emva kokwenza ikomishini ngale meko ngaphakathi kweYunivesithi phantsi kwenkqubo-mgaqo yowama-2003, iBhunga Leyunivesithi, emva kokuba lithethe nababandakanyekayo, lamkela inkqubo-mgaqo entsha ngowama-2016 (eyayiza kusetyenziswa ngokuthe ngcembe kwisithuba seminyaka emihlanu) eyayisenza isiNgesi sibe lulwimi oluyintloko lokufundisa nokufunda, ize iAfrikansi iqhubeke isetyenziswa kwinkqubo eyandisiweyo yokunceda abafundi nakwiikhosi ezithile.

Ngowama-2016, iYunivesithi YaseFreyistata yayitshintsha inkqubo-mgaqo yayo yowama-2003 yokusebenzisa iilwimi ezimbini (iAfrikansi nesiNgesi) – eyayibe nemiphumo eyayingacetywanga yokuba, phakathi kwezinye izinto, kubekho amagumbi ahlukeneyo okufundisa abafundi abamhlophe nabafundi abantsundu kwaza kwabikwa ukuba kukho ukujongana ngezikhondo zamehlo ngokwebala – endaweni yayo yafaka inkqubo-mgaqo eyayiza kusetyenziswa ngokuthe ngcembe kwisithuba seminyaka emihlanu eyayisenza isiNgesi sibe lulwimi oluyintloko lokufundisa nokufunda, ize iAfrikansi iqhubeke isetyenziswa kwinkqubo eyandisiweyo yokunceda abafundi nakwiikhosi ezithile. Le nkqubo-mgaqo intsha yakhatywa ngabamangali abema ngelithi kwakungenziwanga uphando olufanelekileyo, nokuba isininzi sabafundi abamhlophe nabanye abafundi abantsundu abathetha iAfrikansi bakhetha ukufundiswa ngeAfrikansi. Abamangali babengaboni nto ithethelela ukutshintshwa kwenkqubo-mgaqo yolwimi.
xh.interpretation:
INkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yacacisa yathi bonke abemi boMzantsi Afrika banelungelo elikumgaqo-siseko lokufundiswa ngolwimi olusemthethweni abalukhethayo kumaziko ethu emfundo kawonke-wonke. Kodwa uMgaqo-siseko uchaza izinto elixhomekeke kuzo eli lungelo. Umqathango ogubungela yonke into kukuba ukuthenjiswa kwemfundo ngolwimi umntu alukhethayo kumele kube yinto ekukwazeka ngokusengqiqweni ukuyenza. Okuthethwa nokubandakanywa kukukwazeka ngokusengqiqweni yinto iNkundla ekwakufuneka igqibe ngayo kweli tyala. 

Le Nkundla yathi icandelo 29(2)</b> lithi kufuneka “(a) kulinganwe; (b) ikwazeke; kwaye (c) kufuneka kulungiswe imiphumo yemithetho noqheliselo lwexesha elidluleyo ezazicalula abantu ngokwebala,”</b> zibe phambili xa kujongwa ukuba kungakwazeka na ukunikela ngemfundo ngolwimi olusemthethweni olukhethwa ngumntu. Ezi nkalo zidibene nokulingana, ukusabela msinya nokungacaluli ngokwebala.

Ezi nkalo zimele ziqwalaselwe zithelekiswa nemfuneko ekwicandelo 29(2) yokuba ilungelo lokufunda ngolwimi olukhethayo limele “likwazeke ngokusengqiqweni” kwelo ziko lemfundo. Le Nkundla yathi ukuba sengqiqweni xa kuthethwa ngecandelo 29(2) kufuna ukuba ukulingana, ukukwazeka nemfuneko ebaluleke kakhulu yokuphelisa umonakalo obangelwe kukucalulwa kwabantu ngokwebala, zibe ziinkalo eziqukwayo kwinkqubo yokwenza isigqibo esiphathelele ekufumanekeni kwemfundo ngolwimi olukhethwa ngumntu. Kungenxa yokuba zizezinye zeenkalo ezigqibayo ezimele ziqwalaselwe kwanaxa “umfundi sele ezuza ekufundisweni ngolwimi olusemthethweni alukhethayo”. Ngenxa yoko ukungafumaneki ngokulinganayo kunye nokwendiselwa okungenziwanga nganjongo okanye ukuphenjelelwa kokungavani kwabantu bemibala eyahlukeneyo “kwakusisizathu esifanelekileyo” sokulithatha okanye sokunciphisa ukufumaneka kwelungelo lokufundiswa komntu ngolwimi lwakhe lweenkobe. Xa ijongwa le ngcamango, amaziko afundisa ngeelwimi ezimbini angakwazi ukubakho ngaphandle kokuphembelela okanye ukuqhubela phambili ukunikwa kwabanye abantu iinzuzo ezibhetele kunabanye okanye ukucalulwa ngokwebala nemiphumo yako eyenzakalisayo.  Xa kunjalo, ilungelo lokufundiswa ngolwimi olukhethayo lingafikeleleka lize lisetyenziswe.

Le Nkundla yathi ayithetheleleki into yokuba abantu batshele kwinkqubo-mgaqo yolwimi engqineke isisichasi sokuphunyezwa kobulungisa, engakwazekiyo, nengabaquki abanye abantu ibe liyafuneka inyathelo elilungisayo eligungqisa ucalulo ngokwebala kunye nemikhutyana yalo esihlalweni salo. Ilungelo lemfundo libeka imbopheleleko kurhulumente yokuthatha “amanyathelo asengqiqweni” okwenza imfundo “iqhubeke ifumaneka kwaye ifikeleleka”, nokungavumeleki kocalucalulo ngokwebala, enoba lwenziwa ngenjongo okanye akunjalo, kuwo onke amaziko emfundo. Yile mbono ke emele icacise oko kuthethwa kukukwazeka ngokusengqiqweni.

Le Nkundla yacacisa ukuba kungakwazeka kona ukugcina iAfrikansi ilulwimi oluphambili lokufundisa; kodwa – ekubeni unxibelelwano olukhoyo phakathi kweeklasi ezahlula abafundi ngokwebala nokujongana ngezikhondo zamehlo ngokwebala lungakhange luphikwe lilo naliphi iqela – ‘akukwazeki ngokusengqiqweni’ ukugcina inkqubo-mgaqo yeelwimi ezimbini yowama-2003 ukuba loo nkqubo-mgaqo ibeka emngciphekweni ubudlelwane babantu bamabala ahlukeneyo kwaye kuqhubela phambili ukucalulwa kwabantu ngokwebala. Le Nkundla yathi ukubangela ukuba kujongwane ngezikhondo zamehlo ngokwebala ‘kwakusisizathu esivakalayo’ sokusikela umda ukufikeleleka kwelungelo lokufundiswa komntu ngolwimi lwakhe lweenkobe – kule meko eli lungelo lalisele lifunyanwa ngabafundi abathetha iAfrikansi bale Yunivesithi ibe lalisikelwa umda ngokutshintshela kwinkqubo eyenza isiNgesi sibe lulwimi oluyintloko.

Ngoko, le Nkundla yafumanisa ukuba ukwamkelwa kwenkqubo-mgaqo yowama-2016 kwakusemthethweni yaye kusebenza.

xh.facts_and_issues:
The Applicant (AK) was attacked, robbed, abducted and held captive, where she was repeatedly raped. The South African Police Services (SAPS) conducted four different searches for AK, but failed to locate and rescue her. AK was further raped and traumatized until she eventually escaped on the day after her abduction. The SAPS failed to positively connect anyone to the assault, abduction and rape of AK in the investigations that followed.
AK then instituted an action in the Gqeberha High Court. She sought to hold the Minister of Police liable, saying that the SAPS had negligently failed to conduct an effective search and investigation. The High Court ruled that the Minister was liable. The court said that the conduct of the SAPS was negligent because the searches fell below the Constitutional standard and the subsequent investigation was severely flawed. The Court also held that the negligent conduct of the SAPS was wrongful, and that not holding the SAPS liable would inhibit fundamental constitutional rights, especially in the context of the country’s scourge of gender-based violence. 
The Minister appealed to the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA), which overturned the High Court’s ruling, stating that AK had not established the requirements for delictual liability, i.e. negligence, causation and wrongfulness. The SCA held that the conduct of the SAPS during the search and investigation was not negligent and that the SAPS had used all available resources to search for AK and investigate her matter. The SCA also held that there was no causal link between the SAPS’s conduct and the damages suffered by AK.
The SCA further held that imposing liability on the SAPS in the circumstances would inhibit the SAPS in conducting future searches and investigations, and that imposing liability would open the floodgates of civil litigation. 
AK then approached the Constitutional Court and argued that the SCA was incorrect in its findings. The Minister acknowledged that the SAPS has a constitutional and statutory duty to protect the public, and specifically to prevent and investigate violence against women, but he contended that, in this case, there was no proof of negligence, causation and wrongfulness, so the SAPS could not be held liable.
xh.interpretation:
AK succeeded in her appeal to the Constitutional Court. The Court held that the failure of the SAPS to conduct a reasonably effective search to find AK when she had been abducted, assaulted, and raped and, thereafter, to conduct a reasonably effective investigation to hold her perpetrators accountable, was wrongful under the law of delict and in light of the constitutional obligation on the state to suppress gender-based violence. The Constitutional Court also held that the SCA was incorrect in its findings on the law and the facts on negligence, causation, and wrongfulness, and had incorrectly upheld the appeal by the Minister against the Gqeberha High Court judgment. The order of the SCA was therefore set aside.
Parliament must consider the current scourge of gender-based violence and the possible ways to eradicate it.
Parliament must also consider the role of the SAPS and the resources available to the SAPS in eradicating gender-based violence and performing their duties overall.

xh.snippet: This case asked whether a failure by the police to conduct a reasonably effective investigation into a case of rape and kidnapping of a woman is wrongful under the law of delict, and in light of the constitutional obligation on the State to suppress gender-based violence.
