xh.facts_and_issues:
Eli tyala lamanyelwa yiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko ngenxa yemvume yokubhena eyayikhutshwe yiNkundla Yezibheno Yezabasebenzi. Abamangali bafaka isicelo sokuba kubuyiselwe emsebenzini amalungu abo ali-103 awayedendwe ngummangalelwa. Amalungu abamangali ayedendwe ngemva kwesivumelwano sokudenda esasenziwe ngabamangalelwa neminye imibutho yabasebenzi emibini emgodini, iNational Union of Mineworkers (NUM) kunye neUnited Association of South Africa (UASA). Udendo lwenzeka emva kokuba abamangalelwa beye bagqala iNUM njengombutho wabasebenzi omela isininzi sabasebenzi kule nkampani. Abamangali kunye neUASA baba yimibutho yabasebenzi emela igcuntswana labasebenzi. Umphumo waba kukuba imibutho yabasebenzi emela igcuntswana labasebenzi yayiza kunikwa amalungelo ombutho nawokuqhuba uthethwano ngummangalelwa. Kodwa ke, abamangali, ngokwahlukileyo kwiUASA, abazange bagqalwe kuthethwano. Isivumelwano sokudenda senziwa ngaphandle kwabamangali nangona sasiwachaphazela namalungu abo kwaye eso sivumelwano senziwe ngokuhambisana necandelo 23(1)(d) loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi (Labour Relations Act).

Abamangali baya kwiNkundla Yezabasebenzi baza baphikisa ukuhambisana nomgaqo-siseko kwecandelo 23 (1)(d) loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi kunye nokugxothwa kwamalungu abo. Abamangali bema ngelithi isivumelwano esenziweyo seqela sasingqubana nomgaqo-siseko, kuba sasivumela ukuba umbutho wabasebenzi omela isininzi sabasebenzi wenze isivumelwano seqela ngenkqubo yokudenda ngaphandle kwemibutho yabasebenzi eyayimela igcuntswana labasebenzi emsebenzini. Abamangali babefuna icandelo 189(1)(a)- (c) kunye no-23(1)(d) loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi agqalwe njengangqubanayo nomgaqo-siseko nangasebenziyo kodwa iNkundla Yezabasebenzi yafumanisa ukuba awanyhashwanga amalungelo abekwe kumgaqo-siseko yaza yawachitha namanye amabango aweyenziwe ngabamangali. Xa babebhenela kwiNkundla Yezibheno Yezabasebenzi, abamangali bema ngelithi icandelo 189(1)(a)- (c) no-23(1)(d) loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi lalimele litolikwe ngendlela yokuba linyanzele umqeshi ukuba athethe nemibutho yabasebenzi emela igcuntswana labasebenzi kwanokuba sele enze isivumelwano seqela nombutho wabasebenzi omela isininzi sabasebenzi. Le Nkundla yasichitha isibheno yaza yabambelela kwinto yokuba umgaqo wesininzi unendima ebalulekileyo kuMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi ukuze kuqinisekwe ukuba uthethwano lwamaqela luqhutywa ngocwangco. Emva koko kwalandela isicelo semvume yokubhenela kwiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko.
xh.interpretation:
Isigwebo sesininzi seejaji esabhalwa nguFroneman J, sajolisa kumbuzo othi ngaba icandelo 23(1) loMgaqo-siseko lalinyhashiwe na waza wathi gqaba-gqaba ngokunyhashwa okwakunokwenzeka kwecandelo 18 loMgaqo-siseko, ilungelo lenkululeko yonxulumano. Oku kungenxa yokuba kukunyhashwa kwecandelo 23 kuphela okwakuphakanyiswe kumaxwebhu afakwe ngummangali. Malunga nombuzo othi ngaba icandelo 23(1) loMgaqo-siseko lalisikelwe umda na, isininzi seejaji sathi uMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi wenza lisebenze ilungelo lokuba kulandelwe iinkqubo ezizizo kwimicimbi yabasebenzi kwaye iiNkundla bezisoloko zitolika icandelo 189 loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi njengengayiquki nayiphi imfuneko yokuba kuthethwane nomntu ngamnye kwaye kuqhutywe olunye uthethwano ecaleni xa kukho isivumelwano seqela. Ilungelo lokuthethana nomntu ngamnye ebudeni benkqubo yodendo kwezi meko lafunyaniswa lingaxhaswa nguMgaqo-siseko nanguMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi. Isininzi seejaji sathi ibango lenkululeko yonxulumano elalenziwe ngummangali laliwe phantsi kuba laliza kufuna iNkundla ithi ilungelo lokunxulumana ngokukhululekileyo lithetha ukuba yonke imibutho yabasebenzi imele iphathwe ngokulinganayo, ifumane zonke iimfanelo ezibekwa yimimiselo, kungakhathaliseki ukuba ingakanani ngobukhulu. Saphinda sathi umsebenzi unelungelo lokujoyina umbutho wabasebenzi awuthandayo, kodwa loo nto ayiquki ilungelo lokuba loo mbutho wabasebenzi awuthandayo umele unikwe igunya ngazo zonke iindlela afuna ngazo.

Kodwa isigwebo esiveza iimbono ezahlukileyo sikaJafta J, sasiphikisa isigwebo sesininzi seejaji sokuba ilungelo lenkululeko yokunxulumana lalingamelwanga ngendlela efanelekileyo waze wema ngelithi xa kuthethwa ngezobudlelwane nabasebenzi eli lungelo livumela abasebenzi ukuba bajoyine umbutho wabasebenzi abawukhethayo. Eli lungelo liqiniswa lilungelo lokuyila okanye lokujoyina umbutho wabasebenzi okhethwe ngumntu eliqinisekiswe licandelo 23(2)(a) loMgaqo-siseko . UJafta J waphinda wathi asikho isizathu esivakalayo sokugqala umgaqo wesininzi njengobaluleke ngaphezu kwamalungelo akuMgaqo-siseko. Isigwebo esiveza iimbono ezahlukileyo saqukumbela ngelithi ukusikelwa umda kwelungelo lommangali lenkululeko yonxulumano akunasizathu kwaye akuthetheleleki kuba azikho ezinye izizathu, ngaphandle komgaqo wesininzi, eziye zavezwa ukuze kuthethelelwe oko kusikelwa umda kwalo."
xh.right_and_principle:
Ummangali wayesemi ngelithi icandelo 189(1) loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi laliwanyhasha amalungelo akumgaqo-siseko ombutho wabasebenzi omela igcuntswana labasebenzi nawabasebenzi abangekho kumbutho wabasebenzi lokuba kulandelwe iinkqubo ezizizo emsebenzini akwicandelo 23(1) loMgaqo-siseko kuba lalibakhuphela ngaphandle aba basebenzi ebudeni benkqubo yokudenda xa isivumelwano seqela senziwe nombutho wabasebenzi omela isininzi sabasebenzi. Abamangali baveza namanye amalungelo ahlukeneyo akumgaqo-siseko kwisicelo sawo semvume yokubhena aquka ukunyhashwa kwelungelo lenkululeko yonxulumano ngokwecandelo 18 loMgaqo-siseko. 

Le Nkundla kwakufuneka igqibe enoba akho nawaphi na amalungelo akumgaqo-siseko asikelwa umda xa umqeshi ethetha nombutho wabasebenzi omela isininzi sabasebenzi ngaphandle kwemibutho yabasebenzi emela igcuntswana labasebenzi.

xh.facts_and_issues: Abamangali bafaka isicelo kwiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko becela imvume yokubhena nxamnye nesigwebo nomyalelo weNkundla Yesibheno Yezabasebenzi owawusithi isivumelwano seqela sibophelela kwanabasebenzi ababengengomalungu emibutho yabasebenzi eyayenze eso sivumelwano ukuba amalungu alo mibutho yabasebenzi ayesisininzi sabasebenzi emsebenzini.
xh.interpretation:
Isivumelwano seqela sandiswa ngokwecandelo 23(1)(d) loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi (Labour Relations Act [LRA]). Lalisithi isivumelwano seqela siyababophelela kwanabasebenzi abangengomalungu emibutho yabasebenzi eyenze esi sivumelwano ukuba nje amalungu aloo mibutho yabasebenzi asisininzi sabasebenzi emsebenzini. Le Nkundla yathi nakuphi na ukunyhashwa kwelungelo lokugwayimba kwakunesizathu kwaye kuthetheleleka ngokusekelwe kumgaqo wesininzi. Umgaqo wesininzi lukhetho lwenkqubo-mgaqo oluvumela ukuba kwenziwe ukuthanda kwesininzi kunokuba kwenziwe okwegcuntswana. Umgaqo wesininzi, kule meko, wawunceda ukuze uthethwano lweqela lube nocwangco. Into yokuba umgaqo wesininzi uyasebenza ekuphuculeni uthethwano lweqela yamkelwa nakwamanye amazwe. Le Nkundla yafumanisa ukuba ukwenziwa kwesivumelwano phantsi kwecandelo 23(1)(d) yayikukusetyenziswa kwegunya likawonke-wonke ibe kwakuxhomekeka ekuhlolweni ngomgaqo wokuba sisemthethweni na. Lo mgaqo wawufuna ukuba ngalo lonke ixesha kusetyenziswa igunya likawonke-wonke kuquka amanyathelo angengawo awolawulo kulandelwe eyona milinganiselo iphantsi yokuba semthethweni. Ngenxa yezi  zizathu, le Nkundla yagqiba ekubeni isivumelwano sasiwaquka amalungu abamangali nokuba imimiselo edibene nale nto yayihambisana nomgaqo-siseko.

 

Le nkundla, kwisigqibo esasixhaswa zizo zonke iijaji, yathi icandelo 23(1)(d) leLRA lalingalinyhashi ilungelo lenkululeko yonxulumano kuba iLRA inyanzelisa inkqubo yesininzi enika imibutho yabasebenzi emela igcuntswana inkululeko yonxulumano. Imibutho yabasebenzi emela igcuntswana yayinamalungelo okugaya malungelo lawo ababenawo abamangali kunye namalungelo ombutho nawokutsala imali kwimivuzo yamalungu. Le Nkundla yaphinda yathi abamangali babenamalungelo okuthethana nabaqeshi nangona babephulukene nelungelo lokugwayimba ngoxa esi sivumelwano sisebenza. Le Nkundla yathi akukho namnye kwimibutho yabasebenzi eyayingasayinanga okanye kubasebenzi owayephulukene neemfanelo zakhe zombutho nezokuqhuba uthethwano njengeqela. Le Nkundala yathi ngokunikela ngala malungelo, loo nto ithetha ukuba iLRA, nangona yayisekelwe kumgaqo wesininzi, yayingesosixhobo sengcinezelo kwaye yayingayivali umlomo imibutho emela igcuntswana. Yathi lo Mthetho yayiyinika isithuba esaneleyo imibutho emela igcuntswana labasebenzi sokuba iqokelele kwaye igaye inkxaso emsebenzini ukuze ikwazi ukumelana nokugaganyelwa yimibutho yabasebenzi emikhulu. Le Nkundla yathi icandelo 23(1)(d) lalikukhuthaza kwaye likuphumeza ukuqhutywa kothethwano njengeqela, nto leyo eyinjongo efanelekileyo yalo mthetho.

xh.facts_and_issues: Mr A, a foreign national, had entered and stayed in South Africa illegally. He was arrested and detained, and remained in detention for various periods. Eventually he brought an application to the High Court seeking an order preventing his deportation until he was given the opportunity to make an application for asylum. Mr A. said that he was at risk of getting the death penalty if he was deported to his home country. The court of first instance found that Mr A. did not qualify for the protection provided by the Refugees Act, because he had delayed in applying for asylum after entering the country. Mr A. then brought an urgent application to the Constitutional Court to assert his rights in terms of the Refugees Act and prevent his impending deportation.
xh.interpretation:
The court had to determine whether the amendments to the Refugees Act were applicable to Mr A. The amendments had resulted in more stringent regulations, such as requiring an asylum seeker to obtain an asylum transit visa before entering the country. The failure to show good cause for not obtaining such a visa could then result in an asylum seeker not qualifying for refugee status in South Africa. As a result of these amendments, the court needed to provide clarity on the applicability of the principle of non-refoulement as laid down in the Ruta case.   In the Ruta matter, this Court described non-refoulement as “the concept that one fleeing persecutions or threats to ‘his or her life, physical safety or freedom’ should not be made to return to the country inflicting it”.

The court also considered whether an illegal foreigner, who claimed to be a refugee and expressed an intention to apply for asylum, should be permitted to apply in terms of the Refugees Act, and whether a delay between an illegal foreigner’s arrival in the country and his expression of an intention to apply for asylum prevented him from applying for refugee status. The court held that, while a delay in applying is relevant in determining whether an application is authentic, such a delay could not function as an absolute disqualification from initiating the asylum application process, and that the amendments to the Refugees Act did not change section 2, which provides for the principle of non-refoulement.

Lastly, the court also had to determine whether Mr A.’s continued detention was lawful or justified in terms of section 36 of the Constitution. The court held that certain periods of Mr A.’s detention were unlawful, such as when he had paid the required fine, and the periods when his detention was not authorized by a court order.

The court ordered the respondents to take all reasonable steps, within 14 days from the date of the order, to give effect to Mr A.’s intention to apply for asylum in terms of section 21(1B) of the Refugees Amendment Act.
xh.right_and_principle: Section 36 provides criteria for circumstances when rights enshrined in the Bill of Rights may be limited. Rights contained in the Bill of Rights are not absolute and may be limited. Such limitation must conform to the criteria set out in section 36 of the Constitution in order to be justifiable.
xh.snippet: This case was about whether an illegal foreigner who takes a long time to apply for asylum is entitled to the protection of the Refugees Act and, in particular, the principle of non-refoulement. It also concerned whether the detention of such a foreigner was justified in terms of section 36 of the Constitution.

xh.facts_and_issues: Kwicandelo lokuloba ngeminatha phakathi elwandle, ummangali, iBato Star Fishing (Pty) Ltd, wamangalela ukuba avunyelwe ukuba alobe iitoni ezingama-12 000 zeentlanzi ezibanjisiweyo ngexesha lokuloba lowama-2002 ukuya kowama-2005. Waye wanikwa isisikelo seetoni ezingama-873 kuphela ngummangalelwa, uMalathisi Oyintloko (weSebe Lemicimbi Yokusingqongileyo Nokhenketho). Inganelisekanga, iBato Star Fishing yasiphikisa isigqibo soMmangalelwa sokuyabela isisikelo seetoni ezingama-873.
xh.interpretation:
Umbuzo wawusithi ngaba isigqibo soMalathisi Oyintloko weSebe Lemicimbi Yokusingqongileyo Nokhenketho sokunika iBato Star isisikelo seetoni ezingama-873 zeentlanzi ngowama-2002 ukuya kowama-2005, kunokuba ayinike iitoni ezingakumbi, sasisisenzo solawulo esasingasekelwanga kwizizathu ezivakalayo okanye esasingalandelanga inkqubo enobulungisa (ibe ngenxa yoko singasebenzi) phantsi kwePAJA necandelo 33 loMgaqo-siseko.

INkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yavuma ukuba kwakungayi kuba yinto efanelekileyo ukungenelela ekwenziweni kwezigqibo ngamanye amaphiko karhulumente ngaphandle kokuba kukho izizathu, ekubeni iinkundla zingeyondawo iyiyo okanye ngokuqhelekileyo zingenagunya lokwenza izigqibo zokuwisa imithetho okanye zesigqeba. Ekugqibeleni, emva kokuhlalutya izinto ezibandakanyekayo, le Nkundla yagqiba ekubeni ayikwazi kungenelela ize ichithe isigqibo soMalathisi Oyintloko kuba yayingesosigqibo singasekelwanga kwizizathu ezivakalayo. Ngokufanayo, le Nkundla yafumanisa ukuba uMalathisi Oyintloko wayeye wacingisisa kakuhle ngesicelo seBato Star sesisikelo sokuloba iitoni ezingama-12 000 zeentlanzi ngokuthi akale zonke izicelo ethelekisa ngasinye nemiqathango ejongwayo ukuze zifaneleke. Okokugqibela, le Nkundla yafumanisa ukuba esi sigqibo sasenziwe emva kokulandela inkqubo enobulungisa kuba sasisekelwe kwinkqubo-mgaqo esebenzayo eyayenziwe yafumaneka kuwonke-wonke.

Le Nkundla yagxininisa ukuba iPAJA (phantsi kwecandelo 33 loMgaqo-siseko) yayiye ubukhulu becala yathatha indawo yomthetho oqhelekileyo njengomthombo womthetho wolawulo, nokuba ngenxa yoko la maqela amele athembele ngePAJA kuqala, ngaphandle kwakwiimeko ezikhethekileyo, xa ephikisa ukuhambisana nomgaqo-siseko kwendlela amagosa karhulumente aziphatha ngayo okanye izigqibo azenzayo.

Le Nkundla yacacisa yathi isigqibo ‘esisekelwe kwizizathu ezivakalayo’ sixhomekeka kwiimeko zetyala ngalinye, kucingwa ngothotho lwezinto eziquka uhlobo lwesigqibo, ulwazi lomntu osenzayo, uhlobo lweemfuno ezingqubanayo ezibandakanyekileyo, ukuqwalaselwa kwenkqubo-mgaqo, ifuthe leso sigqibo, into yokuba eso sigqibo siza kuyifeza na le nto ifunwayo, sixhaswa ngokufanelekileyo na zizibakala okanye zizizathu zokuba senziwe nokuba umenzi weso sigqibo uye wazibhalansisa na iinkalo.

Iinkundla kwakufuneka zihloniphe indima negunya elinikwa amanye amaphiko karhulumente ngumgaqo-siseko xa zihlola izigqibo, ngokukodwa xa eso sigqibo sibandakanya ulwazi okanye ubugcisa obukhethekileyo – iinkundla azifanelanga ‘zixhuzule iintambo’ kwamanye amaphiko karhulumente. Kodwa ke, oku akuthethi kuthi inkundla ifanele nje ‘igximfize isitampu’ ize ngokuzenzekelayo igunyazise izigqibo ezingasekelwanga kwizizathu ezivakalayo kuba nje ityala linzima.

UNgcobo J (engqinelwa zizo zonke ezinye iijaji) wabhala ecaleni ngemfuneko yokwenza iinguqu neyokuba kulinganwe kuluntu ngokubanzi nakwicandelo loshishino lwabalobi.
xh.right_and_principle: Icandelo 33 loMgaqo-siseko noMthetho 3 Wowama-2000 Okhuthaza Ubulungisa Kulawulo [Promotion of Administrative Justice Act (PAJA)], ngokulandelelana kwayo ibethelela kwaye imela ilungelo lokuba kwenziwe isenzo solawulo esinobulungisa. Ilungelo lezenzo ezinobulungisa lithi amagosa karhulumente (ibe ngamanye amaxesha nabo bangekho kurhulumente) amele enze izigqibo (isenzo) ezihambisana nomthetho, ezilandele inkqubo enobulungisa nezinezizathu ezivakalayo.
xh.snippet: Le nkundla yaxubusha ukuba siyintoni isigqibo esisekelwe kwizizathu ezivakalayo xa kufikwa kwisenzo solawulo.
xh.title: Bato Star Fishing (Pty) Ltd v Minister of Environmental Affairs and Tourism and Others [2004] ZACC 15; 2004 (4) SA 490 (CC); 2004 (7) BCLR 687 (CC)

xh.facts_and_issues:
Mr Booi was employed by Amathole District Municipality. He was charged with misconduct and was dismissed following a disciplinary hearing. He then referred a dismissal dispute to the South African Local Government Bargaining Council, where the arbitrator found him not guilty of the charges and held that the dismissal was unfair, and ordered that he be reinstated. The Municipality approached the Labour Court, which upheld the arbitrator’s findings; however, the Labour Court held that the order of reinstatement was not reasonable since the applicant’s conduct was destructive to the prospect of a continued employment relationship. The Labour Court substituted the arbitration award with an order of compensation, and Mr Booi approached the Constitutional Court to seek reinstatement. 
The Constitutional Court unanimously granted condonation and leave to appeal and upheld the appeal. In terms of section 193 (2)(b) of the LRA, the primary remedy for a finding of unfair dismissal is an order of reinstatement, unless the circumstances surrounding the dismissal are such that a continued employment relationship would be intolerable.
xh.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court emphasised that, where a dismissal had been found to be substantively unfair, reinstatement would be the primary remedy according to section 193(1) of the LRA, unless the employment relationship has irretrievably broken down according to section 193(2)(b) of the LRA. The Constitutional Court determined that the language, context, and purpose of section 193(2)(b) dictate that the bar of intolerability is high to protect labour rights. Further, the court said that the evidentiary burden to establish intolerability is heightened where the dismissed employee has been exonerated of all charges.

The Constitutional Court considered that the arbitrator acted in terms of section 193(2), considered all evidence, found that it does not established intolerability, and decided to order the primary remedy of reinstatement; therefore, the arbitrator’s decision should not be readily interfered with by a review court. The Constitutional Court emphasised that arbitration awards are intended to be final and binding.

The applicant had instructed his legal representatives to secure payment of compensation in terms of the Labour Court’s judgement. This conduct may have created the impression that the applicant had acquiesced in the judgement and would not later seek to appeal it. The Constitutional Court stressed that widespread unemployment, poverty, and exploitation of employees in South Africa are hurdles that the constitutional project seeks to overcome and because the matter related to fair labour practices and job security, the Constitutional Court determined that the doctrine of peremption could not be strictly enforced. The doctrine of peremption is based on the principle that no person can be allowed to take up two positions inconsistent with one another.
xh.right_and_principle:
The Constitutional Court needed to determine the proper approach to section 193(2)(b). 

The Constitutional Court also needed to determine whether the Labour Court was entitled to interfere with the arbitrator’s decision.
xh.snippet: This case was a review of an order by the Labour Court which interfered with an arbitrator's decision.
xh.title: Booi v Amathole District Municipality and Others [2021] ZACC 36

xh.facts_and_issues:
The Applicant, Ms Bwanya, was in a committed romantic relationship with Mr Ruch, who later died. The relationship involved living together and reciprocal duties of support, and the Applicant emotionally supported the deceased whilst he took on the financial responsibilities of the home. They regarded their relationship as a permanent commitment and they presented publicly to friends and family as spouses. In fact, they intended to get married before Mr Ruch passed away. 
On his death, the deceased left a will in which he nominated his mother as the sole heir to his estate. However, his mother had predeceased him in 2013 thus his estate was treated as intestate. The Applicant lodged two claims against the estate on the basis of being the deceased’s life partner. However, the executor excluded her from inheriting under the Intestate Succession Act, and also rejected her claim for spousal maintenance under the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act. 
The Applicant approached the High Court, challenging the constitutionality of section 1(1) of the Intestate Succession Act and section 1 of the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act, because those sections exclude permanent heterosexual life partners. The High Court found the section of the Intestate Succession Act to be unconstitutional for unfair discrimination against permanent heterosexual life partners, but found that the discrimination under the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act was fair and constitutionally justifiable. 
The Applicant then directly approached the Constitutional Court seeking an order of invalidity of both sections from both Acts.
xh.interpretation:
The court decided that Section 1 of the Maintenance Act is inconsistent with the Constitution, as it does not include permanent life partners of a heterosexual romantic relationship in which reciprocal duties of support had been made by the partners and the surviving spouse did not receive a share of the deceased’s estate sufficient to maintain themselves.
The meaning of ‘survivor’ in the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act must include the surviving partner in an opposite-sex long-term commitment in which there was mutual commitment to support each other and where the survivor had not received any fair share of the deceased partner’s estate.
The definitions of 'spouse' and 'marriage' under section 1 of the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act did not meet the requirements of the Constitution because of how they excluded permanent partners in committed heterosexual relationships with mutual support duties. The partners from these relationships should be regarded as spouses for purposes of the Act, and their partnership is to be considered a marriage under the Act.
Interpretations of the definitions of ‘spouse’ under the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act are to also encompass partners from a permanent romantic commitment under which the partners agree to mutually support each other.
Likewise, the definition of ‘marriage’ must include the surviving partners from the relationship defined above.
Parliament was tasked to craft a law that remedies the invalidity found by the Court within a period of 18 months after which the orders will become binding as a form of law.
Section 1(1) of the Intestate Succession Act is constitutionally null and void for its failure to include the words ‘partner in a permanent life partnership in which the partners have undertaken reciprocal duties of support’ after the word ‘spouse.’
As a result of the above, the section of the Succession Act defining the word ‘spouse’ must include the phrase ‘“or partner in a permanent life partnership in which the partners have undertaken reciprocal duties of support”. This means that whenever the word spouse appears in the Act, it will also include the added phrase. For a period of 18 months, Parliament had leeway to take measures to fix the invalidity in the Intestate succession Act. It could achieve this by amending the relevant section. However, should it fail to do so after the period has lapsed, the order of the court becomes binding law to be read into the Act when it is interpreted.
xh.right_and_principle: The principal issue is whether section 1(1) of the Intestate Succession Act and section 1 of the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act are constitutional, because those sections exclude permanent heterosexual life partners from inheriting and benefiting when their partner dies.
xh.snippet: The right to equality in the Constitution demands that there should be no unfair discrimination in legislation. This case is about whether section 1(1) of the Intestate Succession Act and section 1 of the Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act are constitutional, because those sections exclude permanent heterosexual life partners from inheriting and benefiting when their partner dies.
xh.title: Bwanya v Master of the High Court, Cape Town and Others (CCT 241/20) [2021] ZACC 51

xh.facts_and_issues: Ummangali waye wahlaselwa ngokwesondo yindoda eyayilinde ityala lokuzama ukudlwengula elinye ibhinqa. Nakuba isenzo solwaphulo-mthetho eyayityholwa ngaso le ndoda sasinobuzaza kwaye le ndoda yayikhe yafunyaniswa inetyala lokudlwengula ngaphambili, amapolisa nomtshutshisi acebisa ukuba le ndoda ikhululwe ngaphandle kwebheyile. Ummangali waye wafaka ibango lomonakalo kuMphathiswa, esithi amapolisa nabatshutshisi babeye ngenxa yokungakhathali basilela ukuthwala imbopheleleko ebekwe ngumthetho ababemtyala yona yokuthatha amanyathelo okuthintela le ndoda ekumonzakaliseni. INkundla Ephakamileyo yalichitha ibango lommangali yaza iNkundla Ephakamileyo Yezibheno yangqinelana nayo, zisithi amapolisa nabatshutshisi babengamtyali imbopheleleko efunwa ngumthetho yokumkhusela ngokomthetho waseMzantsi Afrika. Ummangali wafaka isimangalo kwiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko sokuba igqibe enoba amapolisa nabatshutshisi banembopheleleko yenkathalo na kwixhoba lobundlobongela besondo, nokuba, ukuba kunjalo, ngaba loo mlinganiselo wenkathalo wawuye wophulwa na.
xh.interpretation:
Le Nkundla yathi icandelo 173 loMgaqo-siseko linika zonke iinkundla igunya lokuvelisa umthetho oqhelekileyo ukwenzela ubulungisa. Icandelo 39(2) loMgaqo-siseko lithi xa kuphuhliswa umthetho oqhelekileyo, zonke iinkundla zimele zikhuthaze injongo, intsingiselo nosukelo loMqulu Wamalungelo. Le Nkundla yathi xa umthetho uphuma ecaleni kulo mlinganiselo, iinkundla zinembopheleleko yokuthatha amanyathelo. Xa kugqitywa enoba imbopheleleko yenkathalo ikho kweli tyala, iNkundla yajonga imimiselo esebenza kule meko eyayisithi amalungu omkhosi wamapolisa anembopheleleko yokulondoloza inkululeko nokhuseleko.

Le Nkundla yathi xa kuthethwa ngezo mbopheleleko ngokunxibelelene nesidima nenkululeko nokhuseleko lomntu, “zimbalwa izinto ezibaluleke kumntu wasetyhini ngaphezu kokukhululeka kwisisongelo sobundlobongela besondo.”  Le Nkundla yathi amapolisa ayenye yeearhente eziphambili zikarhulumente ezinembopheleleko yokukhusela uluntu ngokubanzi, nabasetyhini ngokukhethekileyo, kuko nakuphi na ukunyhashwa kwamalungelo abo asisiseko zizaphuli-mthetho ezinobundlobongela. Le Nkundla yafumanisa ukuba amapolisa, ngenxa yoko, ayenembopheleleko kummangali nokuba ayeye ayophula loo mbopheleleko ngokucebisa ukuba kukhululwe indoda, enembali yokwenza izenzo zobundlobongela besondo, ngaphandle kwebheyile. Ngenxa yoko, le Nkundla yamnika ummangali amabango omonakalo.
xh.right_and_principle:
Ingxaki kweli tyala yayikukuba amapolisa okanye abatshutshisi banembopheleleko yenkathalo na kwixhoba lobundlobongela besondo, nokuba, ukuba kunjalo, ngaba loo mlinganiselo wenkathalo wawuye wophulwa na. Ummangali wema ngelithi babefanele bacingisise ngaphambi kokuba bakhulule lo mtyholwa ekubeni buxhaphake kangaka ubundlobongela obenziwa kwabasetyhini eMzantsi Afrika. Urhulumente wayefanele abe nenkxalabo ekhethekileyo kuba umgaqo-siseko ubeka imbopheleleko yokuba kungenziwa nantoni na enokuphinda ivule ithuba lokwenziwa kobundlobongela. Ummangalelwa wema ngelithi umthetho uchaza ngokucacileyo ukuba impazamo eyenziwe ligosa lenkundla eba neziphumo ezibi, njengokuba kuye kwanjalo kwimeko yommangali, ayinakuba sisizathu sokufaka ibango lomonakalo enkundleni. Kwakhona, urhumente akanayo ‘imbopheleleko yenkathalo’ kumntu okwimeko yommangali.

Le Nkundla yathi amapolisa aneembopheleleko zokukhusela amalungelo neenkululeko ezisisiseko eziqulethwe nguMqulu Wamalungelo. La malungelo asisiseko aquka isidima, inkululeko nokhuseleko. Ngoko, amapolisa afanele abakhusele ngendlela efanelekileyo abasetyhini kubundlobongela besondo, ibe xa esilele ukwenjenjalo anokubekwa ityala.

Le Nkundla yagxininisa imbopheleleko onayo uMzantsi Afrika phantsi komthetho wamazwe ngamazwe yokuthintela konke ukucalucalwa kwabantu ngokobuni. Le Nkundla yathi amapolisa ayenye yeearhente eziphambili zikarhulumente ezinembopheleleko yokukhusela uluntu ngokubanzi, nabasetyhini ngokukhethekileyo, nxamnye nokunyhashwa kwamalungelo abo asisiseko zizaphuli-mthetho ezinobundlobongela. Le Nkundla yafumanisa ukuba amapolisa, ngenxa yoko, ayenembopheleleko yokukhusela ummangali yaza yamnika amabango omonakalo awafunayo.
xh.snippet: Ingxaki kweli tyala yayikukuba amapolisa okanye abatshutshisi banembopheleleko yenkathalo na kwixhoba lobundlobongela lesondo, nokuba, ukuba kunjalo, ngaba loo mlinganiselo wenkathalo wawuye wophulwa na.
xh.title: Carmichele v Minister of Safety and Security [2001] ZACC 22; 2001 (4) SA 938 (CC); 2001 (10) BCLR 995 (CC)

xh.facts_and_issues:
Abamangali bacela isindululo esicacisayo: ukuba icandelo 154(3) leCPA limele litolikwe njengelikhusela ukuba angachazwa amagama amaxhoba olwaphulo-mthetho angabantwana nokuba ngaba oko kungachazwa kwamagama abo kumele kuqhubeke na naxa sele bengabantu abadala ngaphandle kokuba inkundla iyalele ngolunye uhlobo; okanye, kungenjalo, eli candelo liyangqubana nomgaqo-siseko kwinto yokuba lingabakhuseli ngolo hlobo abantwana abangamaxhoba lize ngokuzenzekelayo libakhusele naxa sele bengabantu abadala. Ngowe-1997, ummangali wesibini, wathathwa kubazali bakhe abamzalayo ekwiwadi yababelekayo esibhedlele. Ngowama-2015, xa ummangali wesibini wayeneminyaka eli-17 ubudala, wafunyanwa ngabazali bakhe abamzalayo. Umntu owayemxhwilile wabekwa izityholo waza watshutshiswa, ibe ummangali wesibini wayenokuba lingqina kwelo tyala. Ityala labekelwa umhla wokuqala owawuza kuba semva kokuba ummangali eneminyaka eli-18 ubudala. Enexhala ngenxa yamehlo amajelo eendaba, ummangali wesibini waya kummangali wokuqala, iCentre for Child Law, ukuze afumane inkxaso yezomthetho. ICentre for Child Law yabhalela onke amajelo eendaba aphambili yaza yacela ukuba angachazi ukuba ngubani ummangali wesibini.

Abamangalelwa bamajelo eendaba bathi zombini iindlela elitolikwe ngazo icandelo 154(3) zazingenakuvunyelwa ngumgaqo-siseko, kuba zazingqubana nelungelo lenkululeko yokuveza izimvo nomgaqo wokudandalaziswa elubala kobulungisa.
xh.interpretation:
Isininzi seejaji sathi ubukhulu becala injongo yecandelo 154(3) loMthetho Wenkqubo Elandelwayo Kulwaphulo-mthetho (Criminal Procedure Act) yayikukukhusela umntwana kwimiphumo emibi yokupapashwa kwegama lakhe nokuchazwa ukuba ungubani ngenxa yokuba ebandakanyeke kwityala lolwaphulo-mthetho. Ekubeni olu khuselo lunikwa kuphela abatyholwa namangqina angabantwana, kukho isikhewu kulo mthetho xa kufikwa ekukhuselweni kwabantwana abangamaxhoba kumatyala olwaphulo-mthetho. Le Nkundla yathi ukungaqukwa kwamaxhoba kwicandelo 154(3) kwakulisikela umda ilungelo lokulingana, kuba laliqwalasela icala elinye kwaye linganikeli ngokhuseleko nenzuzo yomthetho elinganayo. Le Nkundla yafumanisa ukuba amalungelo abantwana (esidima nokugcinwa kweemfihlelo zabo) ayenxibelelene, kuba umntwana ngamnye ‘unesidima, iimfuno nezilangazelelo ezikhethekileyo zakhe’. Ukungakwazi ukulawula indlela abaliswa ngayo awona maxesha abuhlungu nanobuntununtunu obomi bomntwana eluntwini kwakuhlasela undoqo wesidima somntwana.

Le Nkundla yafumanisa ukuba ilungelo lesidima lalilisikela umda ilungelo lenkululeko yokuveza izimvo, eliqinisekiswe kwicandelo 16 loMgaqo-siseko neliquka ilungelo lamajelo eendaba lokupapasha inkcazelo, nokuba ilungelo lokupapasha inkcazelo lalingenakusetyenziswa ukuze kuthethelelwe ukunyhashwa kwelungelo lesidima.  Le Nkundla yabhalansisa inkululeko yokuveza izimvo nokudandalaziswa elubala kobulungisa kwelinye icala kunye nelungelo lesidima nelokugcinwa kweemfihlelo kwelinye. Le Nkundla yagqiba kwelokuba umonakalo omkhulu owenziwa kubathathi-nxaxheba abangabantwana, isidima nokugcinwa kweemfihlelo zabo, zinamandla ngakumbi kunemiphumo engaphantsi yokusikela umda ukudandalaziswa elubala kobulungisa nokuphazanyiswa okuncinci kwinkululeko yamajelo eendaba; le nto yayithethelela ukunikelwa kokhuseleko olusisiseko oluqhubekayo (ukungachazwa kwamagama abantwana abangamaxhoba).

Le Nkundla yathi umgaqo wokujonga eyona nto iza kuba yinzuzo emntwaneni xa kudibene nelungelo lesidima nelokugcinwa kweemfihlelo kwakufuna ukuba abantwana abathatha inxaxheba baqhubeke bekhuselwa naxa sele bengabantu abadala. Isigwebo sesininzi seejaji sithi kukho izizathu ezahlukileyo kodwa eziyimfuneko zokuqhubeka nokukhusela abantwana abangamaxhoba, abangamangqina nabatyholwayo. Le Nkundla yawugqala umgaqo wokudandalaziswa elubala kobulungisa nokubaluleka kwenkululeko yokuveza izimvo, kodwa yema ngelithi ukunika abantwana abathatha inxaxheba ukhuseleko oluqhubekayo kwakungenamphumo uqatha kwinkululeko yabeendaba. Le Nkundla yabhengeza icandelo 154(3) njengelingasebenziyo yaza yayalela kufakwe isongezelelo sexeshana esasisithi umntu okhuselekileyo phantsi kweli candelo akalahlekelwa lolo khuseleko akuba ngumntu omdala, kwaye unelungelo lokunikisa okanye lokwala ngemvume yokuba kupapashwe igama lakhe emva kokuba ebe ngumntu omdala – okanye ukuba imvume ayinikelwanga, kungayiwa kwinkundla efanelekileyo ngabeendaba ukuze bacele ukususwa kwesalelo sokupapasha.

UCameron J, uFroneman J noJafta J bavumelana nesigqibo sesininzi seejaji kumba wokukhuselwa kwamaxhoba kodwa abavumelana naso kumba wokuqhubeka nokuwakhusela. Ezi jaji zineembono ezahlukileyo zavuma ukuba phantsi kweli candelo nangokwesigqibo sesininzi seejaji, ukuya kutsho kubudala beminyaka eli-18 abantwana, kuquka amaxhoba, ayeya kukhuseleka ngokwaneleyo. Isigwebo segcuntswana leejaji sathi ilungelo lenkululeko yokuveza izimvo nomgaqo wokudandalaziswa elubala kobulungisa zazifuna ukuba kubekho inkqubo esisiseko apho ukukhuselwa ngokuthi lingachazwa igama kuphela xa loo mntwana ukhuselwayo esiba neminyaka eli-18 ubudala, ngaphandle kokuba inkundla ilwandisa ngokuphandle olo khuseleko. Izigwebo eziveza olunye uluvo zaphinda zema ngelithi isigqibo sokuba ilungelo lesidima, ukugcinwa kweemfihlelo nokuqwalaselwa kweyona nto iya kuba yinzuzo emntwaneni anyhashiwe kwakunzima ukusiqonda kolu khuseleko luqhubekayo. Isizathu yayikukuba into eyayiyingxaki kukuba icandelo 154(3) lalisilela ukukhusela abantwana xa besiba neminyaka eli-18 ubudala yiloo nto kwakukho uloyiko lokuba abeendaba babeza kulipapasha igama lommangali wesibini xa esiba neminyaka eli-18.
xh.right_and_principle: Ingxaki eyayiphambi kweNkundla yayikukuba icandelo 154(3) layichaza ngokuphandle ukuba lalimele likhuselwe lingachazwa igama lomntwana ongumtyholwa okanye olingqina kwityala lolwaphulo-mthetho, kodwa, oko kukhuselwa kwakungekho kubantwana abangamaxhoba. Le Nkundla kwakufuneka igqibe nokuba ukukhuselwa okunikelwa licandelo 154(3) kufanele kuqhubeke naxa sele bengabantu abadala na abamangalelwa, amangqina namaxhoba angabantwana.

xh.facts_and_issues:
The case is commonly referred to as Centre for Child Law v Director-General Department of Home Affairs and Others. Mr Naki, a South African citizen, married Ms Ndovya, a citizen of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). They married in accordance with the customary law of DRC. The marriage was not registered because customary marriages are not registerable in DRC. One of the children of the union, NN, was born in Grahamstown. Before NN was born, Ms Ndovya travelled to and from South Africa on a visitor’s visa.  Shortly before NN’s birth, Ms Ndovya’s visa expired while she was in South Africa. At that time she was at an advanced stage of pregnancy. She was not eligible to apply for a new visa, and she could not travel back to the DRC.
After the birth of NN, Mr Naki and Ms Ndovya tried to register the birth with the Department of Home Affairs, but the Department refused to register the child’s birth because Ms Ndovya didn't have a valid visa. The Department also refused to recognise the couple’s customary law marriage, and NN was treated as a child born out of wedlock. Section 9 and 10 of the Births and Deaths Registration Act did not allow unmarried fathers to register the births of their children without their mothers or where the child’s mother was undocumented.
The Centre for Child Law, a registered law clinic based in the Law Faculty at the University of Pretoria, applied to the High Court for an order declaring sections 9 and 10 of the Births and Deaths Registration Act unconstitutional. The High Court refused to declare section 9 and 10 unconstitutional, and this was an appeal of the decision of the High Court.
xh.interpretation: The Court upheld the application. It found that section 10 of the Births and Deaths Registration Act limited the right of an unmarried father to register his new-born child under his surname. Section 10 also discriminated against the child’s right not to be treated different because of social origin or birth in that they were treated depending on whether they were born out of wedlock. The Court held that Section 10 should be removed from the Act because it was unconstitutional and that section 9(2) would also be removed too, as it was subject to section 10. Parliament should consider unfair discrimination against unmarried fathers and children born to unmarried parents.
xh.right_and_principle:
The main issue in this case was whether sections 9 and 10 of the Births and Deaths Registration Act were in line with the constitutional goal of equality and dignity for unmarried parents and their biological children.
The court considered the following issues:

  • whether there were any reasons that could justify the unfair discrimination in section 10, which drew a distinction between children born to parents who are married versus parents who are not married;
  • whether this differential treatment was reasonable and justifiable; and
  • whether it was in the best interests of a child for legislation to permit a father of a child born in wedlock to register the birth of that child and also allow the same for an unmarried man, but subject to the consent of the child’s mother.
xh.snippet: The court had to decide whether sections 9 and 10 of the Births and Deaths Registration Act violated the constitutional rights of equality (section 9 of the Constitution) and dignity (section 10 of the Constitution) for unmarried parents and their biological children.
xh.title: Centre for Child Law v Director General: Department of Home Affairs and Others (CCT 101 of 2020) [2021] ZACC 31

xh.facts_and_issues:
On 15 March 1996, the Legislature of the province of KwaZulu-Natal (KZN) unanimously adopted its Constitution. This took place after a lengthy political negotiation between the various parties represented in that legislature. On 25 March 1996, the Speaker of the KZN Legislature submitted to the Constitutional Court a copy of the provincial Constitution together with a certificate in which he stated, among other issues, that the Constitution had been passed by the requisite majority. The Speaker formally asked the Constitutional Court to certify it under section 160(4) of the interim Constitution. The President of the Constitutional Court instructed the Speaker to inform any parties that wanted to object to the certification that they were allowed to lodge grounds of objection with the Constitutional Court before written argument was submitted. In response, the African National Congress (ANC) and the Government of National Unity (GNU) provided a list of objections. The ANC and GNU contended that the provincial Constitution was inconsistent with the interim Constitution, including the Constitutional Principles, and should not be certified. The Speaker and Premier claimed that the provincial Constitution was not inconsistent and should be certified. Written objections to the certification were received from the King’s Council of KZN.

All objections were considered by the Constitutional Court. It concluded that the objections from the King’s Council of KZN had nothing to do with matters which the Constitutional Court could properly consider in exercising its powers of certification. The Constitutional Court considered three major issues in its assessment of the provincial Constitution to certify it. The first issue was whether the provincial Constitution was giving more power to the province on any matters beyond the powers of the national government. The second issue was whether the provincial Constitution was consistent with the Constitution of the country. The third issue was whether a provincial Constitution can delay certain of its own parts until a later date or until certain conditions are met.
xh.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court declined to certify the Constitution of the Province of KwaZulu-Natal, adopted on 15 March 1996 by the KwaZulu-Natal Legislature. The Constitution was not in line with the requirements of the Interim Constitution of South Africa. 

The provincial Constitution had many examples of an attempted usurpation of national power which therefore had to be carefully considered and corrected before the Constitution could be valid. There were also inconsistencies between the provisions of the provincial Constitution and the interim Constitution of SA. The Court considered the suspensive conditions and stated that the text of the provincial Constitution would have to be evaluated and certified as a whole, because the meaning and effect of a particular provision could be crucially dependent on another. If certain clauses of the text came into operation after others, this could well influence the effect and meaning of those parts of the text which did come into operation immediately on certification.
xh.right_and_principle: The court had to consider whether KZN's provincial Constitution was materially flawed and could therefore not be certified under s 160(4) of the interim Constitution. One of the main flaws was potential usurpation of national powers.
xh.snippet: This case concerned the certification of the Constitution of the province of KwaZulu-Natal, in which the Constitutional Court saw several major problems.
xh.title: Certification of the Constitution of the Province of KwaZulu-Natal (CCT 15/96) [1996] ZACC 17 (06 September 1996)

xh.facts_and_issues:
Isigwebo seNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko sasingaqhelekanga kuba kwakufuneka iNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko iqwalasele enoba umbhalo womgaqo-siseko owawamkelwe liBhunga Lomgaqo-iseko wawuhambisana nemigaqo yomgaqo-siseko engama-34 eyayikwisihlomelo sesine soMgaqo-siseko Wexeshana. Le migaqo yomgaqo-siseko “yayisisivumelwano esisemthethweni” esasiyingxelo esemthethweni yesigqibo ekwafikelelwa kuso ngamaqela awayeqhuba uthethathethwano. 

Idrafti yokuqala yombhalo womgaqo-siseko yamkelwa liBhunga Lomgaqo-siseko ngowesi-8 kuMeyi 1996 yaza yadluliselwa kwiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko ukuze iqinisekiswe ngowe-10. Ebudeni bale nkqubo iNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yamamela izimvo ezahlukeneyo malunga nombhalo wokugqibela womgaqo-siseko ezazivela kwimibutho yepolitiki nakwamanye amaqumrhu abahlali kwaye, njengoko kuboniswe ngezantsi, iNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yafumanisa ukuba umbhalo wedrafti yomgaqo-siseko wawungahambisani kuzo zonke iinkalo nemigaqo yomgaqo-siseko yaza yawubuyisela kwiBhunga Lomgaqo-siseko.
xh.interpretation:
Kwakukho izinto ezithile ezixhalabisayo ezaphakanyiswa yiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko xa yayithelekisa umbhalo wokugqibela nemigaqo yomgaqo-siseko. Enye yezinto ezazixhalabisa yayibandakanya ukugadwa nokukhuselwa kokuzimela-geqe koMkhuseli Woluntu noMphicothi-zimali Jikelele okwakungahambisani noMgaqo Womgaqo-siseko CP XXIX, ngokuphathelele ukuzimela geqe kweKomishoni Yabasebenzi BakaRhulumente, iBhanki Enguvimba, uMphicothi-zimali Jikelele noMkhuseli Woluntu. INkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yagxininisa ukuba ukuzimela geqe nokungakhethi cala koMkhuseli Woluntu kwakubalulekile ukuze kuqinisekwe ukuba urhulumente uyaphenduliswa kwaye uyasebenza. Ngoko, umbhalo womgaqo-siseko wabuyiselwa kwiBhunga Lomgaqo-siseko ukuze lenze uhlaziyo olungakumbi.

KuMgaqo-siseko, iSahluko 1 sithetha ngeziseko zoMgaqo-siseko. Ezi ziseko zigxininisa ukuba iRiphabliki YoMzantsi Afrika “ililizwe elinye, elizimeleyo, lentando yesininzi” elisekelwe kwiziseko ezingundoqo ezifana nesidima somntu, ukungacaluli ngokobuhlanga, ukongama koMgaqo-siseko nenkqubo yolawulo lwesininzi eyamkela imibutho emininzi. Mhlawumbi kubaluleke kakhulu ukubalaselisa ukuba ezi ziseko zokuqala zingundoqo wolawulo lomgaqo-siseko ibe ngokoMgaqo-siseko kukho izinto eziliqela ekufuneka kuhlangatyezwane nazo ukuze kuhlaziywe la malungiselelo. Ezi zinto zifunekayo zingqongqo ngakumbi kunezo zifuneka xa kuhlaziywa amanye amalungiselelo oMgaqo-siseko.

Xa sibuyela kwisigwebo seNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko, le Nkundla yagxininisa ukuba kwakubalulekile ukuchaza izakhiwo ezisisiseko zolawulo olutsha lomgaqo-siseko kuthelekiswa nemigaqo yomgaqo-siseko. INkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yagxininisa ukuba ezi zakhiwo zaziquka ukuba “ulawulo lwesininzi lomgaqo-siseko olusekelwe ekubeni uMgaqo-siseko wongamile lukhuselwe ziinkundla ezizimele geqe” nto leyo ehambisana nomgaqo IV, VII no-XV. Ukongezelela koko, iNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yagxininisa imfuneko yokuba kubekho “urhulumente owamkela ulawulo lwesininzi olunemibutho emininzi, umqulu wabavoti wezwe lonke, kwaye, ngokubanzi, ukumelwa ngokulinganayo”. INkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yafumanisa ukuba umbhalo omtsha wokugqibela womgaqo-siseko wawuhambisana nezikhokelo zezakhiwo zolawulo olutsha lomgaqo-siseko ezifunwa yimigaqo engama-34 yomgaqo-siseko kuba iye yaxhaswa kwicandelo 1 loMgaqo-siseko.
xh.right_and_principle: INkundla Yomgaqo-siseko yayinikwe imbopheleleko yokuqinisekisa umbhalo wokugqibela womgaqo-siseko ibe le Nkundla kwakufuneka igqibe enoba lo mbhalo womgaqo-siseko wawuhambisana nemigaqo engama-34 yeSihlomelo 4 soMgaqo-siseko Wexeshana. Isigwebo seNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko sahlulwa saba zizahluko ezisibhozo, ezisusela kumongo wenkqubo yokuqinisekisa, ukutolikwa kwemigaqo yomgaqo-iseko ziye ekusetyenzisweni nasekutolikweni koMqulu Wamalungelo namagunya kaRhulumente wephondo nowengingqi.

xh.facts_and_issues:
According to section 143 of the Constitution, provincial constitutions must be consistent with the national Constitution. They may not confer powers or functions on the province that fall outside the area of provincial competence laid down by the National Constitution. Provincial constitutions may, however, provide for "provincial legislative or executive structures and procedures" that differ from the National Constitution. 
In February 1997 the Western Cape legislature adopted a constitution and its Speaker referred the text to the Constitutional Court for certification. The Court heard supporting representations on behalf of the Speaker, whereas the national government and the African National Congress opposed certification. 
Multiple objections to the certification were considered. A key objection was that some Western Cape Constitution provisions were identical to those of the National Constitution, which made them fall outside the competence of provinces.
xh.interpretation:
The Constitutional Court denied certification to the Western Cape Constitution on three grounds.
(a) According to the national Constitution, only national legislation can prescribe an electoral system.
(b) Provincial constitutions can not take away a ceremonial power conferred on the President of the Constitutional Court by the national Constitution (relating to administering oaths of office).
(c) A provision in the provincial text calling for provincial legislation to flesh out a prohibition against provincial cabinet members performing "paid work" was fatally inconsistent with the national Constitution.
xh.right_and_principle: Section 104(1)(a) of the Constitution empowers provinces to adopt their own provincial constitutions,  subject to conditions set out in sections 142 and 143. Provincial constitutions only become law when certified by the Constitutional Court. This case concerned the certification of the Constitution of the Western Cape.
xh.snippet: This case concerned whether the Constitution of the Western Cape was consistent with the Constitution of the Republic of South Africa, and thus whether it could be certified by the Constitutional Court in terms of Section 104(1)(a) of the Constitution.
xh.title: Certification of the Constitution of the Western Cape, 1997 (CCT 6/97) [1997] ZACC 8 (02 September 1997)

xh.facts_and_issues: In 2016 UNISA took the decision to adopt a language policy in terms of section 20 (2) of the Higher Education Act 101/1997. The decision led to the phasing out of the Afrikaans language which meant that no courses were going to be offered in Afrikaans at UNISA. AfriForum disputed the decision in the High Court, which found that the decision was in violation of section 29 (2) of the Constitution, which states that 'Everyone has the right to receive education in the official language or languages of their choice in public educational institutions'. AfriForum’s submissions on regularity were dismissed by the High Court and they approached the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA). The SCA decided that UNISA had failed to establish that the adoption of the language policy was conducted in a constitutionally compliant manner, which led to UNISA appealing the decision to the Constitutional Court.
xh.interpretation: The Court held that the SCA's judgment would not be effected until the 2023 academic year begins, and should UNISA choose to stick with its language policy adopted in 2016, it has to make sure that this is done in accordance with the requirements of section 29 (2) of the Constitution. If UNISA was to have a new language policy before the 2023 academic year, then the judgment handed by the SCA would no longer be in effect.
xh.right_and_principle: The Court had to decide whether the decision by UNISA to discontinue Afrikaans language courses violated section 29 (2) of the Constitution, which states that 'Everyone has the right to receive education in the official language or languages of their choice in public educational institutions'.

xh.facts_and_issues:
Eli tyala lamanyelwa yiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko emva kokuba kuye kwabhenwa kwiNkundla Ephakamileyo Yezibheno [Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA)]. Ummangali, umsebenzi wakwarhulumente, wagxothwa kwinkampani karhulumente. Emva kokuba egxothiwe, wadlulisela isimangalo sakhe kwiCommission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration (iCCMA) ngokoMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi (Labour Relations Act) 66 Wowe-1995. I-CCMA yoyiswa kukusombulula eli tyala ngexesha elisikelweyo leentsuku ezingama-30 yaza yacebisa ukuba kulandelwe inkqubo yolamlo ngokoMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi.

Ummangali wakhetha ukuba angayilandeli inkqubo yolamlo aze endaweni yoko aye kwiNkundla Ephakamileyo YaseRhawutini ukuze ibekele bucala ityala lokumohlwaya elaphumela ekubeni agxothwe kwaye imbuyisele emsebenzini. Ummangali wema ngelithi unezizathu ezibini zeli nyathelo eziphambi kwakhe, esinye sisuka kuMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi size esinye sisusele kuMqulu Wamalungelo xa ufundwa kunye noMthetho Okhuthaza Ubulungisa Kulawulo (Promotion of Administrative Justice Act) 3 Wowama-2000 (iPAJA). Ummangali wema ngelithi iNkundla Ephakamileyo yayinegunya kunye neNkundla Yabasebenzi lokumamela ibango lakhe. INkundla Ephakamileyo yakubekela bucala ukugxothwa kwakhe yaza yayalela ukuba ummangalelwa abuyisele ummangali emsebenzini. Ummangalelwa wafaka isibheno kwiSCA nxamnye nomyalelo weNkundla Ephakamileyo waza wacela ukucaciselwa ukuba ngaba ukugxothwa kommangali kwakuphantsi kwegunya leNkundla Yabasebenzi kuphela ngokwecandelo 157(1) loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi nokuba ukugxothwa “kwakusisenzo solawulo” na ngokwengcaciso yePAJA. Isininzi seejaji zale Nkundla savumelana nesibheno saza sathi ummangali wayesilele ukubonisa ukuba ukugxothwa kwakhe “kwakusisenzo solawulo” ngokwengcaciso yecandelo 1 lePAJA. Emva koko ummangali wabhenela kwiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko.
xh.interpretation:
USkweyiya J, ebhalela isininzi seejaji, wagweba eli tyala ngokusekelwe kwigunya lenkundla kuphela. Isininzi seejaji sathi icandelo 157(1) loMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi lalisithi yiNkundla Yabasebenzi kuphela enegunya kumatyala “amele agwetywe yiNkundla Yabasebenzi”. Le Nkundla yathi eli tyala laliphathelele isityholo sokugxothwa ngendlela engeyiyo nokuba iinkqubo ezazifanele zilandelwe xa kugxothwa nezisombululo zeempikiswano zilawulwa nguMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi. 

Le Nkundla yayigxininisa into yokuba uMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi wawiswa ngokukhethekileyo ukuze wenze icandelo 23 loMgaqo-siseko lisebenze. Abasebenzi bakwarhulumente babezuza kukhuseleko olunikelwa nguMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi, kodwa babenalo nelungelo lokuya kwinkundla ephakamileyo ukuze bacele uncedo phantsi kwePAJA. UMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi ugubungela bonke abasebenzi, kuquka abasebenzi bakwarhulumente, ngaphandle kwabo lo Mthetho uthi abaqukwanga. Le Nkundla yagxininisa ukuba ngoxa imele ilumke xa isalela ummangali okanye ummangalelwa ilungelo xa enamalungelo angaphezu kwelinye, akufanelekanga ukuya kwiNkundla Ephakamileyo ukuze kugqitywe ngesicelo sokurhoxiswa ngokwePAJA xa uMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi ulawula kwaloo ngxaki inye iqwalaselwayo. Xa kukho izizathu ezingaphezu kwesinye sokuthatha amanyathelo kubudlelwane nabasebenzi apho umsebenzi esithi ugxothwe ngendlela engeyiyo okanye kuthathwe amanyathelo angengawo emsebenzini, umsebenzi ufanele aqale alandelele iindlela zokulungisa ingxaki ezikuMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi. Ummangali wayenyanzelekile ukuba azame zonke iindlela zokusombulula ingxaki zoMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi kuqala ngaphambi kokuba ayame ngePAJA okanye ngoMgaqo-siseko ngokungqalileyo. UMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi wawungahluli phakathi komqeshi onguRhulumente nabanye abaqeshi ibe ngenxa yoko uRhulumente umele aphathwe njengabanye abaqeshi. Le Nkundla yaphinda yathi uMgaqo-siseko kwakungayi kwayanywa ngawo ngokungqalileyo kwiNkundla Ephakamileyo (kunokuba kwayanywe ngoMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi) ukuba ummangali wayebeke isityholo sokuba uMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi wawunganikeli ngokhuseleko olwaneleyo kwaye wawungqubana necandelo 23 loMgaqo-siseko. Ummangali wayengenalungelo lokukhetha inkundla awayemele asise kuyo isimangalo sakhe ibe wayefanele alandele iinkqubo ezikuMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi. Isininzi seejaji sathi iNkundla Ephakamileyo yayingenagunya lifanayo neleNkundla Yabasebenzi saza sasichitha isibheno ngeso sizathu.

Kwisigwebo esahlukileyo sikaNgcobo J, kwenziwa la magqabaza alandelayo abalulekileyo ngecandelo 23 loMgaqo-siseko: UNgcobo J wagxininisa into yokuba uMgaqo-siseko wawutshintsha umahluko wangaphambili owawuphakathi kwabaqeshi babucala nabangurhulumente nokuba phantsi koMgaqo-siseko onke amacandelo abasebenzi akhuselwa ngokulinganayo ngokwecandelo 23 loMgaqo-siseko. UNgcobo J wagxininisa nento yokuba uMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi wasungula iNkundla Yabasebenzi kunye neNkundla Yesibheno Yabasebenzi njengeenkundla ezikhethekileyo ezinegunya elikhethekileyo lokumamela amatyala asusela kuMthetho Wobudlelwane Nabasebenzi, nokuba loo nto yayiza kuthintela ukuzichongela kwabantu iinkundla (into yokuba ummangali azikhethele nayiphi na inkundla afuna ukuya kuyo).
xh.right_and_principle: KwiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko, ummangali wema ngelithi ukugxothwa komsebenzi wakwarhulumente kwakubandakanya amalungelo abasebenzi kodwa kwangaxeshanye nobulungisa bolawulo, ekubeni ummangalelwa wayeyinkampani karhulumente. Ummangalelwa wema ngelithi ummangalelwa xa egxotha umsebenzi wayesebenzisa igunya laseburhulumenteni, elinokuphinda lihlolwe ngokwePAJA. Kwelinye icala, ummangali wayama ngecandelo 195 loMgaqo-siseko, eliphathelele imigaqo elawula ulawulo lwaseburhulumenteni. Omnye wemibuzo eyaphakanyiswayo yayikukuba ngaba zombini iNkundla Ephakamileyo neNkundla Yabasebenzi zazinegunya na kwiimpikiswano eziphathelele ingqesho zabasebenzi bakwarhulumente.

xh.facts_and_issues:
The matter was referred to the Constitutional Court for confirmation of an order of constitutional invalidity made by the High Court. The High Court had declared section 2(1)(a) and (b) of the South African Citizenship Act 88 of 1995 (the “Citizenship Act”), as amended by the South African Citizenship Amendment Act 17 of 2010 (the “2010 Amendment”), unconstitutional and invalid.

The applicants alleged that two categories were impacted by the 2010 Amendment: 1) those who acquired citizenship “by descent” (as defined in the previous version of the Citizenship Act) by being born to a South African parent outside of the country and who had registered their births prior to 1 January 2013 and 2) people who were born to a South African parent outside the country but who had not prior to 1 January 2013 registered their births in accordance with the previous version of the Act. The applicants argued that neither of these categories of persons were able to retain or obtain South African citizenship following the 2010 Amendment. The applicants were each born outside of South Africa to a South African parent prior to 1 January 2013 (being the date on which the 2010 Amendment came into effect).
xh.interpretation:
Section 2(1) of the 2010 Amendment classifies a citizen as any person who:

(a) who immediately prior to the commencement of the 2010 Amendment was a South African citizen by birth (i.e. immediately prior to 1 January 2013); or

(b) who is born in or outside of South Africa to a South African citizen.

The Constitutional Court interpreted section 2(1)(a) and (b) of the amended Citizenship Act in a way that it did not arbitrarily deprive persons of their citizenship overnight. The Constitutional Court held that it was clear that section 2(1)(a) retains citizenship only for those who were considered “citizens by birth” before the commencement of the 2010 Amendment. This could create an anomaly as persons who acquired citizenship by descent under the previous version of the Citizenship Act would now be excluded. This apparent exclusion could be resolved by adopting a purposive interpretation of section 2(1)(b).

The Court interpreted the term ‘is born’ in section 2(1)(b) as a “state of being” not indicative of a tense, but rather including all persons regardless of when they were born. The Court held that this was a reasonable and constitutionally compliant interpretation which meant that section 2 was applicable to persons born to a South African parent before and after 1 January 2013, curing the anomaly.

This interpretation allowed for all categories of citizens who acquired citizenship by birth or descent in terms of the previous version of the Citizenship Act to be included. As the 2010 Amendment could be interpreted in a constitutionally compliant manner, the findings of invalidity in the High Court were not confirmed by the Constitutional Court.

The Constitutional Court thereby ensured that the sections of the 2010 Amendment would be interpreted and applied consistently with section 20 of the Constitution.

(i) On section 20 of the Constitution, the Constitutional Court held that although the importance of citizenship should not be overemphasised, citizenship is a gateway right to many other constitutional rights – namely, freedom of movement, freedom of trade and political rights, and is more than a legal status. Citizenship related to the core of a person’s identity, a sense of belonging in a community and to security of a person most especially in communities rife with xenophobia. Deprivation of, or interference with, a person’s citizenship status affects their private and family life, their choices concerning where establish their homes, apply for jobs, enrol in schools; whether they can form part of the community; their ability to participate fully in the political activity and governance; and the extent to which they may exercise freedom of movement.

(ii) The Constitutional Court held that whilst certain rights in the Constitution are only available to South African citizens, drawing arbitrary and irrational distinctions between citizens and non-citizens through legislation or decision-making is inconsistent with the Constitution.

(iii) Legislation must be interpreted to promote the spirit, purport and objects of the Bill of Rights, but any interpretation must remain consistent with the text of the legislation. The Constitutional Court interpreted section 2(1) of the 2010 Amendment by analysing the plain meaning of the words, the context of the case and section’s purpose in light of the Bill of Rights. The Constitutional Court adopted an interpretation that was consistent with and promoted both the text of the section (by recognising that the section’s language is not time-specific but rather linked to a condition of having been born) as well as the Bill of Rights (not to arbitrarily deprive persons of their citizenship overnight, as required by section 20 linked to other constitutional rights).
xh.right_and_principle:
Based on the Respondents’ interpretation of the 2010 Amendment, the applicants were unable to gain citizenship, despite having the right to gain citizenship under the previous version of the Citizenship Act had they registered their births.

Section 20 of the Constitution provides that: ‘No citizen may be deprived of citizenship'.

The issue before the Constitutional Court was whether it was possible to interpret section 2(1) of the 2010 Amendment in a manner constitutionally complaint with section 20 of the Constitution. Interrelated to this question was whether the phrase ‘any person who is born’ in section 2(1)(b) meant that the section applied only to future persons born to South African citizens, or whether it could be interpreted to include past births too.

If the section only applied to future cases, it would have deprived people entitled to citizenship by descent under the previous version of the Citizenship Act merely because they were born before 1 January 2013.
xh.snippet: The Court had to determine whether section 2(1)(a) and (b) of the South African Citizenship Act 88 of 1995 (the “Citizenship Act”), as amended by the South African Citizenship Amendment Act 17 of 2010 (the “2010 Amendment”), was unconstitutional and invalid.
xh.title: Chisuse and Others v Director-General, Department of Home Affairs and Another [2020] ZACC 20; 2020 (10) BCLR 1173 (CC); 2020 (6) SA 14 (CC)

xh.facts_and_issues:
This case concerns the conflict between the constitutional right to adequate housing in terms of section 26(2) of the Constitution and a property owner’s right to develop private property. 86 indigent individuals were unlawfully occupying private unused industrial facilities as living quarters. The owner of the property (Blue Moonlight) approached the South Gauteng High Court, Johannesburg seeking an order to evict the occupiers in order to develop the property. The occupiers opposed the eviction on the basis that it would almost certainly render them homeless and argued that the City of Johannesburg (the City) had an obligation to provide them with temporary housing under the Constitution and the Prevention of Illegal Eviction and Unlawful Occupation of Land Act, 19 of 1998 (PIE) before they could be evicted.

The High Court granted the eviction order, but also ordered the City to remedy its housing policy as it was found to be unconstitutional and the High Court issued a structural interdict against the City obliging the City to report back to the High Court on the steps taken remedying its housing policy. The City was also ordered to provide temporary housing to the occupiers and to pay Blue Moonlight compensation until the eviction date. The City subsequently appealed the High Court’s order to the Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA). The SCA only set aside the structural interdict against the City and the High Court’s compensation order and declared the City’s housing policy unconstitutional to the extent that it excluded the occupiers from temporary housing and the City was ordered to provide them with “temporary emergency accommodation”. The City appealed the SCA’s order to the Constitutional Court.
xh.interpretation:
In a unanimous judgment by Van der Westhuizen J, the Court held that an owner's constitutional right not to be deprived of property must be interpreted in the social and historical context and be balanced against the right of access to adequate housing and not to be evicted arbitrarily from one's home. The Court emphasised that apartheid legislation undermined both the right of access to adequate housing and the right to property. Section 25 prohibits arbitrary deprivation of property, but also undertakes to redress unequal social conditions.

Section 26 of the Constitution “highlights the transformative vision of the Constitution” and PIE was enacted to specifically prevent the historical abuse of displacement of people. In this case, even though housing unlawful occupiers indefinitely suspends an owner's right to use and enjoy property, evictions can only be carried out in terms of PIE. PIE allows for the eviction of unlawful occupiers only in circumstances where such eviction is just and equitable.

In deciding whether an eviction is just and equitable in terms of PIE, the Court considered that many of the occupiers had lived on the property for a very long time, the occupation had once been lawful, Blue Moonlight was aware of the occupiers’ presence when it purchased the property, and the eviction of the occupiers would render them homeless while there was no competing risk of homelessness on the part of Blue Moonlight. Furthermore, the Court held that a key consideration was whether the City had made reasonable efforts to provide alternative accommodation to the occupiers. After considering the City’s housing policy, the Court noted that the policy differentiated between persons relocated by the City itself and those evicted by private landowners. However, where relocation was sought by the City, these persons were housed in temporary accommodation, which was not the case with persons evicted by private landowners.

The Court emphasised that section 26(2) of the Constitution recognises that the state is constrained by resources in giving effect to the right to adequate housing and therefore a housing policy may differentiate and give preference to categories of people; however any differentiation must be rational. The City’s housing policy was found to be “rigid”. The Court held that the policy failed to take into account whether emergency accommodation should be made available in individual cases, considering the categories of persons affected (such as elderly people and children) and their circumstances, and that an imminent eviction might render them homeless, regardless of whether the eviction or relocation is sought by the City or a private landowner. The Court held that this differentiation was not rational. Where an eviction may result in homelessness, it is irrelevant whether such eviction is at the instance of the City or a private landowner. The Court emphasised that this matter concerns “temporary” accommodation in an emergency as defined in Chapter 12 of the National Housing Code and not “permanent” housing. The obligation, while derived from the right to progressive realisation of adequate housing in terms of section 26(2) of the Constitution, is distinct from the obligation to address permanent housing needs.

The Court therefore declared the City’s housing policy unconstitutional and in violation of section 26 of the Constitution to the extent that it excluded people evicted by private landowners from its temporary housing programme. The Court dismissed the City’s appeal and held that the occupiers had to vacate the properties by a given date. The Court stipulated that the City was to provide the evictees with "temporary accommodation in a location as near as feasibly possible to the area" in which the building was situated, in order to ensure that the occupiers were not rendered homeless between the date of eviction and the date by which the City would have to provide emergency housing.
xh.right_and_principle: The Court considered whether the 86 occupiers must be evicted to allow the owner to fully exercise its rights regarding its property and, if so, whether their eviction must be linked to an order that the City provide them with accommodation. The City argued that it was neither obliged nor able to provide emergency accommodation in these circumstances and that its role in this regard was secondary. The City argued that local government does not have a primary role in fulfilling the right to access to adequate housing and that this mandate falls on the shoulders of the national and provincial government. The City argued that it fulfilled its duties after requesting assistance from provincial government and no more could be expected from it. The occupiers opposed the City’s appeal and also applied for a conditional cross-appeal requesting that an order of eviction be linked to the condition that suitable alternative accommodation be provided and that the City report back on steps taken to remedying its housing policy.
xh.snippet: The Court considered whether the 86 occupiers must be evicted to allow the owner to fully exercise its rights regarding its property and, if so, whether their eviction must be linked to an order that the City provide them with accommodation.
xh.title: City of Johannesburg Metropolitan Municipality v Blue Moonlight Properties 39 (Pty) Ltd and Another (CC) [2011] ZACC 33; 2012 (2) BCLR 150 (CC); 2012 (2) SA 104 (CC)

xh.facts_and_issues: The Premier of Mpumalanga, acting under section 121 of the Constitution, referred the Mpumalanga Petitions Bill to the Constitutional Court so they could decide on the constitutionality of the Bill because he had two reservations about its constitutionality.
xh.interpretation:
The Court found that it did not have jurisdiction to decide the first issue because the Premier had not followed the process set out for him in section 121 of the Constitution. This section required the Premier to send the Bill back to the legislature for reconsideration if he had issues with certain parts of the Bill before referring the matter to the Court. Thus, the question which was left open in the Liquor Bill case is now considered closed as the Court held that “no room exists, in referral proceedings under sections 79 and 121 of the Constitution, for a consideration by the Court of issues that have not been raised in compliance with the Constitution by the President or the Premier.”

Concerning the second issue, the Court found that the clauses conferring the power to the Speaker were not unconstitutional as the Speaker was well placed to make the regulations and to determine the date on which they came into force.

The legislature is permitted by the Constitution to appoint a functionary to determine when a law comes into force. The Court found that neither section 104 nor section 125 (which provide for the provincial legislative authority and provincial executive authority respectively) requires that legislative power be delegated to the members of the executive.

The functionary that is normally the best person to make this determination is the head of the executive. However, there is no provision in the Constitution that requires that this functionary be the President or Premier. The allocation of powers to the Speaker to determine the date of commencement of a Bill was also found to not implicate the doctrine of separation of powers.

Given all of the above, Clauses 18 and 19 of the Mpumalanga Petitions Bill 2000 were deemed constitutional.
xh.right_and_principle: The first issue that the Premier raised was whether the legislature was permitted by the Constitution to pass the Petitions Bill. The second issue was whether the legislature was allowed to give the provincial Speaker the power to make regulations and to determine the date upon which an Act comes into force.
xh.snippet: The first issue that the Premier raised was whether the legislature was permitted by the Constitution to pass the Petitions Bill. The second issue was whether the legislature was allowed to give the provincial Speaker the power to make regulations and to determine the date upon which an Act comes into force.
xh.title: Constitutionality of the Mpumalanga Petitions Bill, 2000 [2001] ZACC 10; 2002 (1) SA 447 (CC); 2001 (11) BCLR 1126

xh.facts_and_issues:
The applicant, Ms Daniels, resided in a dwelling on the farm Chardonne as a resident under the Extension of Security of Tenure Act (ESTA), owned by Chardonne Properties CC (the second respondent). The respondent, Mr Scribante managed the farm and under ESTA he was “the person in charge”. In an attempt to get rid of Ms Daniels from the farm, Mr Scribante removed or interfered with the door to Ms Daniels’s dwelling and cut the electricity supply. Ms Daniels obtained interim order from the Stellenbosch Magistrate’s Court for the restoration of her undisturbed occupation on the farm and required Mr Scribante to repair and replace the door and restore the electricity supply. Mr Scribante then ceased to maintain the dwelling. The dwelling required improvements which would enable it to be fit for human living. These included levelling the floors, paving part of the outside area and the installation of an indoor water supply, a wash basin, a second window and a ceiling. The applicant decided to carry out the improvements which she would pay from her own pocket. The respondents admitted the condition of the dwelling infringed upon Ms Daniels’s right to human dignity.

The applicant sent a letter to the first respondent informing him of the applicant’s intent to make improvements to the dwelling. The first respondent responded by sending a letter that refused to grant permission to make the improvements. The applicant then approached the Court seeking an order decalring that she was allowed to make improvements to her dwelling without the owner’s permission.
xh.interpretation:
The Court considered the application of section 8(2) of the Constitution which provides that a “provision of the Bill of Rights binds a natural or juristic person if, and to the extent that, it is applicable, taking into account the nature of the right and the nature of any duty imposed by the right”.

Madlanga J held that there was no basis to read the reference in section 8(2) to “the nature of the duty imposed by the right” to mean that if a right would result in imposing a positive obligation, that in no circumstances would it bind a natural or juristic person. Section 8(2) places “the nature of the duty” at the heart of the enquiry.

Although the right in this case was expanded on in ESTA, section 8(2) of the Constitution applied because the original source of the right was section 25(6) of the Constitution. The Court held that whether private persons will be bound by section 8(2) depends on a number of factors:

(i) What is the nature of the right? (Is the obligation positive or negative? That is, does the obligation require something to be done, or for the party to abstain from doing something?)

(ii) What is the history of the right?

(iii) What does the right seek to achieve?

(iv) How best can that be chieved?

(v) What is the “potential of invasion of that right by persons other than the State or organs of State?

(vi) Would letting private persons off the net not negate the essential content of the right?

Madlanga J stressed that after weighing up these factors one concludes that private persons are bound and must bear a positive obligation, then such an obligation must be imposed and section 8(2) does envisage that such obligation can be imposed. However, the Court recognised that private persons pay for their actions from their own pockets and that it would be unreasonable to require private persons to bear the exact same obligations as the State under the Bill of Rights.

Madlanga J stated that the Court had not on any previous occasion held that under no circumstances may private persons bear positive obligations under the Bill of Rights. The decisive question is whether private persons should be bound by the right in the Bill of Rights. In relation to security of tenure, the duty (both positive and negative) imposed by the right to security of tenure does in fact rest on private persons. People in need of protection under ESTA often reside on land owned by private persons, as in this case. The obligation resting on an owner is a positive one. A private party is required by section 25(6) of the Constitution through ESTA to accommodate another on their land. The obligation is also negative in that the occupier’s right should not be “improperly invaded”.

The Court held that Ms Daniels was entitled to make improvements to her dwelling and the parties were ordered to engage meaningfully regarding the implementation of the improvements.
xh.right_and_principle:
The main question was whether the Extension of Security of Tenure Act afforded residents the right to make improvements to their dwelling without the owner’s permission.

ESTA was promulgated under section 25(6) of the Constitution to afford security of tenure to persons who reside on land that they do not own. The respondents argued that if the Court concludes that an occupier is entitled to make improvements to bring the dwelling to a standard that is constitutionally compliant, it would be equal to indirectly placing an obligation on the owner or person in charge to ensure an occupier’s enjoyment of their right under section 25(6).
xh.snippet: The main question was whether the Extension of Security of Tenure Act afforded residents the right to make improvements to their dwelling without the owner’s permission.
xh.title: Daniels v Scribante and Another [2017] ZACC 13; 2017 (4) SA 341 (CC); 2017 (8) BCLR 949 (CC)

xh.facts_and_issues:
The matter was referred to the Constitutional Court to confirm a declaration of constitutional invalidity made by the Cape of Good Hope, High Court. The High Court declared section 66(3) of the Insolvency Act 24 of 1936 unconstitutional and invalid on the basis that it unjustifiably limited section 12(1)(b) of the Constitution. Section 66(3) of the Insolvency Act authorised a person presiding over a creditors' meeting, to commit a person to prison, if that person was summoned and refused to be sworn in, fail to produce any book or document which they were required to produce, or refuse to answer a question lawfully put to them.

The applicant was summoned in terms of the Insolvency Act to a meeting of creditors and was requested under section 64(3) of the Insolvency Act to produce certain books of account and financial record. On the day of his interrogation, the second, third and fourth respondents made an application for the issue of a warrant committing the applicant to prison under section 66(3) of the Insolvency Act on the grounds that he had been in breach of the provisions of the Act, failed to produce the books and documents and he had been summoned to produce and that he had failed to answer questions lawfully put to him under section 65(1) fully and satisfactorily. The application was postponed for argument and thereafter the presiding officer who was not a magistrate, issued a warrant committing the applicant to prison.
xh.interpretation:
