Parliament seeks to pass an amendment to the Electoral Act that will fix the problem of independent candidates not being able to be elected to the National Assembly and Provincial Legislatures. The issue must now be fixed by 10 December 2022.
zu.right_and_principle: This matter can be understood as the second part of a ‘two-part’ decision. The Constitutional Court had to consider whether to further suspend a declaration of constitutional invalidity of the Electoral Act (73 of 1998) for an additional six months, giving Parliament more time to amend the Electoral Act. Although the Court has decided that the Electoral Act is unconstitutional, it has suspended the declaration thereof giving Parliament the time to fix the problem as this is sometimes considered a more effective solution to an unconstitutional piece of legislation.
zu.snippet: This matter can be understood as the second part of a ‘two-part’ decision. The Constitutional Court had to consider whether to further suspend a declaration of constitutional invalidity of the Electoral Act 73 of 1998 for an additional six months, giving Parliament more time to amend the Electoral Act.
zu.title: Speaker of National Assembly and Another v New Nation Movement NPC and Others (CCT 110/19) [2022] ZACC 24

zu.facts_and_issues: The matter was referred to the Constitutional Court in terms of section 172(2) of the Constitution to confirm the declaration of constitutional invalidity of section 51(1) the Criminal Law Amendment Act 105 of 1997 made by the Eastern Cape High Court. Section 51(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, obliged a High Court to sentence people convicted of certain serious offences to life imprisonment, unless under section 51(3)(a) “substantial and compelling circumstances” justified the imposition of a lesser sentence. The Eastern Cape High Court declared the section to be constitutionally invalid on the basis that it was inconsistent with both section 35(3)(c) of the Constitution which made provisions for the right to be tried before an ordinary court and the constitutional doctrine of the separation of powers.
zu.interpretation:
On the question whether the doctrine of the separation of powers was infringed, the Court held that the legislature and the executive share interests in the punishment imposed by courts and that punishment was not at the exclusive discretion of the courts. Both the executive and the legislature share an interest in the nature and severity of punishment. It is the purview of the legislature to determine which acts should be criminalised and punished. The separation here was not absolute as this legislative function is checked by the courts to ensure its constitutional compliance. The executive had a duty to ensure that citizens are protected from persons who break the law. In order to carry out these obligations the executive and legislature must have the power under the Constitution to do so.

The powers of the legislature are not unlimited and the Court pointed out that legislation by its nature is general (and not specific to individual cases) and the power of the legislature should be balanced with that of the judiciary to apply and adapt a principle in an individual case. It would go against the rule of law to require the judiciary to impose a punishment which is out of proportion to the crime committed.

It was held that the legislature does not have the power to compel courts to impose sentences which are inconsistent with the Constitution. The Court held that section 51(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment does not oblige courts to impose a sentence which would limit an offender’s section 12(1)(e) constitutional right not to be treated in a cruel, inhuman or degrading way and therefore there was no infringement of the doctrine of separation of powers. The Court held further that there was no infringement of the rights contained in section 35(3)(c) of the Constitution and declined to confirm the order of invalidity by the Eastern Cape High Court.
zu.right_and_principle: The Court discussed the doctrine of separation of powers and explained that separation of powers under the Constitution is not absolutely strict and embodies a system of checks and balances with the aim of preventing an over-concentration of power in any one branch of government. Intrusion by one branch of government into the domain of another is unavoidable and necessitates a dialogue between the branches. Thus, there is no absolute separation between the judiciary and the legislature and executive.
zu.snippet: The applicants applied for confirmation of the constitutional invalidity of section 51(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 105 of 1997 by the Eastern Cape High Court under the provisions of section 172(2) of the Constitution. Challenge to section 51(1), read with section 51(3)(a) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, obliged High Courts to sentence people convicted of certain serious offences to life imprisonment, unless substantial and compelling circumstances justified the imposition of a lesser sentence.
zu.title: S v Dodo (CCT 1/01) [2001] ZACC 15

zu.facts_and_issues: The matter was heard by the Constitutional Court for confirmation of an order of constitutional invalidity made by the Pretoria High Court. The case concerned the constitutionality of the criminalisation of: (a) prostitution (carnal intercourse for reward); and (b) the keeping or managing of a brothel. Both forms of conduct were offences created in terms of the Sexual Offences Act 23 of 1957. The appellants (a brothel-owner, a brothel-employee and a sex worker) were convicted in the Magistrates’ Court for contravening the Sexual Offences Act. The appellants maintained that certain provisions of the Sexual Offences Act were unconstitutional. The High Court found section 20(1) (aA) of the Sexual Offences Act, which criminalised sex for reward, unconstitutional and invalid but dismissed the appellants’ appeal in respect of the provisions of the Sexual Offences Act which criminalised the keeping or managing of a brothel. The appellants appealed this part of the High Court’s order to the Constitutional Court and the State also opposed the confirmation of constitutional invalidity made by the High Court.
zu.interpretation:
The majority judgment penned by Ngcobo J in the Constitutional Court, firstly held that this matter should have been decided in terms of the Interim Constitution.[The decision and the analysis of the Court still remain relevant].

In relation to the challenge to section 26 of the Interim Constitution, the majority held that the two subsections must be read together to determine if there was an infringement on the right. Section 26(1) of the Interim Constitution guaranteed every person “the right to freely engage in economic activity and to pursue a livelihood in the national territory”. Section 26(2) held that this does not preclude the designing of measures “to promote the protection or the improvement of the quality of life, economic growth, human development, social justice, basic conditions of employment, fair labour practices or equal opportunity for all, provided such measures are justifiable in an open and democratic society based on freedom and equality”.

The Court emphasised that section 26(2) requires there to be a rational connection between the law and the purpose for which it was enacted and if the purpose is sanctioned by subsection 2, the second question is whether it is justifiable in an open and democratic society based on freedom and equality. In this matter the Court held that the legislature was mandated to “combat social ills” and the means chosen to regulate this fell within the scope of Parliament. Parliament had a wide discretion in choosing how to combat social problems, including through the creation of new offences. Furthermore, the courts must give effect to legislative choices made by Parliament except where the choices are not in line with the Constitution. The Court emphasised that it cannot declare legislation invalid merely because it views it as ineffective or because there were better means of addressing the problem. The majority held that sex work and brothel keeping were not protected by section 26 of the Interim Constitution.

The minority judgment by O’Regan J and Sachs J, acknowledged that the challenges to section 26 of the Interim Constitution provides two possible interpretations. One interpretation is that it only relates to lawful economic activity; the other is that it relates to all forms of economic activity. However, the minority recognised that the question whether the right could be claimed only if it related to lawful economic activity did not need to be resolved at this time.

In relation to the other constitutional challenges raised, the majority and minority judgments agreed that the appeal against the High Court’s order concerning brothels should be dismissed. The majority held that section 20(1)(aA) was not unconstitutional and did not confirm the High Court’s order of constitutional invalidity and that sex work did not unfairly discriminate on the basis of gender. The minority agreed that criminalisation of sex work did not infringe the rights to human dignity and economic activity, and that any limitation on privacy was reasonably justifiable. However, the minority judgement found that the criminalisation of sex work reinforces double standards and gender stereotypes by making patrons accomplices to the crime at most and in contrast, making the sex worker the primary offender and this constituted unfair discrimination
zu.right_and_principle:
Various constitutional challenges were raised against the Sexual Offences Act. It was argued that the provisions infringed on the rights to equality, freedom and security of person, dignity and the right to economic activity in terms of section 26 of the Interim Constitution.

Section 26 of the Interim Constitution which provided for the right to economic activity corresponds largely with section 22 of the 1996 Constitution which guarantees the right to freedom of trade, occupation and profession.
zu.snippet: Various constitutional challenges were raised against the Sexual Offences Act. It was argued that the provisions infringed on the rights to equality, freedom and security of person, dignity and the right to economic activity in terms of section 26 of the Interim Constitution.
zu.title: S v Jordan and Others (Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Task Force and Others as Amici Curiae (CCT 31/01) [2002] ZACC 22

zu.facts_and_issues: In the High Court, the applicants filed an application to challenge the constitutionality of sections 15 and 16 of the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences and Related Matters) Amendment Act 32 of 2007 (the Act). They argued it was unconstitutional to the extent that it criminalized consensual sexual conduct between children. The North Gauteng High Court declared the relevant sections unconstitutional and therefore invalid. An application for confirmation of invalidity was launched before the Constitutional Court.
zu.interpretation:
The Court held that in respect of whether the criminalization of consensual sexual conduct between children violated section 28 of the Constitution, it was necessary to firstly determine the scope of section 28.

The Court held that section 28(2) of the Constitution fulfils at least two separate roles. First, it is as a guiding principle in each case that deals with a particular child. Secondly, it is a standard against which to test provisions or conduct which affect children in general. The Court added that the best-interests principle is not only limited to scenarios where legislation is inflexible, the principle also applies in circumstances where a statutory provision is shown to be against the best interests of children in general, for whatever reason. As a matter of logic what is bad for all children will be bad for one child in a particular case. Thus, if there is evidence that exposing children to the criminal justice system for engaging in consensual sexual behaviour has a negative impact on them generally, then a Court may declare the scheme to be contrary to the best interests of the child in terms of section 28(2), and therefore invalid.

Therefore, section 28 is both a self-standing right and a guiding principle in respect of all matters affecting the child. What is in the best interests of the child in each case will require a consideration of various factors. Further, it is not necessary that the specific interests of the child in the case before the court are affected, but rather whether the interests of children in general are affected. Legislation would be inconsistent with this right if it is demonstrated to be against the interests of children in general.

In a unanimous judgment, the Constitutional Court found that sections 15 and 16 of the Act were unconstitutional in that they infringed the rights of adolescents (12- to 16-year olds) to dignity and privacy, and further in that they violated the best-interests principle contained in section 28(2) of the Constitution. The Court held that the sections infringed the best-interests principle in many ways. Most importantly, the offences created by the provisions ran the risk of exposing children to the harmful effects of the criminal justice system and could undermine support structures by deterring adolescents from seeking help and could create a breakdown in parental care.

 

Relying on expert evidence, the Court concluded that the provisions criminalized what constituted developmentally normal conduct for adolescents, and adversely affected the very children the Act sought to protect. The effects of the provisions were found not to be rationally related to the State’s purpose of protecting children. The Court then found that the infringement of the best-interests principle cannot be justified in terms of section 36 of the Constitution as was no evidence that criminalising such consensual sexual behaviour would deter adolescents from engaging in it.

Therefore, the Constitutional Court declared the sections 15 and 16 of the Act invalid to the extent that they criminalized consensual sexual conduct between adolescents.

 

The Constitutional Court suspended the declaration of invalidity for 18 months to allow Parliament to amend the provisions. The Court further ordered a suspension on all investigations, arrests, prosecutions and criminal and ancillary proceedings (regarding adolescents) in relation to sections 15 and 16 of the Act, until Parliament remedied the defects identified. Finally, the Minister was ordered to take the necessary steps to ensure that the details of any adolescent convicted of an offence in terms of sections 15 or 16 of the Act will not appear in the National Register for Sex Offenders and that such an adolescent will have his or her criminal record removed.
zu.right_and_principle: The applicants argued at the Constitutional Court that sections 15 and 16 of the Act unjustifiably infringe children’s constitutional rights to dignity, privacy and bodily and psychological integrity, as well as the principle in section 28(2) of the Constitution that a child's best interests must be of paramount importance in all matters concerning the child. The respondents argued that the sections do not infringe the constitutional rights of children and are rationally related to the legitimate government purpose of protecting children from the risks associated with engaging in sexual activity
zu.snippet: The applicants argued at the Constitutional Court that sections 15 and 16 of the Act unjustifiably infringe children’s constitutional rights to dignity, privacy and bodily and psychological integrity, as well as the principle in section 28(2) of the Constitution that a child's best interests must be of paramount importance in all matters concerning the child.
zu.title: Teddy Bear Clinic for Abused Children and Another v Minister of Justice and Constitutional Development and Another (CCT 12/13) [2013] ZACC 35

zu.facts_and_issues:
The respondent (Mr McBride) worked as an operative of the armed wing of the political party, the African National Congress (Umkhonto we Sizwe) and he had been convicted for his role in carrying out a car bomb attack in 1986 that killed three people and injured 69 others. The respondent was found guilty of multiple murders and was sentenced to death. In 1997 he applied for amnesty under the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act 34 of 1995 and amnesty was granted to him in 2001.

In 2003 the respondent was a candidate for the position of Ekurhuleni Metro Police Chief. The appellant (The Citizen) in September and October 2003 published various articles and editorials questioning the respondent’s candidacy and expressed the view that he was a “criminal” and “murderer”. Some of the articles failed to mention that the respondent was granted amnesty by the National Truth and Reconciliation Commission and the respondent sued the appellant and other journalists for defamation in the Witwatersrand Local Division (South Gauteng High Court, Johannesburg), arguing that the articles impaired his dignity by labeling him a “criminal” and a “murderer” when he he was granted amnesty for these crimes.
zu.interpretation:
The majority held that amnesty granted in terms of the Act did not make the fact that the respondent committed murder untrue and the Act did not prohibit frank public discussion. The court affirmed that one can defend a claim of defamation if they can convince the court that the comment was ‘fair’. The majority emphasised that ”fair” means that “criticism is protected even if extreme, unjust, unbalanced, exaggerated and prejudiced, so long as it expresses an honestly-held opinion, without malice, on a matter of public interest on facts that are true”. The Constitutional Court therefore found in favor of the appellant (The Citizen) regarding calling Mr McBride a criminal and murderer. In addition, the Court found that the appellant had defamed the respondent by claiming falsely that he was not remorseful for his actions and awarded the respondent damages on this aspect.

As the matter essentially concerned a defamation claim and the defences raised thereto, a key issue the Constitutional Court had to decide was, how to find a balance between two constitutional rights, namely The Citizen’s right to freedom of expression, on the one hand, and Mr McBride’s right to human dignity on the other. The majority emphasised that the right to human dignity is not only given separate constitutional recognition in section 10 of the Constitution but is also one of the founding values of the Constitution in section 1. Therefore, a failure to uphold the right is not only a violation of section 10 but is also a threat to a founding value underpinning the legitimacy of the State. The majority stated that freedom of expression is just as important as human dignity and one cannot say that human dignity trumps freedom of expression. Therefore, the Court held that the law of defamation must be interpreted to give effect to the appropriate balance between the right to freedom of expression, on the one hand, and a person’s human dignity on the other. The Court held on this interpretation that the requirement that a comment must be “fair” in defence to a claim for defamation gives effect to the balance between the right to freedom of expression and dignity.
zu.right_and_principle: The key issue the Constitutional Court had to determine was how amnesty granted to the respondent for crimes committed during the struggle against apartheid by the National Truth and Reconciliation Commission affected a claim for defamation. The respondent was granted amnesty in terms of the Promotion of National Unity and Reconciliation Act for crimes committed in 1986.
zu.snippet: The key issue the Constitutional Court had to determine was how amnesty granted to the respondent for crimes committed (during the struggle against apartheid) by the National Truth and Reconciliation Commission affected a claim for defamation.
zu.title: The Citizen 1978 (Pty) Ltd and Others v McBride (CCT 23/10) [2011] ZACC 11

zu.facts_and_issues:
The applicants approached the Constitutional Court for an order setting aside the orders made by the Supreme Court of Appeal in two connected matters relating to the validity and the lawfulness in the execution of warrants for search and seizure issued in terms of section 29 of the National Prosecuting Authority Act 32 of 1998 (NPA Act). The applicant in the first application was Thint (Pty) Ltd (a company which was initially indicted with Mr Shaik and his companies in relation to fraud and corruption charges) and the applicants in the second matter were Mr Zuma and his personal attorney, Mr Hulley. In 2005, the National Director of Public Prosecutions (NDPP) decided to prosecute Mr Zuma for corruption offences (which related to Mr Shaik and his companies) and other fraud and tax offences. During August and September 2005 various search and seizure operations were conducted at the offices of Thint, Mr Hulley and at the residences and the former offices of Mr Zuma on the basis of search and seizure warrants issued in terms of section 29(5) and 25(6) of the NPA Act.

In the application for the search and seizure warrants, the investigating director held that the element of surprise was necessary to ensure that no evidence would be destroyed on the premises. Mr Zuma challenged and Mr Hulley challenged the lawfulness of various warrants in the Durban High Court and held that the prosecution failed to show the need for the search and seizure, the warrants failed to provide sufficient detail relating to the offences and attorney-client privilege was potentially violated during the search and seize operations. The High Court declared five warrants invalid and the NDPP was ordered to return the items seized. Thint launched a similar challenge in the Pretoria High Court but was unsuccessful. The State and Tint appealed the High Court orders to the SCA which respectively set aside the order in the Mr Zuma and Mr Hulley matter and confirmed the Thint High Court order in a separate judgment. Following the SCA orders Mr Zuma, Mr Hulley and Thint applied for leave to appeal to the Constitutional Court.
zu.interpretation:
Then the Court considered whether the warrants’ terms or their execution provided insufficient protection for the applicants’ legal professional privilege. It was held that there was no statutory or constitutional requirement for the warrants to have referred expressly to section 29(11) of the NPA Act, which provides a mechanism for the speedy resolution of claims of privilege made during a search.

Furthermore, it was held that there was nothing untoward in the manner of the state’s execution of the warrants, and specifically that the search at Mr Hulley’s offices was carried out lawfully. None of the applicants made any claim of privilege during the searches. Moreover, since those searches, the applicants have failed to claim privilege in respect of any particular item or document seized, despite having had adequate time to do so. It was held that in the absence of any evidence of actual prejudice to them, the appalicants’ argument relating to legal professional privilege had to be dismissed. The majority therefore found the section 35(3) had not been breached. The applicants’ case was dismissed and the SCA’s order was upheld.
zu.right_and_principle: The applicants raised various constitutional challenges in their application for leave to appeal which included the assertion that Mr Zuma’s rights to a fair trial in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution had been threatened because the warrants did not sufficiently protect his legal professional privilege during the search of Mr Hulley’s office.
zu.snippet: In this case, it was argued that Mr Zuma’s right to a fair trial in terms of section 35(3) of the Constitution had been threatened because the warrants did not sufficiently protect his legal professional privilege.
zu.title: Thint (Pty) Ltd v National Director of Public Prosecutions and Others; Zuma and Another v NDPP and Others (CCT 89/07) [2008] ZACC 13

zu.facts_and_issues: The applicants were 133 residents of Winne Mandela informal settlement in Tembisa and a voluntary organisation supporting the residents. The residents were given a state housing subsidy that granted them ownership of a stand and the house to be constructed on it. This plan was not followed through and the applicants, some waiting for more than two decades, discovered that the Municipality had unlawfully given the stands and houses promised to them to other residents of the informal settlement instead. The matter was heard by the High Court (which found in favour of the residents), then by the Supreme Court of Appeal (which merely extended the period within which the Municipality had to provide the land and houses). The Municipality then applied to the High Court to have that period further extended. The residents sought constitutional damages from the High Court and, after that failed, they sought the same from the Constitutional Court.
zu.interpretation:
First, the Court considered an application for direct leave to appeal for constitutional damages, which determines whether the court will hear the matter or not. Direct leave to appeal means that, instead of going from the High Court to the Supreme Court of Appeal and then to the Constitutional Court, as is the normal process, the applicants could go straight to the Constitutional Court to ask for constitutional damages. This happens mainly when the matter is urgent or is in the public interest. The Constitutional Court granted direct leave to appeal, meaning that they heard the matter even though it hadn't followed the normal pathway through the courts.

The respondents were allowed to present additional evidence that wasn’t initially submitted before the High Court. The respondents wanted to present evidence relating to events that occurred after the most recent High Court judgment on the matter (referred to as Thubakgale III) and which they argued was relevant to the current case. The Constitutional Court agreed and allowed additional evidence to be heard.

The Constitutional Court did not agree that constitutional damages were appropriate and dismissed the appeal.
zu.right_and_principle: This case was about whether awarding constitutional damages was the appropriate relief for the infringement of a socio-economic right (in this case, the right of access to housing). Constitutional damages are a special kind of remedy in terms of which the Court can order the State to pay damages for violating constitutional rights.
zu.snippet: This case was about whether awarding constitutional damages was the appropriate relief for the infringement of a socio-economic right.
zu.title: Thubakgale and Others v Ekurhuleni Metropolitan Municipality and Others [2021] ZACC 45

zu.facts_and_issues: Four communities whose land rights were affected by the Communal Land Rights Act [No. 11 of 2004] (CLARA) had mounted a two-pronged constitutional challenge to this legislation in the North Gauteng High Court, Pretoria. One part was challenging CLARA on the ground that its provisions undermined security of tenure. The other part was contending that the way CLARA was enacted was incorrect. The substantive challenge was partially successful, and the High Court declared certain provisions of CLARA invalid. Although it found that Parliament should have followed the procedure for the passing of Bills affecting the provinces prescribed by Section 76, it did not grant relief on that account because Parliament had committed an error in good faith and did not intend to suppress the views of the provinces. It accordingly dismissed this part of the application. The High Court referred the order of invalidity to the Constitutional Court for confirmation. In the Constitutional Court, the applicants sought confirmation of the order of invalidity and sought leave to appeal against the dismissal of their application to have CLARA declared entirely unconstitutional because of Parliament’s failure to enact it according to the procedure in Section 76. The applicants also asked for direct access to the Constitutional Court and an order declaring CLARA constitutionally invalid on the ground that Parliament failed to comply with its constitutional obligations to facilitate public involvement in the legislative process in terms of Sections 59(1)(a) and 72(1)(a) of the Constitution.
zu.interpretation: The judgment of the High Court was set aside and replaced by a new one from the Constitutional Court. The new order was that the whole of the Communal Land Rights Act (CLARA) was invalid because this legislation did not satisfy the requirements of Section 76 of the Constitution.
zu.right_and_principle:
The Constitutional Court needed to resolve the following major questions:
(a) Did Parliament follow the correct procedure in enacting CLARA?
(b) Did Parliament comply with its constitutional obligation to facilitate public involvement in the legislative process in enacting CLARA?
(c) Should the order of invalidity be confirmed?
(d) What relief, if any, were the applicant communities entitled to?
zu.snippet: This case concerned whether Parliament had followed the correct legal process in enacting the Communal Land Rights Act [No. 11 of 2004] (CLARA).
zu.title: Tongoane and Others v National Minister for Agriculture and Land Affairs and Others (CCT 100 of 2009) [2010] ZACC 10

zu.facts_and_issues:
The applicants applied to the Constitutional Court for leave to appeal a judgment made by the Pretoria High Court relating to the rights of refugees to work in the private security industry in South Africa. The Private Security Industry Regulation Act 56 of 2001(“the Security Act”) required security service providers to register with the Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority (“the Authority”). Section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act listed citizenship or permanent residence as a requirement for registration. Despite the provisions of section 23(1)(a), section 23(6) granted the Authority the decision to register any applicant as a security service provider, on good cause shown and on grounds which are not in conflict with the purpose of the Security Act and the objects of the Authority.

All of the applicants, except for the first applicant, applied to the Authority to be registered as security service providers in terms of the Security Act and were initially registered. However, the second to sixth applicants subsequently received a notice from the Authority that they intended to withdraw their registration as they were not citizens or permanent residents. The Authority allowed the second to sixth applicants to make written representation as to why they should be registered despite these requirements. However, after considering their written submissions, the Authority denied their applications and withdrew their registration. Some applicants also appealed to the Appeal Committee, which dismissed the appeal.
zu.interpretation:
The majority judgment written by Kondile AJ turned its attention to the constitutionality of section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act. Kondile AJ, writing for the majority, started the equality analysis by firstly considering, whether the provision differentiated between categories of people and if there was such differentiation whether there was a legitimate rationale for such differentiation. During this first leg of the analysis, looking at the rational connection between the provision and its purpose, the Court emphasised that the private security industry was a special environment and at stake was the safety and security of the public at large. Section 12 of the Constitution provides everyone with the right to freedom and security of the person, which includes the right to be free from all forms of violence from either public or private sources. In a society rife with violent crime, the importance of protecting this right could not be exaggerated.

The majority judgment held that the regulatory scheme was carefully designed for the purpose of screening entrants to the private security industry rather than constituting a blanket ban on the registration of refugees as private security service providers. That is not to say that foreign nationals, including refugees, are inherently less trustworthy than South Africans. In a country where xenophobia has caused increased suffering, it was important to stress this and explain that it was not that the Authority did not trust refugees. The Security Act was designed to limit eligibility for registration to people whose trustworthiness could be objectively verified, and it was easier to verify the trustworthiness of citizens and permanent residents. The preamble to the Act acknowledges that the right to security of the person is fundamental to the well-being and to the social and economic development of every person. The Court therefore held that the differentiation between citizens and permanent residents on one hand and other foreigners in this instance, was rational and served a legitimate government purpose.

On establishing differentiation, the majority judgment then considered whether the differentiation amounted to discrimination. The Court held that in this instance, the differentiation was on grounds analogous to those listed in section 9(3) of the Constitution, and therefore constituted discrimination. The analysis then turned to whether the discrimination was unfair. Various factors were considered by the Court on the question of fairness, such as the fact that while refugees were fully entitled to work in South Africa, section 22 of the Constitution limited the right to choose a job to citizens only. The Court also considered that refugees could be registered as security service providers if the requirements of section 23(6) of the Security Act were met and that there was no complete exclusion of refugees from being registered. The majority found that section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act did not unfairly discriminate against the applicants and was therefore constitutionally sound.

In their dissenting judgment, Mokgoro J and O'Regan J held that section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act discriminated unfairly on the basis of refugee status. The joint dissenting judgment was not convinced that the purpose identified by the Minister to ensure that security service employees were trustworthy was really intended by the section. The dissenting judgment stated that the order it would have proposed was to require that refugees who could meet the other requirements of the Security Act should not be barred from registration as security service providers. Those refugees who could not meet those requirements should seek to establish that “good cause” exists for them to be registered as contemplated by section 23(6) of the Security Act.
zu.right_and_principle:
The applicants applied to the High Court to review and set aside the decisions of the Authority and the Appeal Committee and in the alternative they sought to declare section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act inconsistent with the Constitution on the basis that it violated the right to equality in section 9 of the Constitution as it unfairly discriminated against the applicants due to their refugee status. The High Court agreed that section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act afforded permanent residents and citizens preferential treatment, but the Court found the provision to be constitutionally compliant if read in conjunction with other provisions and taking into account the purpose of the provision.

The Constitutional Court had to determine whether the Authority’s refusal to register the applicants as security service providers, on the basis that they are neither permanent residents nor citizens, was justified and whether section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act to the extent it excluded refugees from its scope constituted unfair discrimination in violation of section 9 of the Constitution.
zu.snippet: The Constitutional Court had to determine whether the Authority’s refusal to register the applicants as security service providers, on the basis that they are neither permanent residents nor citizens, was justified and whether section 23(1)(a) of the Security Act to the extent it excluded refugees from its scope constituted unfair discrimination in violation of section 9 of the Constitution.
zu.title: Union of Refugee Women and Others v Director, Private Security Industry Regulatory Authority and Others (CCT 39/06) [2006] ZACC 23

zu.facts_and_issues: The matter was referred to the Constitutional Court to confirm an order of constitutional invalidity made by the Western Cape Division of the High Court and an appeal was made against certain parts of the High Court’s order. The second to sixteenth applicants in the matter were all clients of the Stellenbosch Law Clinic and had emoluments attachment orders issued against them by clerks of the court employed in various Magistrates’ offices. The clients had approached a company known as SA Multiloan in Stellenbosch for small loans. Later when they fell into arrears, the creditor provider demanded that they sign further documents which resulted in default judgments and emoluments attachment orders obtained by the credit providers. This allowed for the automatic deduction of the judgment debt from their salaries or wages.
zu.interpretation:
The majority judgment, written by Cameron J, held that it was not possible to interpret section 65J of the Magistrates Courts Act as incorporating judicial oversight (as argued by Jafta J in his minority judgment). The majority held that section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act allows the issuing of an emolument’s attachment order where the debtor consents in writing; or if ‘the court has so authorised’. The majority reasoned that the conjunction ‘or’ makes it clear that an emoluments attachment order may be obtained through the debtor’s written consent even when a court has not authorised it.

Consequently, a debtor’s section 34 right of access to court is infringed by such an execution process not sanctioned by a court.

Additionally, the majority explained that section 65J(1) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act sets the scene for section 65J(2) and contemplates that a judgment creditor, not a court, causes an emoluments attachment order to be issued from a court. Once issued, section 65J(5) provides that the order may be executed ‘as if it were a court judgment’. The majority viewed this wording as demonstrating that the section permits execution without judicial oversight. The majority judgment concluded that the language of the provision clearly shows that it permitted judicially unsanctioned enforcement of judgment debts and was therefore unconstitutional, holding that a debtor’s section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any form of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court. The majority confirmed the High Court’s declaration of constitutional invalidity of certain words in section 65J(2).
zu.right_and_principle:
The issue was whether a debtor's section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any type of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court.

The applicants approached the Law Clinic to institute proceedings in the High Court to have the emoluments attachments orders set aside. The Law Clinic challenged the constitutional validity of section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 32 of 1944. The Law Clinic argued that section 65J(2) of the Magistrate’s Court Act allowed for emoluments attachment orders to be obtained without judicial oversight. The High Court agreed and declared certain words in section 65J(2) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act unconstitutional to the extent that it failed to provide for judicial oversight over the issuing of an emoluments attachment order against a judgment debtor. The High Court also declared that section 45 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act does not permit a debtor to consent in writing to the jurisdiction of a magistrates’ court other than that in which that debtor resides or is employed.
zu.snippet: The issue was whether a debtor's section 34 right of access to court is breached when an execution process against any type of property occurs without judicial oversight by a court.
zu.title: University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others v Minister of Justice and Correctional Services and Others; Association of Debt Recovery Agents NPC v University of Stellenbosch Legal Aid Clinic and Others (CCT 127/15) [2016] ZACC 32

zu.facts_and_issues:
Mr Jacobs was in a motor vehicle accident and suffered severe head injuries that impaired his mental capacity. Seven years after the accident, Mr Jacobs had been placed under curatorship, and the curator of Mr Jacobs instituted an action on his behalf against the Road Accident Fund (RAF) for payment of damages. Both the High Court and Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) dismissed the action, because it was filed after the prescribed time period in the RAF Act had already lapsed. Section 23(1) of the RAF Act stated that this type of action must be filed within 3 years of the accident. This was an appeal to the Constitutional Court against the decision of the SCA.
The court looked at sections 23 (2)(b) and (c) of the Road Accident Fund Act, as well as section 13(1)(a) of the Prescription Act, to determine whether:
(i) the RAF Act, the Prescription Act and mental health legislation should be read together;
(ii) the RAF Act limits the right to access the court, and if so, whether the limitation was reasonable; and
(iii) the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
zu.interpretation:
The court read together the provisions in the RAF Act, the Prescription Act and mental health legislation. The majority of the court found that the applicant was not protected against the 3-year prescription time for compensation claims since he was placed under curatorship after the expiry of the prescribed time. 

The court held that the prescription time, which limits the right to access courts in the RAF Act, was not reasonable for as long as a person remains mentally impaired. The court noted that sections 9(1) and 233 of the Constitution required it to interpret the provisions of RAF and the Prescription Act in a manner that is consistent with international law and the right to equal protection under the law. Consequently, the 3-year prescription time in the RAF Act would not be applicable to Mr Jacobs for as long as he remained mentally impaired.

The court upheld the appeal and dismissed the special plea of prescription.
zu.right_and_principle: The right to equality in terms of s 9 of the Constitution was implicated. The Court had to determine whether the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
zu.snippet: The court had to determine whether the RAF Act discriminated against persons who are mentally impaired, and are not detained under the Prescription Act or placed under curatorship.
zu.title: Van Zyl N.O. v Road Accident Fund [2021] ZACC 44

zu.facts_and_issues:
The Applicant, together with the three intervening parties, are provincial governments constitutionally tasked with implementing provincial legislation. However, there was relic law from the apartheid era, Proclamation R293 of 1962, issued in terms of the Administration Act of 1927. This Proclamation governed the setting-up of special African townships by the Minister of Bantu Administration and Development in areas under the African Native Trust. This Proclamation was one of the tools with which the apartheid state disposed Africans from landholding and created barriers to Africans owning any land. Instead, Africans could only hold rights to the lands through an insecure tenure system of Deeds of Grant and Certificates of Occupancy and letting for residential purposes. The township manager had the authority to cancel this tenure at any point. Special deeds registries were created to register the deeds of grant under the legislation.

When South Africa transitioned to democratic majority rule, the President, empowered by the Interim Constitution, passed Proclamation R9 of 1997 together with amendments to the Deeds Registry Act. The impact of these changes was to regularise and create a more uniform approach to registration of titles in immovable property. The President also delegated certain legislative competencies to the provincial legislations to ensure multi-level governance. 
Consequently, the North West passed the North West Act 7 which supposedly repealed the whole of Proclamation R293. Similar to other provincial governments, it considered the Proclamation to be unconstitutional. 

DVB Behuising (Pty) Ltd was aggrieved by the North West’s decision and applied to the High Court for an order upholding the constitutionality of the provision. It also argued that the repeal had a negative impact on its property business since its clients were left with an insecure form of land tenure. This order was granted at the High Court, and was the subject of the current appeal.
zu.interpretation:
The action by the North West Government to revoke regulations 1 and 3 of Proclamation R293 was of no force or consequence. This was because the Constitution did not grant provincial governments the competence to make laws involving the registration of deeds of grant. The revocation was therefore not authorised by the Constitution.
Parliament should properly consider the issue of legislative competency of the provincial legislatures and governments with regard to land tenure and security of property rights. It is important for there to be a clear demarcation of what the provincial governments are allowed to legislate about within the sole limits of their jurisdiction and those issues that can only be legislated at a national level.
Parliament will also need to carefully consider the issue of competency by assignment through secondary legislation. In a society where the Constitution is the supreme law of the land, the authority for provinces to make legislation should be derived directly from the Constitution and not an executive Proclamation.
zu.right_and_principle:
The main issue before the court was whether the Proclamation was in line with the values and provisions of the Interim Constitution. 

The court also had to consider whether provincial governments had the authority to legislate on deeds registration.
zu.snippet: The court had to decide whether the Constitution allowed provincial governments the authority to legislate on registration of titles in immovable property.
zu.title: Western Cape Provincial Government and Others; In Re: DVB Behuising (Pty) Limited v North West Provincial Government and Another (CCT 22/99) [2000] ZACC 2

zu.facts_and_issues:
The Women’s Legal Centre (WLC) brought this action, arguing that the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act were inconsistent with the Constitution. These two laws failed to recognize Muslim marriages, and were therefore infringing on the fundamental rights of parties to Muslim marriages, especially Muslim women, and any children born of Muslim marriages. The WLC argued that the Acts specifically violated the rights to equality, dignity, and access to courts, and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount in every issue involving a child (sections 9, 10, 28 and 34 of the Constitution). The Supreme Court of Appeal (SCA) agreed with the WLC and held that these Acts were constitutionally invalid, and the WLC then applied to the Constitutional Court to confirm the SCA’s order.
If the application was not successful, the applicants asked the court to confirm the order of the High Court, which required the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
zu.interpretation:
The court determined three main issues:
(i) whether the SCA’s order of constitutional invalidity should be confirmed;
(ii) if the order was confirmed, whether it should have retrospective effect as ordered by the Supreme Court of Appeal (meaning that the Acts are regarded as always having been unconstitutional); and
(iii) whether to confirm the order of the High Court which required the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
The Constitutional Court conducted a thorough investigation and held that the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act were indeed inconsistent with the Constitution, even though the confirmation proceedings were not opposed.
The Court found that the laws unjustly discriminated against spouses in Muslim marriages and children born out of such marriages, based on their gender, religion and marital status. The court noted that there was no justification for the discrimination. Further, the Court held that it can reasonably be assumed that, where there is unfair discrimination, the right to human dignity is also violated, unless the opposite is proved.
The court held that the laws also unjustifiably violated the right of access to courts and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount. 
On the issue of retrospectivity, the court supported limited retrospectivity of the order, to ensure that other interested parties were adequately notified of the legal consequences of this order, going forward. 
Finally, the court found that the applicants had failed to establish an obligation on the State to enact legislation to recognise Muslim marriages and to regulate the consequences of such recognition.
Parliament was ordered by the court to remedy the defects identified in the Divorce Act and Marriage Act by either amending existing legislation, or making and passing new legislation by 28 June 2024, in order to ensure the recognition of Muslim marriages as valid marriages for all purposes in South Africa and to regulate the consequences arising from such recognition. It should also consider making amendments to other laws to ensure a balance of the right to freedom of religion, family life and protection of children with other constitutional rights.
zu.right_and_principle: The rights implicated are the rights to equality, dignity, and access to courts, and the principle of the best interests of the child being paramount in every issue involving a child (sections 9, 10, 28 and 34 of the Constitution).
zu.snippet: This case concerned the constitutionality of the Marriage Act and the Divorce Act, which failed to recognise Muslim marriages.
zu.title: Women's Legal Centre Trust v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others (CCT 24/21) [2022] ZACC 23

zu.facts_and_issues: After a long history of litigation between the parties, the Applicant (Mr Zuma) had disobeyed an order of the Constitutional Court to appear before a commission of enquiry on State Capture. As a result, contempt of court proceedings were launched, but Mr Zuma refused to participate, and the Court granted a judgment and order for his arrest for contempt of court. This judgment sentenced the Applicant to 15 months of imprisonment. It is this judgment and order that the Applicant is seeking to have rescinded.
zu.interpretation: The court stated that the matter could be heard directly at the Constitutional Court without having first being head in a lower court. The judgment and order sentencing the Applicant for contempt of court continues to stand.
zu.right_and_principle:
The main legal question before the Court was whether the Applicant’s application met the requirements for rescission in rule 42 (1(a) of the Uniform Rules of Court. This rule requires that the following conditions be met:
(a) that the party was unaware of the proceedings before the court, or
(b) that the party was precluded from participating in the proceedings, and
(c) that the judgment was erroneously sought or granted by the court.
The Court also had to consider whether the requirements for rescission according to the common law were met.
zu.snippet: This case was about Mr Jacob Zuma disobeying an order of the Constitutional Court to appear before a commission of enquiry on State Capture, and the resulting contempt of court proceedings.
zu.title: Zuma v Secretary of Judicial Commission of Inquiry into Allegations of State Capture, Corruption and Fraud in Public Sector Including Organs of State and Others (CCT 52 of 2021) [2021] ZACC 28

af.interpretation:
These institutions in terms of section 181 of the Constitution are independent and are “subject only to the Constitution and the law”. It is critical to emphasise this provision. The Constitutional Court has emphasised that the Public Protector in fulfilling her mandate is “not supposed to bow down to anybody, not even at the door of the highest chambers of raw State power”.

These institutions are obligated in terms of section 181(2) of the Constitution to be impartial and to “exercise their functions without fear, favour or prejudice” and no “person or organ of state may interfere with the functioning of these institutions.” It is also important to note that these institutions only account to the National Assembly on their activities and performance. The remaining provisions of Chapter 9 of the Constitution provides for the functions of each of these institutions, their tenure and removal from office.
af.mechanism: The Public Protector and Auditor-General in specific are watchdogs over the State and are critical in the fight against corruption and enforcing accountability. The South African Human Rights Commission is mandated to monitor the observance of human rights and take action where human rights have been violated. The Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities has various powers including investigating matters concerning the rights of cultural, religious communities and the Commission for Gender Equality also has extensive power including the power to lobby and investigate issues relating to gender equality. The Electoral Commission is mandated to manage the elections of the national, provincial and municipal legislative bodies.
af.snippet: Provides for the establishment of independent State institutions strengthening constitutional democracy.
af.title: Chapter 9 Institutions
af.topic_meaning: Chapter 9 of the Constitution provides for the establishment of independent State institutions strengthening constitutional democracy. These include the Public Protector; the South African Human Rights Commission; the Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural Religious and Linguistic Communities; the Commission for Gender Equality; the Auditor-General and the Electoral Commission and the Independent Broadcasting Authority. These institutions are often colloquially referred to as the “Chapter 9 institutions”.

af.legislation: Section 42 of the Constitution requires the enactment of legislation giving effect to these intergovernmental relations and procedures for the settlement of intergovernmental disputes. The Intergovernmental Relations Framework Act 13 of 2005 specifically provides the framework governing the relationship between these three spheres of government.
af.mechanism: Section 41 of the Constitution obliges all three spheres of government and organs of state within each sphere to adhere to stipulated constitutional principles such as the need to “preserve the peace, national unity and the indivisibility of the Republic” and the need to “co-operate with one another in mutual trust and good faith by assisting and supporting one another”.
af.snippet: Governs the constitutional relationship between the three spheres of government.
af.title: Co-operative Government and Intergovernmental Relations
af.topic_meaning: Chapter 3 of the Constitution governs the constitutional relationship between the three spheres of government and stipulates the principles of co-operative governance between national, provincial and local government. Importantly section 40(1) of the Constitution confirms that each of these three spheres of government is “distinctive, interdependent and interrelated”. This confirmation recognises the independence of each sphere to govern within its sphere but at the same time recognises the need for interdependency.

af.interpretation:
In Economic Freedom Fighters and Others v Speaker of the National Assembly and Another [2017] ZACC 47, the Constitutional Court clarified that the National Assembly has an obligation to hold the Executive, including the President, accountable.
In Doctors for Life International v Speaker of the National Assembly and Others [2006] ZACC 11, the Constitutional Court said that both the National Assembly and the NCOP must participate in the law-making process and act together in making law, to ensure that the interests they represent are taken into consideration. If either the National Assembly or the NCOP fail to fulfil its obligation, the result is that Parliament has failed to fulfil its obligation.
In Premier: Limpopo Province v Speaker: Limpopo Provincial Legislature and Others (CCT 94 of 2010) [2011] ZACC 25 (11 August 2011), the Constitutional Court held that Parliament may legislate on Schedule 5 matters, subject to section 44(2) of the Constitution.
In Organisation Undoing Tax Abuse v Minister of Transport and Others (32097/2020) [2022] ZAGPPHC 1; All SA 756 (GP) (13 January 2022), the High Court used section 44(1)(a)(ii) to determine whether Parliament could legislate on matters relating to provincial roads and municipal roads at local level.
In Primedia Broadcasting, A Division of Primedia (Pty) Ltd and Others v Speaker of the National Assembly and Others (2749 of 2015) [2015] ZAWCHC 72 (28 May 2015), the High Court highlighted that section 45 empowers Parliament to make rules concerning the conduct of business in the NA and the NCOP.
In In Re: National Education Policy Bill No 83 of 1995 [1996] ZACC 3; 1996 (4) BCLR 518; 1996 (3) SA 289, the Constitutional Court held that when there is a conflict between a provincial law and a national law, the Constitution provides for the resolution of that conflict by giving priority either to Acts of Parliament or to provincial laws, depending on the circumstances. If there is a conflict, the provisions of the law which prevail must be enforced in all respects.
In Executive Council of the Province of the Western Cape v Minister for Provincial Affairs and Constitutional Development and Another, Executive Council of KwaZulu-Natal v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others [1999] ZACC 13; 2000 (1) SA 661; 1999 (12) BCLR 1360, the Constitutional Court found that the national government’s powers with respect to local government are only those that Chapter 7 of the Constitution allocates to it.
af.legislation:
Powers, Privileges and Immunities of Parliament and Provincial Legislatures Act 4 of 2004

Although this Act does not directly refer to section 42 of the Constitution, s 23 of the Act provides guidance for civil proceedings against Parliament. 

Local Government: Municipal Systems Act, No. 32 of 2000

Sections 11-12 of this Act set out the executive and legislative authority of municipalities.

Powers, Privileges and Immunities of Parliament and Provincial Legislatures Act 4 of 2004

Relevant Provisions include section 6, 11, and 22.
af.mechanism:
Importantly Schedule 4 of the Constitution stipulates functional areas of concurrent national and provincial legislative competence and this includes housing, health services and education (excluding tertiary education). This means that both the national and provincial governments can legislate on these areas. Part B of Schedule 4, stipulates functional areas in terms of which local government has concurrent legislative authority in order to manage their own affairs, such as municipal health services.

Schedule 5 of the Constitution stipulates functional areas in terms of which the provincial legislative authority has exclusive provincial competence, such as liquor licences and ambulance services. This means that the provincial government has exclusive legislative authority over these areas and the national government may only intervene and pass legislation on these functional areas in very limited circumstances. Part B of Schedule 5 also stipulates functional areas in terms of which local government has exclusive legislative competence in order to manage their affairs such as beaches and amusement facilities and the control of public nuisances.
af.snippet: The Constitution divides legislative power between various spheres of government, namely national (Parliament), provincial and local government.
af.title: Parliament and Legislative Competence
af.topic_meaning:
The Constitution divides legislative power between various spheres of government, namely national (Parliament), provincial and local government. The Composition of Parliament is set out in section 42 of the Constitution. Parliament consists of the National Assembly and the National Council of Provinces. Both participate in the legislative process of South Africa. The National Assembly represents the people, and the National Council of Provinces represents the provinces.
The Legislative Authority is set out in section 43 of the Constitution. Parliament may legislate on the national sphere of government, respective provincial legislatures may legislate on the provincial sphere of government, and the municipal councils may legislate on the local sphere of government. The legislative authority of the national sphere of government is set out in detail in section 44 of the Constitution; section 104 of the Constitution for the provincial sphere; and the powers and functions of municipalities can be found in section 156 of the Constitution.
The three spheres of government do not compete with each other but should be viewed as working together and sharing responsibilities. Section 45 of the Constitution provides that the National Assembly and the National Council of Provinces must establish a joint rules committee to make rules and orders concerning the joint business of the Assembly and Council. Under section 45 of the Constitution, Cabinet members, members of the National Assembly, and delegates to the National Council of Provinces have the same privileges and immunities before a joint committee of the Assembly and the Council as they have before the Assembly or the Council.

af.interpretation: Municipalities have the power to pass laws in respect of the functional areas listed in Part B of Schedule 4 and Part B of Schedule 5. The Constitution also gives municipalities the right to exercise any power concerning a matter reasonably necessary for or incidental to the performance of its functions (found in Part B of Schedule 4 and Part B of Schedule 5).
af.legislation: The Local Government: Municipal Structures Act 117 of 1998 further defines the different municipalities relating to categories and types of municipality. The Local Government: Municipal Systems Act 32 of 2000 provides for the manner in which municipal powers and functions are exercised.
af.mechanism: Different categories of municipalities are provided for in section 155 of the Constitution.
af.snippet: Deals with local government, consisting of municipalities which are vested with both legislative and executive authority.
af.title: Local Government
af.topic_meaning: Chapter 7 of the Constitution deals with local government, consisting of municipalities which are vested with both legislative and executive authority. These are original powers which are derived directly from the Constitution. Section 151(3) of the Constitution emphasises that a municipality “has the right to govern, on its own initiative, the local government affairs of its community, subject to national and provincial legislation” and importantly national and provincial government may not “compromise or impede a municipality’s ability or right to exercise its power or perform its functions”.

af.interpretation: Section 85 of the Constitution confirms that the executive authority of the Republic is vested in the President who, together with members of the cabinet, must implement national legislation, co-ordinate functions of state departments and develop and implement national policy. This section refers to the President’s powers as head of the national executive.
af.legislation: The exercise of executive power of the National Executive does not constitute “administrative action” in terms of the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 2000 and therefore cannot be reviewed in terms of this Act. This, however, does not mean the exercise of these powers cannot be reviewed by the Courts. The Courts will review the exercise of this power under the principle of legality enshrined in section 1(c) of the Constitution.
af.snippet: Provides for the power and functions of the President and the National Executive as well as the election and removal of the President by way of impeachment or a motion of no confidence.
af.title: President and National Executive
af.topic_meaning:
Chapter 5 of the Constitution provides for the powers and functions of the President and the National Executive as well as the election and removal of the President by way of impeachment or a motion of no confidence. The requirements for a motion of no confidence in the Cabinet, excluding the President is also covered in section 102.

Importantly, sections 84 and 85 of the Constitution provides for the exclusive powers of the President as head of State and head of the national executive respectively. The powers of the President as head of State include the power to assent to and sign Bills and to pardon or reprieve any offenders. These are original presidential powers which may only be exercised by the President.

af.interpretation:
The powers and functions of the Premier is specifically provided for in section 127 of the Constitution which includes the assenting and signing of Bills and the appointment of commissions of inquiry within the province. Importantly, the provincial executive must act in accordance with the Constitution and the provincial constitution, if one has been passed. The province of the Western Cape passed a provincial constitution.

An important and unique mechanism for provincial interference in local government is provided for in section 139 of the Constitution. This section provides for interference by the provincial executive if a municipality is not adhering to its executive duties in terms of the Constitution. The provincial executive has the authority to take “any appropriate steps”. If the provincial executive authority does not or cannot fulfil this duty in terms of section 139, then the national executive authority must intervene.
af.snippet: Provides for the powers and functions of the Premier and what can be done when a municipality does not adhere to its executive duties.
af.title: Provincial Executive Authority
af.topic_meaning:
Sections 125 to 141 of the Constitution, under Chapter 6 of the Constitution, deals with provincial executives.

Section 125 of the Constitution confirms that the executive authority of the province is vested in the Premier and the Premier together with other members of the executive Council exercises the executive authority which includes “implementing provincial legislation”; “developing and implementing provincial policy” and “co-ordinating the functions of the provincial administration and its departments”.

af.mechanism:
Section 217(3) of the Constitution requires national legislation to be enacted to provide a framework for such policy and the Preferential Procurement Policy Framework Act 5 of 2000 was specifically enacted in this regard.

Various laws give effect to these constitutional standards in section 217(1) of the Constitution such as the Public Finance Management Act 1 of 1999, which requires the National Treasury to determine a “framework for an appropriate procurement and provisioning system which is fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost-effective”.
af.snippet: Stipulates the constitutional standards of public procurement in South Africa.
af.title: Public Procurement
af.topic_meaning:
Section 217 of the Constitution stipulates the constitutional standards of public procurement in South Africa.

Section 217(1) of the Constitution provides that:

“When an organ of state in the national, provincial or local sphere of government, or any other institution identified in national legislation, contracts for goods and services, it must do so in accordance with a system which is fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost-effective.”

These five constitutional principles inform the law of public procurement in South Africa.

The Constitution also enables public procurement to be used as a tool to advance persons or categories of persons disadvantaged by unfair discrimination. Importantly, section 217(2) of the Constitution stipulates that the five constitutional principles identified in section 217(1) does not prohibit organs of State from implementing a procurement policy providing preferential allocation of contracts and advancing persons disadvantaged by unfair discrimination.

af.interpretation:
Die begrip waardigheid is 'n moeilike begrip om te definieer, maar dit behels die erkenning van die ingeboude waarde van elke mens. In wese kom die reg op waardigheid outomaties as gevolg van menswees. Die kern van die reg op waardigheid is die aanname dat elke mens onmeetbare menslike waarde het, ongeag hul omstandighede, en daarvolgens behandel moet word.

Die reg op waardigheid verskaf die grondslag vir en lig die vertolking in van baie regte in die Handves van Regte. As gevolg hiervan is die reg op waardigheid nie dikwels die onderwerp van litigasie in gevalle waar 'n persoon se regte geskend word nie, tensy geen ander reg in die Handves van Regte die belang op die spel sal beskerm of uitvoer nie. In daardie gevalle kan die reg op waardigheid deur die howe gebruik word om skendings van 'n persoon se regte aan te spreek wat nie aangespreek kan word deur ander regte in die Handves van Regte te beroep nie. Die reg is ook verbind met die idee van demokrasie en erken dat mense die reg en vryheid het om hul eie keuses te maak.
af.snippet: Erken dat elkeen die reg op inherente gelykheid het.
af.title: Afdeling 10: Menswaardigheid
af.topic_meaning: Artikel 10 van die Grondwet erken dat elkeen die reg het op “inherente waardigheid en die reg dat hul waardigheid gerespekteer en bevorder word”. Dit beteken 'n persoon se reg op waardigheid heg bloot as gevolg van menswees. Die reg op waardigheid is nie net 'n grondliggende waarde in artikel 1 van die Grondwet nie, maar is ook 'n afsonderlike, afdwingbare reg op sy eie.

af.interpretation: Die grondwetlikheid van die doodstraf was een van die Grondwethowe se eerste baanbrekende uitsprake en alhoewel die meerderheidsuitspraak nie op die reg op lewe gefokus het nie, het die ander ooreenstemmende uitsprake beklemtoon dat die reg op lewe met die reg op waardigheid verbind is. Baie van die regters het opgemerk dat die doodstraf nie net die reg op lewe heeltemal beperk nie, maar eintlik verwyder. Dit is belangrik dat die reg op lewe beskryf is as die reg om menslikheid te ervaar en is 'n weerspieëling van elke individu se waarde en waarde in 'n samelewing.
af.mechanism: Wat dit beteken vir die reg op lewe om ongekwalifiseerd te wees, maar steeds aan 'n beperking onderhewig te kan wees, is dat 'n wet wat die reg toelaat om uit selfverdediging dood te maak, 'n regverdigbare beperking op die reg op lewe is, net soos die gebruik van geweld deur die polisie in baie beperkte omstandighede.
af.snippet: Waarborg elkeen die reg op lewe.
af.title: Afdeling 11: Lewe
af.topic_meaning: Artikel 11 van die Grondwet waarborg die reg op lewe aan almal en is 'n ongekwalifiseerde reg. Dit is belangrik om te verstaan dat alhoewel die reg op lewe ongekwalifiseerd is, beteken dit nie dat dit nie binne redelike rede beperk kan word nie (mits die beperking regverdigbaar is) ingevolge artikel 36 van die Grondwet, die beperking van regte bepaling in die Grondwet.

af.interpretation:
Die substantiewe aspek van die reg op vryheid en sekerheid van die persoon vereis die bevordering van 'n wettige regeringsdoel wat in die wet verkry word vir die ontneming van 'n persoon se vryheid, terwyl die prosedurele aspek van die reg verband hou met prosedurele billikheid en behoorlike proses en sal afhang van die omstandighede van elke geval.

Die reg op liggaamlike en sielkundige integriteit, strek tot die reg om reproduktiewe keuses te maak, om in veiligheid en beheer van jou eie liggaam te wees en die reg om nie aan mediese of wetenskaplike eksperimente onderwerp te word sonder om ingeligte toestemming te gee nie.
af.legislation: Die Wet op Keuse oor Beëindiging van Swangerskap 92 van 1996 is spesifiek uitgevaardig om uitdrukking te gee aan die reg om reproduktiewe keuses te maak.
af.snippet: Bied aan elkeen die reg op vryheid en sekerheid van die persoon en die reg op liggaamlike en sielkundige integriteit.
af.title: Afdeling 12: Vryheid en sekuriteit van die persoon
af.topic_meaning: Artikel 12 van die Grondwet verleen nie net aan almal die reg op vryheid en sekerheid van die persoon nie, maar dit verleen ook aan elkeen die reg op liggaamlike en sielkundige integriteit. Dit is belangrik om te verstaan dat die reg op vryheid en sekerheid van die persoon wat verskeie aspekte behels soos die reg om nie arbitrêr van vryheid ontneem te word nie en die reg om nie gemartel te word nie, beide substantiewe en prosedurele beskerming waarborg.

af.legislation: Suid-Afrika is 'n ondertekenaar van verskeie internasionale reg konvensies wat state verplig om slawerny en knegskap uit te roei, soos die 1956 Aanvullende Konvensie oor die Afskaffing van Slawerny, die Slawehandel, en Instellings en Praktyke soortgelyk aan Slawerny. In 2013 is die Wet op die Voorkoming en Bekamping van Mensehandel 7 van 2013 spesifiek uitgevaardig om uitvoering te gee aan Suid-Afrika se internasionale en grondwetlike verpligtinge en hierdie Wet verskaf maatreëls spesifiek om slagoffers van mensehandel te beskerm en by te staan.
af.snippet: Voorsien dat niemand aan slawerny, knegskap of dwangarbeid onderwerp mag word nie.
af.title: Afdeling 13: Slawerny, diensbaarheid en dwangarbeid
af.topic_meaning: Artikel 13 van die Grondwet bepaal dat niemand aan slawerny, knegskap of dwangarbeid onderwerp mag word nie. In die hedendaagse sin kan slawerny verstaan word as om een persoon aan 'n ander persoon se beheer te onderwerp, wat daardie persoon 'n eienaar van die persoon maak. Hierdie breë definisie dek baie dwangverhoudings, hetsy in die werkplek, huis of andersins.

af.interpretation: Die grondwetlike beskerming wat aan die reg op privaatheid verleen word, is deur die Konstitusionele Hof geïnterpreteer om uit te brei na aspekte van 'n persoon se lewe waarvoor 'n regmatige verwagting van privaatheid bestaan. By die oorweging of 'n skending van die reg op privaatheid plaasgevind het, sal die howe nie net oorweeg wat die slagoffer verwag om privaat te wees nie (die subjektiewe verwagting), maar ook die objektiewe komponent van die verwagting van privaatheid, met inagneming of die samelewing die verwagting as redelik sal erken. Die objektiewe komponent fokus op 'n bepaling deur 'n hof of die persoon wat beweer dat hul privaatheid geskend is, redelikerwys kan verwag dat hul privaatheid in die besondere omstandighede beskerm word.
af.legislation: Die Wet op die Beskerming van Persoonlike Inligting 4 van 2013 is spesifiek uitgevaardig om uitvoering te gee aan die reg op inligtingsprivaatheid en die Wet voorsien streng maatreëls vir die verwerking van persoonlike inligting deur openbare en private liggame. Die Inligtingsreguleerder wat ingevolge die Wet ingestel is, is 'n onafhanklike liggaam wat gemagtig is om nakoming van die Wet te monitor.
af.mechanism: Die beskerming wat aan die reg op privaatheid verleen word, word meer intens hoe nader dit verband hou met die intieme persoonlike sfeer van die lewe, soos die huis, en minder intens soos dit wegbeweeg van daardie kern. Byvoorbeeld, as iemand se gesinslewe, seksuele voorkeur en huisomgewing strenger deur die reg op privaatheid beskerm sal word. Die reg op privaatheid is onderling verwant aan die reg op waardigheid.
af.snippet: Bied aan almal 'n algemene reg op privaatheid en beskerming teen spesifieke gevalle van privaatheidskendings.
af.title: Afdeling 14: Privaatheid
af.topic_meaning: Artikel 14 van die Grondwet waarborg nie net aan almal 'n algemene reg op privaatheid nie, maar bied ook beskerming teen spesifieke gevalle van privaatheidskendings soos die reg om nie 'n mens se huis te laat deursoek nie, eiendom waarop beslag gelê word en die reg op die privaatheid van jou kommunikasie. Die beskerming van hierdie reg erken dat elkeen 'n reg het op persoonlike outonomie en intimiteit.

af.interpretation: Hierdie afdeling is belangrik aangesien dit beklemtoon dat diverse oortuigings en opinies beskermingswaardig is en geakkommodeer moet word en erken dat Suid-Afrika 'n multikulturele samelewing is. Die reg op vryheid van godsdiens word beskerm indien daar 'n afwesigheid van dwang of beperking op 'n godsdienstige oortuiging of praktyk is en die reg sou geskend word indien maatreëls aangeneem word wat mense gedwing het om op te tree op 'n manier wat hulle oortuigings teenstaan.
af.legislation: Artikel 15 van die Grondwet voorsien die reg om in 'n bepaalde God of gode te glo en die godsdienstige leerstellings wat verband hou met 'n geloof in daardie God of gode; die reg om onseker te bly oor geloof in 'n God of gode en die godsdienstige leerstellings wat verband hou met 'n geloof in daardie God of gode; asook die reg om glad nie in enige God te glo nie. Dit is egter nie net die reg om te glo of nie te glo wat deur artikel 15 van die Grondwet beskerm word nie. Artikel 15 beskerm ook die reg om in ooreenstemming met daardie oortuigings of nie-oortuigings op te tree en vir 'n persoon om hul lewe te organiseer op 'n wyse wat getrouheid aan die spesifieke gekose geloofstelsel demonstreer.
af.mechanism: Artikel 15 van die Grondwet voorsien die reg om in 'n bepaalde God of gode te glo en die godsdienstige leerstellings wat verband hou met 'n geloof in daardie God of gode; die reg om onseker te bly oor geloof in 'n God of gode en die godsdienstige leerstellings wat verband hou met 'n geloof in daardie God of gode; asook die reg om glad nie in enige God te glo nie. Dit is egter nie net die reg om te glo of nie te glo wat deur artikel 15 van die Grondwet beskerm word nie. Artikel 15 beskerm ook die reg om in ooreenstemming met daardie oortuigings of nie-oortuigings op te tree en vir 'n persoon om hul lewe te organiseer op 'n wyse wat getrouheid aan die spesifieke gekose geloofstelsel demonstreer.
af.snippet: Waarborg almal die reg op vryheid van gewete, godsdiens, denke, oortuiging en opinie.
af.title: Afdeling 15: Vryheid van godsdiens geloof en mening
af.topic_meaning:
Artikel 15(1) van die Grondwet waarborg elkeen die reg op vryheid van gewete, godsdiens, denke, oortuiging en opinie. Die reg op godsdiensvryheid strek ook tot die reg om nie sulke oortuigings te hê nie.
