Thus, there is not a complete divide between the three branches of government and there is often an overlap. For example, in cases where Parliament has enacted legislation which the courts declare not to be in line with the Constitution, Parliament will be ordered to redraft the relevant parts of the legislation.
en.snippet: This principle sees State power divided between the legislative branch, the executive branch and the judiciary.
en.title: Separation of Powers
en.topic_meaning: South Africa’s new constitutional order provides for a clear distinction between the three branches of the government in order to limit an over-concentration of State power in any one branch and to recognise the functional independence of the three branches of government. This doctrine of separation of powers sees State power divided between the legislative branch (which drafts the law), the executive branch (which implements the law) and the judiciary (which interprets and resolves dispute of the law). This doctrine allows for checks and balances to be carried out by each branch over the others, and ensures that no branch of government can usurp the power of another. Although not specifically mentioned in the Constitution, the doctrine of separation of powers is an essential component of the foundation of South African constitutional law.

en.interpretation:
Many court decisions have stressed the importance of separation of powers amongst the different arms of government and checks and balances that allow the other arms of government and the public to monitor and review the National Assembly in its functions.
Although members of the NA are elected under a political party or self-sponsored, they are allowed to support the views of another political party by floor-crossing.
en.legislation:
Sections 46-59 discuss the role of the National Assembly in detail and the legislation that gives effect to it includes:
(a) Electoral Commission Act 51 of 1996 
(b) Electoral Act 73 of 1998 
(c) Local Government: Municipal Structures Act 117 of 1998
(d) Constitution Fifteenth Amendment Act of 2008
(e) Constitution Tenth Amendment Act of 2003
(f) Rules of the National Assembly
en.snippet:
Sections 46-59 of the Constitution govern the National Assembly, which is the first House of Parliament, with the second House being the National Council of Provinces (NCOP). The National Assembly is the primary legislative power in Parliament and the house to which the national executive is accountable. They provide for:
(a) its composition and membership; 
(b) the duration of its term; 
(c) its meetings and business;
(d) the powers and privileges of its members; and 
(e) the checks and balances that can be exercised over it by the executive and members of the public.
en.title: The National Assembly
en.topic_meaning:
Composition and membership of the National Assembly 
The NA consists of 350 to 400 members who are elected every five years. 
Every South African who is qualified to vote (i.e. any citizen who is 18 years or older) is eligible to be a member of the NA. However, there are five exceptions:
(a) those in the service of the State, except the President, Deputy President, Ministers, and Deputy Ministers;
(b) permanent delegates to the National Council of Provinces or members of a provincial legislature or a Municipal Council;
(c) unrehabilitated insolvents;
(d) anyone declared to be of unsound mind by a court of the Republic; or
(e) anyone convicted of an offence and sentenced to more than 12 months' imprisonment without the option of a fine, either in South Africa or another country provided the conduct is also considered an offence in South Africa.
These persons may be allowed to be NA members in terms of national legislation that prescribes the limitations and conditions of their membership. 
After the election, the members are sworn into office by the Chief Justice or a judge designated by the Chief Justice. The oath or affirmation requires members of Parliament to affirm their loyalty to the State, and obedience to the Constitution, before assuming their duties. 
A person would lose their membership in the NA if they cease to be eligible; if they are absent from the Assembly without permission; or if they cease to be a member of the party that nominated them to be a member of the Assembly. 

Duration and term
The NA’s term of office lasts for five years, but the term may end earlier.  The President or Acting President has the power to end the term of office of the NA before the expiry of the five-year term if the conditions in sections 50(1) and 50(2) of the Constitution are met.

Meetings and business
The NA meetings are chaired by the speaker and deputy speaker. The Speaker and Deputy Speaker are elected from among the members of the NA.
Section 53 states that a majority (more than half) of the members must be present before a decision can be taken by the Assembly. Questions before the Assembly must be decided by a majority vote.
Powers and Privileges
The NA has two principal functions, as set out in section 55 of the Constitution. The first is to exercise legislative authority by considering, passing, amending or rejecting any legislation before it, and by initiating or preparing new legislation itself (except for money bills). Parliament’s second primary function is to maintain oversight of the national executive authority and any organ of the State.
The Assembly has the power to control its internal arrangements, proceedings and procedures, according to the Rules of the National Assembly. The salaries of the members of the NA are charged directly from the National Revenue Fund, which helps to ensure that members are independent and impartial in their duties.
Section 58 grants the Assembly’s members immunity (legal protection) from being held liable either criminally or civilly for violations of law or for anything they say or reveal in the Assembly or any of its committees. This allows members to exercise free speech and speak up on behalf of their constituents without the fear of facing criminal and civil actions. Other immunities are prescribed by law.

Checks and balances by the Executive and members of the public
The Constitution gives the executive and the public the power to oversee the Assembly by reviewing and monitoring the performance of its functions.
Members of the executive arm of government (President, members of the Cabinet or Deputy Ministers) have the power to oversee the Assembly’s performance by attending and speaking in the Assembly. 
The public can also oversee the NA. Section 59 requires the NA to conduct its business in an open manner and to facilitate public involvement and participation in the law-making process. The Assembly may only exclude the public from involvement if it is reasonable and justifiable, in a democratic society, to do so.

en.interpretation:
In Doctors for Life International v Speaker of the National Assembly and Others 2006 (6) SA 416 (CC), s 67 was used to illustrate  the principle of co-operation and communication in the national legislative process. This provision describes how local government is involved in NCOP proceedings, albeit indirectly. In this way, the NCOP also represents the concerns and interests of local government in addition to the provinces.
In the same judgment, DFL challenged the passing of legislation by parliament on the basis that the NCOP had not allowed for sufficient public participation in terms of s 72. The constitutional court found that s 72 demands meaningful public participation, and the NCOP's failure to carry out public consultations before passing the bill resulted in the invalidation of some of the legislation in question.
en.legislation:
Importantly, Schedule 4 of the Constitution stipulates functional areas of concurrent national and provincial legislative competence and this includes housing, health services and education (excluding tertiary education). This means that both the national and provincial governments can legislate on these areas. The NCOP may initiate and prepare new legislation concerning the areas listed in this Schedule.

The Powers, Privileges and Immunities Act No. 4 of 2004 sets out certain powers, privileges and immunities of Parliament, including delegates to the NCOP and members of provincial legislatures; and provides for incidental matters.

The Rules of the National Council of Provinces provides for the processes, structure and sittings of the NCOP.
en.snippet: Sections 60-72 of the Constitution concern the structure, powers, processes and functions of the National Council of Provinces (NCOP). The NCOP represents provincial interests in Parliament and is deeply involved in the passing of new Bills, especially where they affect the provinces or amend the Constitution, which is dealt with by ss 73-77 (for more on this, see the guide to Parliament and Legislative Competence).
en.title: The National Council of Provinces
en.topic_meaning:
The NCOP consists of a delegation of 10 members for each of the 9 provinces in South Africa. Section 60 stipulates that these delegates must include 6 permanent delegates and 4 special delegates. 

According to ss 61 and 62, the special delegates must include the Premier of the province (or a member of the provincial legislature of that province, appointed by the Premier in her place), and 3 other special delegates, who are appointed by the provincial legislature of that province. The permanent delegates may not necessarily be members of the provincial legislature, but they must be eligible for that role. If they are members of the provincial legislature, they automatically lose that position as soon as they are appointed as a permanent delegate in the NCOP. Section 64 states that the NCOP must elect a Chairperson and a Deputy Chairperson from among the permanent delegates. There must also be a second Deputy Chairperson who serves for only 1 year, and who must be succeeded by someone from a different province so that each province gets a turn.

The NCOP exercises legislative power in two ways: by initiating and preparing new legislation in an area listed in Schedule 4 of the Constitution, or by considering, passing, rejecting or amending legislation that came from the National Assembly (s 68).  The Premier (or her designated representative) heads the delegation for each province and casts a vote on behalf of that province when the NCOP makes decisions. Each province gets one vote, and decisions must be supported by at least 5 provinces (s 65). Members of Cabinet, Deputy Ministers and municipal representatives may attend sessions and speak in the NCOP, but they may not vote (ss 66 and 67). 

The NCOP also has wide powers to conduct its proceedings in its own ways and determine its own rules (S 70). Section 69 gives the NCOP the power to summon any person to give evidence during its proceedings, and may receive petitions or submissions by any person. Like the members of the National Assembly, NCOP members have parliamentary privileges and immunities (s 71), which means that an NCOP member has free speech and can't be held civilly or criminally liable for what they say or produce before the NCOP or its committees. The NCOP also has important obligations, however, which include the duty to facilitate public participation in its processes and to conduct its business in an open and transparent way (s 72).

en.interpretation:
In Doctors for Life International v Speaker of the House of Assembly, the Constitutional Court cites Section 73 as part of the “National Legislative Process” in which “all Bills, constitutional amendments, Bills affecting and not affecting provinces and money Bills are dealt with, together with assent to Bills and the publication and safekeeping of Acts.”
In Ex Parte President of the Republic of South Africa: In re Constitutionality of the Liquor Bill, the Constitutional Court interpreted section 76 of the Constitution as placing more influence on the National Council of Provinces, mainly though invoking the Mediation Committee. The Court also held that if the President has reservations about a Bill's constitutionality, the President can refer it to the Constitutional Court only after Parliament has reconsidered it in the light of his reservations, to no avail.
In Tongoane and Others v National Minister for Agriculture and Land Affairs and Others, the Constitutional Court interpreted the section 76 procedure to govern Bills whose provisions substantially affect the interests of the provinces. The substantiality can be established via the "pith and substance" test, which looks to the effect of the subject-matter of the legislation.
In President of the Republic of South Africa and Others v United Democratic Movement (African Christian Democratic Party and Others Intervening; Institute for Democracy in South Africa and Another as Amici Curiae), the Constitutional Court held that in the case of abstract review in terms of section 80, only the Constitutional Court is empowered to suspend the operation of impugned provisions until the challenge is resolved.
en.legislation: The Money Bills Amendment Procedure and Related Matters Act, [No. 9 of 2009] provides for a procedure to amend money bills before Parliament, as well as for norms and standards for amending money Bills before provincial legislatures.
en.snippet: The Constitution outlines various procedures in the introduction, adoption, and general handling of various bills in the National Assembly and the National Council of Provinces.
en.title: The National Legislative Process
en.topic_meaning:
The national legislative process is explained by Sections 73 - 82 of the Constitution. Different Bills will go through different routes, depending on where they originated, what they seek to do, and whether or not they affect the provinces. These processes are further expanded and dealt with by the Rules of the National Assembly and the Rules of the National Council of Provinces.

Section 73 of the Constitution dictates who can introduce any Bill in the National Assembly (NA) and the National Council of Provinces (NCOP). It states that only a Cabinet member, a Deputy Minister, or a member or committee of the National Assembly, can introduce a Bill in the National Assembly. Only the Cabinet member responsible for national financial matters may introduce either a Money Bill or a Bill which provides for legislation expected in section 214 of the Constitution (equitable shares and allocations of revenue). Only a member or committee of the National Council of Provinces (NCOP) may introduce a Bill in the Council referred to in section 76(3), besides the Bills that may be introduced in the NA. If there is a need, a Bill passed by the NA must be referred to the NCOP. A Bill passed by the Council must be referred to the NA.

Section 74 sets out the process for amending the Constitution. The process is rigorous, which reflects the seriousness of constitutional changes. It states that any Bill amending s 1 of the Constitution, or s 74, can only be passed by the NA and the NCOP together, with a supporting vote of at least 75 per cent of NA members and a supporting vote of at least six provinces in the NCOP. A Bill amending any provision in Ch 2 (the Bill of Rights) requires a supporting vote of at least two-thirds of NA members and a supporting vote of at least six provinces in the NCOP. Any Bill amending the Constitution must also be referred to the President for assent.

Section 75 of the Constitution sets out the procedure to be followed by the NCOP after the NA passes Ordinary Bills not affecting provinces. On receipt of such a bill, the NCOP must deal with the Bill in one of three ways:

  1. pass the Bill without amendments and submit it for presidential assent; or
  2. pass the Bill subject to amendments, which requires the NA to reconsider the Bill and pass the Bill again with or without amendments and submit it for presidential assent; or decide not to proceed with the Bill; or
  3. reject the Bill. 

Section 76 covers the procedure for when the NA passes an ordinary bill affecting provinces, other than a money bill. Such a Bill must be reported to the NCOP, which must then pass the Bill, pass an amended Bill, or reject the Bill. If the NCOP passes the Bill without amendment, the Bill must be sent to the President for assent. If the NCOP amends the bill, the bill must be sent to the NA and if the NA passes the amended Bill, it is sent to the President for assent. If the NCOP rejects the Bill, or if the NA refuses to pass an amended Bill, the Bill or the amended Bill must be referred to the Mediation Committee. 

The Mediation Committee may agree on the Bill as passed by the NA, the amended Bill as passed by the NCOP, or a different version of the Bill. Section 78 deals with the Mediation Committee, who may be part of the Committee and how it can agree on a version of a Bill or decide on a question during the national legislative process. The Mediation Committee consists of nine members of the NA, elected by the Assembly, and one delegate from each provincial delegation in the NCOP. The Committee will only have officially agreed on a Bill or a question if the Bill, or one side of the question, is supported by at least five of the representatives of the NA and at least five of the representatives of the NCOP. The mediation must be completed within 30 days and if the two houses still disagree after mediation, the original bill lapses. The bill may, however, still become law if it is passed again by two-thirds of the NA. This requirement prevents the NCOP from having absolute power over such bills, but it means that the NCOP can delay the passage of the bills and force a two-thirds majority in the NA for the bill to be passed. 

Section 77 deals with so-called ‘money bills’, which is any bill that appropriates money; imposes national taxes, levies, duties or surcharges; abolishes or reduces any national taxes, levies, duties or surcharges; or authorises direct charges against the National Revenue Fund. These Bills can only deal with these issues or subordinate matters incidental to them. Money bills are dealt with in the same way as ordinary bills not affecting the provinces.

Section 79 of the Constitution concerns what the President can do with new Bills. The President can either assent (agree) to the new Bill and sign it, or refer it back to the NA for reconsideration if he/she has reservations about the constitutionality. If the Bill referred to the NA included matters that relate to the NCOP, then the NCOP must participate in the reconsideration of the Bill. Once the Bill is reconsidered and sent back to the President, he/she can either assent to and sign it or, if he/she still has reservations about it, send it to the Constitutional Court for a decision on its constitutionality. If the Constitutional Court decides that the Bill is constitutional, then the President must assent to and sign it.

Sections 80 and 81 state that when a Bill is assented to and signed by the President, it becomes an Act of Parliament. It must then be published promptly and takes effect when it is published in the Government Gazette. The signed copy of the Act is conclusive evidence of the provisions of that Act and must be kept at the Constitutional Court.

If an Act is passed and members of the NA are concerned about its constitutionality, s 82 provides that they may apply to the Constitutional Court for an order declaring that all or part of it is unconstitutional. However, such an application must be supported by at least one-third of NA members and must be made within 30 days of the President assenting to and signing the Act.

xh.interpretation:
These institutions in terms of section 181 of the Constitution are independent and are “subject only to the Constitution and the law”. It is critical to emphasise this provision. The Constitutional Court has emphasised that the Public Protector in fulfilling her mandate is “not supposed to bow down to anybody, not even at the door of the highest chambers of raw State power”.

These institutions are obligated in terms of section 181(2) of the Constitution to be impartial and to “exercise their functions without fear, favour or prejudice” and no “person or organ of state may interfere with the functioning of these institutions.” It is also important to note that these institutions only account to the National Assembly on their activities and performance. The remaining provisions of Chapter 9 of the Constitution provides for the functions of each of these institutions, their tenure and removal from office.
xh.mechanism: The Public Protector and Auditor-General in specific are watchdogs over the State and are critical in the fight against corruption and enforcing accountability. The South African Human Rights Commission is mandated to monitor the observance of human rights and take action where human rights have been violated. The Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities has various powers including investigating matters concerning the rights of cultural, religious communities and the Commission for Gender Equality also has extensive power including the power to lobby and investigate issues relating to gender equality. The Electoral Commission is mandated to manage the elections of the national, provincial and municipal legislative bodies.
xh.snippet: Provides for the establishment of independent State institutions strengthening constitutional democracy.
xh.title: Chapter 9 Institutions
xh.topic_meaning: Chapter 9 of the Constitution provides for the establishment of independent State institutions strengthening constitutional democracy. These include the Public Protector; the South African Human Rights Commission; the Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural Religious and Linguistic Communities; the Commission for Gender Equality; the Auditor-General and the Electoral Commission and the Independent Broadcasting Authority. These institutions are often colloquially referred to as the “Chapter 9 institutions”.

xh.legislation: Section 42 of the Constitution requires the enactment of legislation giving effect to these intergovernmental relations and procedures for the settlement of intergovernmental disputes. The Intergovernmental Relations Framework Act 13 of 2005 specifically provides the framework governing the relationship between these three spheres of government.
xh.mechanism: Section 41 of the Constitution obliges all three spheres of government and organs of state within each sphere to adhere to stipulated constitutional principles such as the need to “preserve the peace, national unity and the indivisibility of the Republic” and the need to “co-operate with one another in mutual trust and good faith by assisting and supporting one another”.
xh.snippet: Governs the constitutional relationship between the three spheres of government.
xh.title: Co-operative Government and Intergovernmental Relations
xh.topic_meaning: Chapter 3 of the Constitution governs the constitutional relationship between the three spheres of government and stipulates the principles of co-operative governance between national, provincial and local government. Importantly section 40(1) of the Constitution confirms that each of these three spheres of government is “distinctive, interdependent and interrelated”. This confirmation recognises the independence of each sphere to govern within its sphere but at the same time recognises the need for interdependency.

xh.interpretation:
In Economic Freedom Fighters and Others v Speaker of the National Assembly and Another [2017] ZACC 47, the Constitutional Court clarified that the National Assembly has an obligation to hold the Executive, including the President, accountable.
In Doctors for Life International v Speaker of the National Assembly and Others [2006] ZACC 11, the Constitutional Court said that both the National Assembly and the NCOP must participate in the law-making process and act together in making law, to ensure that the interests they represent are taken into consideration. If either the National Assembly or the NCOP fail to fulfil its obligation, the result is that Parliament has failed to fulfil its obligation.
In Premier: Limpopo Province v Speaker: Limpopo Provincial Legislature and Others (CCT 94 of 2010) [2011] ZACC 25 (11 August 2011), the Constitutional Court held that Parliament may legislate on Schedule 5 matters, subject to section 44(2) of the Constitution.
In Organisation Undoing Tax Abuse v Minister of Transport and Others (32097/2020) [2022] ZAGPPHC 1; All SA 756 (GP) (13 January 2022), the High Court used section 44(1)(a)(ii) to determine whether Parliament could legislate on matters relating to provincial roads and municipal roads at local level.
In Primedia Broadcasting, A Division of Primedia (Pty) Ltd and Others v Speaker of the National Assembly and Others (2749 of 2015) [2015] ZAWCHC 72 (28 May 2015), the High Court highlighted that section 45 empowers Parliament to make rules concerning the conduct of business in the NA and the NCOP.
In In Re: National Education Policy Bill No 83 of 1995 [1996] ZACC 3; 1996 (4) BCLR 518; 1996 (3) SA 289, the Constitutional Court held that when there is a conflict between a provincial law and a national law, the Constitution provides for the resolution of that conflict by giving priority either to Acts of Parliament or to provincial laws, depending on the circumstances. If there is a conflict, the provisions of the law which prevail must be enforced in all respects.
In Executive Council of the Province of the Western Cape v Minister for Provincial Affairs and Constitutional Development and Another, Executive Council of KwaZulu-Natal v President of the Republic of South Africa and Others [1999] ZACC 13; 2000 (1) SA 661; 1999 (12) BCLR 1360, the Constitutional Court found that the national government’s powers with respect to local government are only those that Chapter 7 of the Constitution allocates to it.
xh.legislation:
Powers, Privileges and Immunities of Parliament and Provincial Legislatures Act 4 of 2004

Although this Act does not directly refer to section 42 of the Constitution, s 23 of the Act provides guidance for civil proceedings against Parliament. 

Local Government: Municipal Systems Act, No. 32 of 2000

Sections 11-12 of this Act set out the executive and legislative authority of municipalities.

Powers, Privileges and Immunities of Parliament and Provincial Legislatures Act 4 of 2004

Relevant Provisions include section 6, 11, and 22.
xh.mechanism:
Importantly Schedule 4 of the Constitution stipulates functional areas of concurrent national and provincial legislative competence and this includes housing, health services and education (excluding tertiary education). This means that both the national and provincial governments can legislate on these areas. Part B of Schedule 4, stipulates functional areas in terms of which local government has concurrent legislative authority in order to manage their own affairs, such as municipal health services.

Schedule 5 of the Constitution stipulates functional areas in terms of which the provincial legislative authority has exclusive provincial competence, such as liquor licences and ambulance services. This means that the provincial government has exclusive legislative authority over these areas and the national government may only intervene and pass legislation on these functional areas in very limited circumstances. Part B of Schedule 5 also stipulates functional areas in terms of which local government has exclusive legislative competence in order to manage their affairs such as beaches and amusement facilities and the control of public nuisances.
xh.snippet: The Constitution divides legislative power between various spheres of government, namely national (Parliament), provincial and local government.
xh.title: Parliament and Legislative Competence
xh.topic_meaning:
The Constitution divides legislative power between various spheres of government, namely national (Parliament), provincial and local government. The Composition of Parliament is set out in section 42 of the Constitution. Parliament consists of the National Assembly and the National Council of Provinces. Both participate in the legislative process of South Africa. The National Assembly represents the people, and the National Council of Provinces represents the provinces.
The Legislative Authority is set out in section 43 of the Constitution. Parliament may legislate on the national sphere of government, respective provincial legislatures may legislate on the provincial sphere of government, and the municipal councils may legislate on the local sphere of government. The legislative authority of the national sphere of government is set out in detail in section 44 of the Constitution; section 104 of the Constitution for the provincial sphere; and the powers and functions of municipalities can be found in section 156 of the Constitution.
The three spheres of government do not compete with each other but should be viewed as working together and sharing responsibilities. Section 45 of the Constitution provides that the National Assembly and the National Council of Provinces must establish a joint rules committee to make rules and orders concerning the joint business of the Assembly and Council. Under section 45 of the Constitution, Cabinet members, members of the National Assembly, and delegates to the National Council of Provinces have the same privileges and immunities before a joint committee of the Assembly and the Council as they have before the Assembly or the Council.

xh.interpretation: Municipalities have the power to pass laws in respect of the functional areas listed in Part B of Schedule 4 and Part B of Schedule 5. The Constitution also gives municipalities the right to exercise any power concerning a matter reasonably necessary for or incidental to the performance of its functions (found in Part B of Schedule 4 and Part B of Schedule 5).
xh.legislation: The Local Government: Municipal Structures Act 117 of 1998 further defines the different municipalities relating to categories and types of municipality. The Local Government: Municipal Systems Act 32 of 2000 provides for the manner in which municipal powers and functions are exercised.
xh.mechanism: Different categories of municipalities are provided for in section 155 of the Constitution.
xh.snippet: Deals with local government, consisting of municipalities which are vested with both legislative and executive authority.
xh.title: Local Government
xh.topic_meaning: Chapter 7 of the Constitution deals with local government, consisting of municipalities which are vested with both legislative and executive authority. These are original powers which are derived directly from the Constitution. Section 151(3) of the Constitution emphasises that a municipality “has the right to govern, on its own initiative, the local government affairs of its community, subject to national and provincial legislation” and importantly national and provincial government may not “compromise or impede a municipality’s ability or right to exercise its power or perform its functions”.

xh.interpretation: Section 85 of the Constitution confirms that the executive authority of the Republic is vested in the President who, together with members of the cabinet, must implement national legislation, co-ordinate functions of state departments and develop and implement national policy. This section refers to the President’s powers as head of the national executive.
xh.legislation: The exercise of executive power of the National Executive does not constitute “administrative action” in terms of the Promotion of Administrative Justice Act 3 of 2000 and therefore cannot be reviewed in terms of this Act. This, however, does not mean the exercise of these powers cannot be reviewed by the Courts. The Courts will review the exercise of this power under the principle of legality enshrined in section 1(c) of the Constitution.
xh.snippet: Provides for the power and functions of the President and the National Executive as well as the election and removal of the President by way of impeachment or a motion of no confidence.
xh.title: President and National Executive
xh.topic_meaning:
Chapter 5 of the Constitution provides for the powers and functions of the President and the National Executive as well as the election and removal of the President by way of impeachment or a motion of no confidence. The requirements for a motion of no confidence in the Cabinet, excluding the President is also covered in section 102.

Importantly, sections 84 and 85 of the Constitution provides for the exclusive powers of the President as head of State and head of the national executive respectively. The powers of the President as head of State include the power to assent to and sign Bills and to pardon or reprieve any offenders. These are original presidential powers which may only be exercised by the President.

xh.interpretation:
The powers and functions of the Premier is specifically provided for in section 127 of the Constitution which includes the assenting and signing of Bills and the appointment of commissions of inquiry within the province. Importantly, the provincial executive must act in accordance with the Constitution and the provincial constitution, if one has been passed. The province of the Western Cape passed a provincial constitution.

An important and unique mechanism for provincial interference in local government is provided for in section 139 of the Constitution. This section provides for interference by the provincial executive if a municipality is not adhering to its executive duties in terms of the Constitution. The provincial executive has the authority to take “any appropriate steps”. If the provincial executive authority does not or cannot fulfil this duty in terms of section 139, then the national executive authority must intervene.
xh.snippet: Provides for the powers and functions of the Premier and what can be done when a municipality does not adhere to its executive duties.
xh.title: Provincial Executive Authority
xh.topic_meaning:
Sections 125 to 141 of the Constitution, under Chapter 6 of the Constitution, deals with provincial executives.

Section 125 of the Constitution confirms that the executive authority of the province is vested in the Premier and the Premier together with other members of the executive Council exercises the executive authority which includes “implementing provincial legislation”; “developing and implementing provincial policy” and “co-ordinating the functions of the provincial administration and its departments”.

xh.mechanism:
Section 217(3) of the Constitution requires national legislation to be enacted to provide a framework for such policy and the Preferential Procurement Policy Framework Act 5 of 2000 was specifically enacted in this regard.

Various laws give effect to these constitutional standards in section 217(1) of the Constitution such as the Public Finance Management Act 1 of 1999, which requires the National Treasury to determine a “framework for an appropriate procurement and provisioning system which is fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost-effective”.
xh.snippet: Stipulates the constitutional standards of public procurement in South Africa.
xh.title: Public Procurement
xh.topic_meaning:
Section 217 of the Constitution stipulates the constitutional standards of public procurement in South Africa.

Section 217(1) of the Constitution provides that:

“When an organ of state in the national, provincial or local sphere of government, or any other institution identified in national legislation, contracts for goods and services, it must do so in accordance with a system which is fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost-effective.”

These five constitutional principles inform the law of public procurement in South Africa.

The Constitution also enables public procurement to be used as a tool to advance persons or categories of persons disadvantaged by unfair discrimination. Importantly, section 217(2) of the Constitution stipulates that the five constitutional principles identified in section 217(1) does not prohibit organs of State from implementing a procurement policy providing preferential allocation of contracts and advancing persons disadvantaged by unfair discrimination.

xh.interpretation:
Isidima kunzima ukusichaza, kodwa sibandakanya ukuqonda ixabiso analo umntu ngamnye. Ngokuyintloko, ilungelo lesidima lifumaneka ngokuzenzekelayo ngenxa yokuba ungumntu. Undoqo wesidima kukuthatha bonke abantu njengabanexabiso elingenakulinganiswa nanto, kungakhathaliseki ukuba zinjani na iimeko zabo, ibe bafanele baphathwe ngolo hlobo ke.

Ilungelo lesidima libeka isiseko kwaye linceda ekutolikweni kwamalungelo amaninzi akuMqulu Wamalungelo. Ngenxa yale nto, ilungelo lesidima alidli ngakuvela xa kuxoxwa amatyala apho amalungelo omntu eye anyhashwa, ngaphandle kwaxa lingekho elinye ilungelo elikuMqulu Wamalungelo elikhusela okanye eliphumeza oko kufunwayo. Xa kunjalo, ilungelo lesidima lingasetyenziswa ziinkundla ukulungisa ukunyhashwa kwamalungelo omntu angenakulungiswa ngokusebenzisa amanye amalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo. Eli lungelo liphinda linxibelelane nengcamango yentando yesininzi kwaye ligqala into yokuba abantu banelungelo nenkululeko yokuzenzela ukhetho.
xh.snippet: Kugqalwa into yokuba wonke umntu unelungelo lesidima esingenakohluthwa.
xh.title: Icandelo 10 : Isidima somntu
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 10 loMgaqo-siseko ligqala into yokuba wonke umntu “unelungelo lesidima esingenakohluthwa nelungelo lokuba sihlonitshwe isidima sakhe kwaye sikhuselwe”. Le nto ithetha ukuba ilungelo lomntu lokuba nesidima ulifumana nje kuba engumntu. Ilungelo lesidima alisosiseko nje kuphela esikwicandelo 1 loMgaqo-siseko, kodwa likwalilungelo elahlukileyo, nelinokunyanzeliswa lilodwa.

xh.interpretation: Ukuhambisana nomgaqo-siseko kwesigwebo sithunyelweambo sesinye sezigwebo ezibalaseleyo zokuqala zeNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko ibe nangona isigwebo sesininzi sasingajoliswanga kwilungelo lobomi, ngokuqinisekileyo izigwebo ezivumelana naso zagxininisa ukuba ilungelo lokuphila neleselene nelungelo lesidima. Iijaji ezininzi zokuphawula ukuba isigwebo sentambo sasinganeli ngaphandle ukusikela umda ilungelo lokuphila, kodwa sasilishenxisa ngokupheleleyo. Okubalulekileyo kukuba ilungelo lokuphila lachazwa njengelungelo lokuba nexesha lokubonisa ukuxabana nokubaluleka komntu ngamnye eluntwini.
xh.mechanism: Okuthethwa kukuba ilungelo lokuphila alixhomekekanga kwimeko ethile ngoxa likwazi ukusikelwa umda ukuba yiyo nayiphi na ilungelo lokubulala xa kufuneka sikhusela ukukusikelwa umda kwelungelo lokuphila ngenxa yesizathu esibambekayo esiyiyo kuba kunjalo ukusetyenziswa kwezigalo ngamanye amaxesha kwiimeko ezithile ezinqabileyo.
xh.snippet: Liqinisekisa wonke umntu ngelungelo lokuphila.
xh.title: Icandelo 11: Ubomi
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 11 loMgaqo-siseko liqinisekisa wonke umntu ngelungelo lokuphila kwaye lilungelo elingaziwa kwiimeko ezithile. Kubalulekile ukuba uqonde ukuba nangona ilungelo lokuphila lingaxhomekeka kwimeko yokujonga i-alinakusikelwa umda ngokufanelekileyo (ukuba kukho isizathu soko kusikelwa umda) ngokwecandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko, elithetha ngokusikelwa umda kwamalungelo kuMgaqo-siseko.

xh.interpretation:
Ukukhuselwa ngokoqobo kwelungelo lenkululeko nokukhuselwa komntu kufuna kuphunyezwe injongo efanelekileyo karhulumente efunyanwa emthethweni xa kubandezwa umntu inkululeko ngoxa ukukhuselwa kwenkqubo elandelwayo kweli lungelo kudibene nokulandelwa kwenkqubo eyiyo nenkqubo efanelekileyo kwaye kuya kuxhomekeka kwimeko yetyala ngalinye.

Ilungelo lokuba umzimba nengqondo yakho ilawulwe nguwe, lidlulela kwilungelo lokuzikhethela kwimiba ephathelele inzala, ukukhuseleka nokulawula umzimba wakho nelungelo lokungafakwa kulingelo lwezamayeza okanye lwesayensi ngaphandle kwemvume yakho emva kokuba ucaciselwe.
xh.legislation: The Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Act 92 of 1996 was specifically enacted to give expression to the right to make reproductive choices.
xh.snippet: Linika wonke umntu ilungelo lenkululeko nokukhuseleka komntu nelungelo lokuba umzimba nengqondo yakho zilawulwe nguwe.
xh.title: Icandelo 12: Inkululeko nokukhuseleka komntu
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 12 loMgaqo-siseko alaneli nje ukunika wonke umntu ilungelo lenkululeko nokukhuseleka komntu, kodwa likwanika wonke umntu ilungelo lokuba mzimba nengqondo yakhe zilawulwe nguye. Kubalulekile ukuqonda ukuba ilungelo lenkululeko nokukhuseleka komntu elibandakanya iinkalo ezahlukeneyo ezinjengelungelo lokubandezwa inkululeko ngaphandle kwesizathu nelungelo lokungangcungcuthekiswa, liqinisekisa ngokukhuselwa ngokoqobo nangokwenkqubo elandelwayo.

xh.legislation: South Africa is a signatory to various international law conventions obligating States to eradicate slavery and servitude such as the 1956 Supplementary Convention on the Abolition of Slavery, the Slave Trade and Institutions and Practices Similar to Slavery. In 2013, the Prevention and Combatting of Trafficking in Persons Act 7 of 2013 was specifically enacted to give effect to South Africa’s international and constitutional obligations and this Act provides measures specifically to protect and assist victims of trafficking.
xh.snippet: Lithi akakho umntu omele enziwe ikhoboka, abe sisicaka okanye anyanzelwe ukuba asebenze.
xh.title: Icandelo 13: Ubukhoboka nomsebenzi wesinyanzelo
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 13 loMgaqo-siseko lithi akakho umntu omele enziwe ikhoboka, isicaka okanye anyanzelwe ukuba asebenze.  Ngokwale mihla ubukhoboka bungaqondwa ngokuthi kukunyanzela umntu ukuba abe phantsi kolawulo lomnye umntu, aze loo mntu abe ngumnini wakhe. Le ngcaciso ephangaleleyo igubungela iimeko eziliqela zolwalamano olunyanzeliswayo, enoba kusemsebenzini, ekhaya okanye kwenye indawo.

xh.interpretation: Ukhuseleko olunikelwa ngumgaqo-siseko kwilungelo lokukhuselwa kweemfihlo kuye kwatolikwa yiNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko njengokufikelela kwiinkalo zobomi bomntu apho kukho kulindeleke ngokufanelekileyo ukuba kukhuselwe iimfihlo. Xa ziqwalasela enoba liye lanyhashwa ilungelo lokukhuselwa kweemfihlo, iinkundla aziyi kujonga kuphela into ixhoba eliyigqala njengeyimfihlo (ulindelo oluqhutywa ziimvakalelo zalo) kodwa nalulindelo lokoqobo lokukhuselwa kweemfihlo, kujongwe ukuba ngaba uluntu beluya kujonga olo lindelo njengolunezizathu ezibambekayo na. Olokoqobo lujolisa ekugqibeni kwenkundla enoba lo mntu uthi ilungelo lokukhuselwa kweemfihlo zakhe linyhashiwe ebenesizathu esivakalayo sokulindela ukuba iimfihlo zakhe zikhuselwe kuloo meko.
xh.legislation: The Protection of Personal Information Act 4 of 2013 was specifically enacted to give effect to the right to informational privacy and the Act provides strict measures for the processing of personal information by public and private bodies. The Information Regulator established in terms of the Act is an independent body empowered to monitor compliance of the Act.
xh.mechanism: Ukukhuselwa kwelungelo lokugcinwa kweemfihlo kuba ngqongqo ngakumbi xa kudibene neenkalo zobuqu zobomi bomntu, ezinjengekhaya, kuze kunyenyiswe xa kubhekela kweso sazulu. Ngokomzekelo, ubomi bentsapho yomntu, ukhetho lwakhe kwezesondo nemeko yakhe yasekhaya zikhuselwa ngamandla lilungelo lokugcinwa kweemfihlo. Ilungelo lokugcinwa kweemfihlo zomntu linxibelelene nelungelo lokuphathwa ngesidima.
xh.snippet: Linika wonke umntu ilungelo lokukhuselwa kweemfihlo zakhe ngokubanzi kwaye likhusela abantu kwizenzo zokungakhuseli iimfihlo.
xh.title: Icandelo 14: Ukuba neemfihlo
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 14 loMgaqo-siseko alaneli nje ukuqinisekisa wonke umntu ngelungelo lokukhuselwa kweemfihlo ngokubanzi kodwa likwathetha nangokukhuselwa kwizenzo ezithile zokungakhuseli  iimfihlo njengelungelo lokuba ikhaya lomntu lingasetshwa, kungahluthwa izinto zakhe nelungelo lokuba unxibelelwano lomntu lungamanyelwa okanye lufundwe. Ukukhuselwa ngokwenene lungelo kukugqala kwi-ndaba umntu unelungelo lokuzilawula nelokuba i-zazi yedwa.

xh.interpretation: Eli candelo libalulekile kuba ligxininisa into yokuba iinkolelo neembono ezingafaniyo zifanelwe kukukhuselwa kwaye zifanele zinikwe indawo yazo ibe ligqala into yokuba uMzantsi Afrika lilizwe elineenkcubeko ezininzi. Ilungelo lenkululeko yonqulo likhuselwa xa kungekho kunyanzelwa okanye ukuqhotyoshwa kwenkolelo okanye kwesenzo sonqulo ibe eli lungelo liyanyhashwa xa kuthathwa amanyathelo anyanzela abantu ukuba benze ngendlela echasene neenkolelo zabo.
xh.legislation: Section 15(3) of the Constitution empowers the State to enact legislation to recognise customary and religious marriages and the Recognition of Customary Marriages Act 120 of 1998 affords legal recognition to customary marriages prescribing to certain requirements and provides equal status to spouses in customary marriages.
xh.mechanism: Icandelo 15 loMgaqo-siseko lithi umntu unelungelo lokukholelwa kuThixo okanye kooThixo abathile neemfundiso zonqulo ezidibene nokukholelwa kulo Thixo okanye abo Thixo; ilungelo lokuhlala ungaqinisekanga ngokukholelwa kuThixo okanye kooThixo neemfundiso zonqulo ezidibene nokukholelwa kulo Thixo okanye abo Thixo; kunye nelungelo lokungakholelwa kuye nawuphi na uThixo. Kodwa ke, ayilolungelo lokukholelwa okanye lokungakholelwa kuphela elikhuselwa licandelo 15 loMgaqo-siseko. Icandelo 15 likhusela nelungelo lokwenza ngokuvumelana nezo nkolelo okanye noko kungakholelwa nelokuba umntu ahlengahlengise ubomi bakhe ngendlela ebonisa ukuba ulandela iinkolelo zakhe azikhethileyo.
xh.snippet: Liqinisekisa wonke umntu ngelungelo lokuba nenkululeko yesazela, yonqulo, yeengcinga, yeenkolelo neembono.
xh.title: Icandelo 15: Inkululeko yokunqula, yenkolelo noluvo
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 15(1) loMgaqo-siseko liqinisekisa wonke umntu ukuba unelungelo lenkululeko yesazela, yonqulo, yeengcinga, yeenkolelo neembono. Ilungelo lenkululeko yonqulo lifikelela nakwilungelo lokungabi nazo ezo nkolelo. Ababhali boMgaqo-siseko babefuna ukuba zonke iinkonzo ziphathwe ngokulinganayo kwaye kuqinisekwe ukuba umgaqo-siseko uyalikhusela ilungelo lenkululeko yeengcinga neenkolelo, equka ukungakholelwa ukuba uThixo ukho nokucinga nantoni na ofuna ukuyicinga.

Icandelo 15(2) loMgaqo-siseko lithi ezo zenzo zonqulo zingenziwa kumaziko axhaswa nguRhulumente phantsi kwemiqathango ethile eyimfuneko ukuze kuqinisekwe ukuba kuyiwa kuzo ngokwemiyalelo ebekwe ligunya likarhulumente, ziqhutywa ngendlela eyenza kubekho ukulingana kwaye kuyiwa ngokukhululekileyo kwaye akunyanzelwa mntu ukuba aye.

xh.legislation: The Promotion of Equality and Prevention of Unfair Discrimination Act 4 of 2000, is the constitutionally mandated legislation envisaged in section 9(4) of the Constitution and amongst other things, regulates hate speech.
xh.mechanism: Kubalulekile ukuphawula ukuba yintoni na eyenzekayo ngexesha lokubonisa izimvo kwiindidi kwiindidi ezisikelwe umda ngokwecandelo 16(2) Umgaqo-siseko, alikhuselwa umgaqo wokuba yintoni na ulisikela umda kunye neliungelo lenkululeko yokubonisa iimeko eziluncedo zentetho azivakalayo ezilindelekileyo kwaye azikho kwintetho ekhuselwa ngumgaqo-siseko. Kodwa ke, uhlobo oluthile lokuveza uluwelile oluzinzileyo ndidi zisikelwe umda luba luluvo olukhuselwayo Umgaqo wokuba ube yiyo nayiphi na indlela ezama ukuyisebenzisa kunye/okanye ukusikela umda olo luvo imele ipase kuvavanyo lokusikelwa umda kwelungelo ngokwecandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko.
xh.snippet: Liqinisekisa wonke umntu ukuba unelungelo lenkululeko yokuveza izimvo equka inkululeko yabeendaba, inkululeko yokufumana okanye yokukhupha inkcazelo, inkululeko yobugcisa bezandla nenkululeko yemfundo nesayensi.
xh.title: Icandelo 16: Inkululeko yokuthetha
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 16(1) loMgaqo-siseko lizwe lonke umntu ukuba unelungelo lenkululeko yokuveza izimvo engapheleli ngaphandle kwinkululeko yabeendaba, kodwa equka nenkululeko yokufumana okanye yokukhupha inkcazelo okanye iingcamango, inkululeko yobugcisa nenkululeko yemfundo nesayensi.

Icandelo 16(2) Umgaqo-siseko licacisa ngokukhethekileyo uhlobo lwezixhobo ezingakhuselwa ngumgaqo-siseko nento ekhoyo kwikululeko yokuveza izimvo ayifikeleli kwezi ndidi zokubonisa izimvo. Eli candelwana lithi lisikelwe umda eli lungelo. Ezi ndidi elisikelwe umda wokungena ukusasaza ubuxoki usenzela imfazwe; ukuphembelela ubundlobongela okanye ukuthethelela intiyo esekelwe kwibala lomntu, ukuhlanga, ubuni okanye kunqulo oluphembelelayo ukuba onzakaliswe. Udidi lokugqibela lwaziwa ngokuba sisithintelo sentetho evakalisa inzondo. Ezi ndidi zikho ngenxa yokuba zingakwazi ukuba nefuthe elibi kwisidima sabanye abantu kunye zingadala umonzakalo.

xh.interpretation: Ukuhlanganisana, ukumatsha, ukuqhankqalaza neepetishini zivumela amaqela angenafuthe kangako kwimibutho yepolitiki okanye kwinkqubo yepolitiki ukuba aveze imiba ebalulekileyo kuwo, atsalele ingqalelo yabantu kule miba kwaye athethe nabanye abemi nabameli ngale miba.
xh.legislation: The Regulations of Gatherings Act 205 of 1993 provides detail on the lawful conduct of gatherings. This piece of legislation pre-dates the Constitution and faced a constitutional challenge in 2018. The Constitutional Court declared section 12(1)(a) of the Act, which criminalised the failure to notify the relevant authority of a gathering, unconstitutional and invalid.
xh.snippet: Likhusela ilungelo lokuhlanganisana, lokumatsha, lokuqhankqalaza nelokunikela ngepetishini ukuba zenziwa ngendlela enoxolo ibe akuxhotywanga.
xh.title: Icandelo 17: Ukuhlanganisana, ukuqhankqalaza, noxwebhu lwezikhalazo
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 17 loMgaqo-siseko likhusela ilungelo lokuhlanganisana, lokumatsha, lokuqhankqalaza nelokunikela ngepetishini ukuba zenziwa ngendlela enoxolo ibe akuxhotywanga. Uqhankqalazo nokuhlanganisana zizixhobo ezazinamandla xa kwakusiliwa nocalucalulo ibe ukukhuselwa kweli lungelo kufanele kujongwe ngokwale mbali yalo. Eli lungelo likwayindlela ebalulekileyo yothethwano kuluntu olulawulwa sisininzi, lusisixhobo sepolitiki sabantu ababukulwayo nabangenayo enye indlela yokuveza izikhalazo zabo.

xh.interpretation: Kubalulekile ukugxininisa into yokuba ilungelo lenkululeko yonxulumano ifikelela nakwilungelo lokunganyanzelwa ukuba unxulumane nabantu. Le nkalo elandulayo yenkululeko yelungelo lonxulumano yadlala indiba ebaluleke kakhulu kwisigwebo seNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko setyala elalaliphakathi kweNew Nation Movement NPC Nabanye kunye noMongameli WoMzantsi Afrika Nabanye [2020] ZACC 11 sokuba uMthetho Wolonyulo (Electoral Act) 73 Wowe-1998 wawungqubana nomgaqo-siseko xa kufikwa ekuthintelweni kwabagqatswa abazimeleyo ukuba bazigqatse kunyulo lwelizwe nolwephondo.
xh.mechanism: Nangona eli lungelo liliquka neqela labantu, ngokuyintloko lilungelo elilelomntu omnye kunokuba ibe lelawo nawuphi na umbutho osungulwe ngenjongo yokukhusela bhetele amalungelo omntu omnye.
xh.snippet: Liqinisekisa wonke umntu ukuba unelungelo lenkululeko yonxulumano.
xh.title: Icandelo 18: Inkululeko yokuzibandakanya
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 18 loMgaqo-siseko liqinisekisa wonke umntu ukuba unelungelo lenkululeko yonxulumeno. Eli lungelo liye lachazwa njengelungelo elinxibelelene namanye kuba liqinisa namanya amalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo. Ngokomzekelo, eli lungelo liqinisa ilungelo lomntu lokuyila umbutho wepolitiki kwaye liqinisa nelungelo lomsebenzi lokuyila nokujoyina imanyano yabasebenzi. Eli lungelo likhusela ukhetho lwabantu lize lisikele umda ungenelelo lukarhulumente. Eli lungelo linika abantu ngabanye igunya lokuzigqibela kwaye lenza abantu bakwazi ukwenza ukhetho ngendlela abafuna ukubuhlengahlengisa ngayo ubomi babo kwaye baphuhlise ububona njengabantu xa beqhubana nabanye abantu kuluntu, nto leyo ephuhlisa intlonipho ize ikhusele nokwamkelwa kwabantu abangafaniyo.

xh.interpretation: Amalungelo aphangaleleyo epolitiki aqinisekiswa nguMgaqo-siseko amele ajongwe ngokwengcombolo yawo embalini apho isininzi sabemi boMzantsi Afrika sasilibandezwa ilungelo lokuthatha inxaxheba kwipolitiki.
xh.legislation: The Electoral Act 73 of 1998 regulates elections of the National Assembly, the Provincial Legislature and Municipal councils. In 2020, the Constitutional Court found that the Electoral Act was unconstitutional to the extent that independent candidates were not able to be elected for the National Assembly and Provincial Legislature, and Parliament was required to remedy this defect.
xh.snippet: Lichaza amalungelo abanzi epolitiki anjengelungelo lokusungula umbutho wepolitiki, ilungelo lokugayela umbutho wepolitiki nokuthatha inxaxheba kunyulo olukhululekileyo, oluqhutywa ngendlela eyiyo noluqhutywa rhoqo nelokubamba isikhundla xa unyuliwe.
xh.title: Icandelo 19: Amalungelo opolitiko
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 19 loMgaqo-siseko lichaza amalungelo abanzi epolitiki anjengelungelo lokusungula umbutho wepolitiki, ilungelo lokugayela umbutho wepolitiki nokuthatha inxaxheba kunyulo olukhululekileyo, oluqhutywa ngendlela eyiyo noluqhutywa rhoqo nelokubamba isikhundla xa unyuliwe.

Icandelo 19 loMgaqo-siseko, xa lifundwa kunye necandelo 1(d) loMgaqo-siseko, ligxininisa umgaqo wokuba undoqo kulawulo lwentando yesininzi kukuba yintando yesininzi enemibutho emininzi kunokuba lilizwe elinombutho omnye osikela umda ukubandakanyeka kwabantu kwinqanaba lepolitiki.

xh.interpretation: UMgaqo-siseko awumeli nje imiyalelo, iinkqubo ezilandelwayo nezakhiwo zenkqubo yentando yesininzi eMzantsi Afrika, ukwaqhubela phambili imilinganiselo neziseko uluntu oluzibona zifanelekile. Xa iinkundla zihlola enoba umthetho “uyahambisana na nomgaqo-siseko”, oko kukuthi, uyavunyelwa na nguMgaqo-siseko, ziye ziqwalasele neziseko ezikwicandelo 1, ngokukodwa ukuhambisana kwalo nokulawula komthetho.
xh.snippet: Iziseko zoMgaqo-siseko
xh.title: Icandelo 1: IRiphablikhi yoMzantsi-Afrika
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 1 loMgaqo-siseko lichaza iziseko eyakhelwe phezu kwazo iRiphabliki YoMzantsi Afrika. Ligxininisa ulawulo loRhulumente wentando yesininzi kwaye liqinisekisa ukuba kwahlukwene nenkqubo yoCalulo apho uRhulumente wayenegunya elingalinganamida.

Liqinisekisa ukuba iRiphabliki yoMzantsi Afrika “ililizwe elinye, elizimeleyo, lentando yesininzi”. Esi siqinisekisa sisodwa sibalulekile kuba ngaphambi kowe-1994 uMzantsi Afrika wawahlulwe waba ngoorhulumente bamaphandle abahlukeneyo (iiBantustan) apho Abemi BoMzantsi Afrika Abantsundu babenziwa bangabemi. Icandelo 1 liqinisekisa nokuba iRiphabliki YoMzantsi Afrika yakhelwe kwiziseko ezinjengesidima sokuba ngumntu, ukungacaluli ngokwebala, ukulawula komthetho nokongama koMgaqo-siseko (nto leyo ethetha ukuba umthetho osungulwe nguMgaqo-siseko usebenza kubo bonke abantu kwaye ngowona mthetho mkhulu elizweni) kunye nenkqubo yolawulo lwesininzi evumela amaqela ezopolitiko aliqela.

Kubalulekile ukuphawula ukuba ukuhlaziywa kwecandelo 1 loMgaqo-siseko kufuna ukuba kufikelelwe inani eliphezulu labakuxhasayo. Ubuncinane kufuneka ama-75 pesenti amalungu ePalamente Yelizwe axhase olo hlaziyo kwaye kubekho ubuncinane inkxaso yamaphondo amathandathu kwiBhunga Lamaphondo Elizwe. Ngoko kusoloko kubalulekile ukubuza enoba nakuphi na ukuhlaziywa koMgaqo-siseko kuzichaphazela ngokungangqalanga na iziseko ezikwicandelo1 loMgaqo-siseko.

xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 29 loMgaqo-siseko lichaza amalungelo emfundo kwaye lithi wonke umntu unelungelo lemfundo esisiseko nelemfundo enomsila, amele urhulumente, ngamanyathelo afanelekileyo, aqhubeke eyenza ifumaneke kwaye ifikeleleke.

Icandelo 29(2) liphinda lithi wonke umntu unelungelo lokufumana imfundo ngalo naluphi ulwimi lwaseburhulumenteni alukhethayo, xa kukwazeka. Libalulekile eli solotya longezelelweyo kuba ebudeni bexesha localulo, yayisisiNgesi neAfrikansi kuphela ezazigqalwa njengeelwimi zaseburhulumenteni neelwimi ekufundiswa ngazo. Kodwa ke eli lungelo lizisikela umda ngokwalo ibe kukaninzi kuphikiswana ezinkundleni ngalo.

Okokugqibela, icandelo 29(3) loMgaqo-siseko likhusela kwelungelo lokusungula izikolo ezizimeleyo ukuba nje ezo zikolo: i) azicaluli ngokwebala; ii) zibhalisiwe kuRhulumente kwaye; iii) zigcina umgangatho ofanelekileyo. Okubalulekileyo kukuba, uRhulumente akanyanzelekanga ukuba enze ubuncwane bufumaneke kwezo zikolo ekubeni zisebenza ngeendleko zazo kwaye uRhulumente unembopheleleko emnqandayo ukuba angangeneleli kwezo zikolo.

Ebudeni bexesha localulo, kwakusebenza ukongama kwepalamente eMzantsi Afrika. Ngenxa yoko imithetho epasiswe yiPalamente yayijonga izinto ezifunwa ligcuntswana labamhlophe kuphela ize ingawananzi amalungelo oluntu abo bonke abantu beminye imibala. IiNkundla zazingakwazi ukubhengeza uMthetho WasePalamente njengongasebenziyo kuba unyhasha amalungelo oluntu ibe zazikwazi ukubhengeza uMthetho njengongasebenziyo kuphela xa kukho iziphene kwinkqubo elandelwayo.

xh.mechanism: It is, however, subject to the condition that these rights may not be exercised in a way that is inconsistent with other fundamental human rights guaranteed in the Bill of Rights. For instance, the right to exercise a cultural practice must be consistent with an individual’s right to dignity and freedom and security of the person. If the right is practised in a manner that endangers a person’s life then it is inconsistent with the constitutional protection afforded in terms of section 30 of the Constitution and the State can intervene to protect an individual.
xh.snippet: Likhusela ilungelo lomntu lokusebenzisa ulwimi lwakhe nelokuthatha inxaxheba kwinkcubeko ayikhethayo.
xh.title: Icandelo 30: Ulwimi nenkcubeko
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 30 loMgaqo-siseko likhusela ilungelo lomntu lokusebenzisa ulwimi lwakhe nelokuthatha inxaxheba kwinkcubeko ayikhethayo. Lelinye lamalungiselo ahlukeneyo oMgaqo-siseko akhusela iintlanga, iinkonzo, namaqela athetha ulwimi olunye eMzantsi Afrika kwaye libonisa ukuzibophelela kumthetho wamazwe ngamazwe ekukhuseleni loo maqela.

xh.interpretation: Icandelo 31 loMgaqo-siseko likhusela izithethe, unqulo nolwimi lomntu ngamnye nolweqela elithile. Ngokweli candelo, mntu ngamnye umele avelise ubungqina bokuba ungoweqela elithile ukuze axhamle amalungelo elo qela. Eli Candelo 31 loMgaqo-siseko likwasekelwe ncam kwinqaku 27 leInternational Covenant on Civil and Political Rights nto leyo yenze uba ukukhuselwa kwamalungelo oluntu angezithethe, unqulo nolwimi kuhambisane nomthetho wehlabathi lonke.
xh.mechanism: La malungelo awamele angqubane namanye akhankanywe kuMqulu wamaLungelo (Bill of Rights), Ngokomzekelo, xa indlela abanqula ngayo abantu abathile iyingozi komnye umntu, ngokwecandelo 31 loMgaqo-siseko, ilungelo labo lokunqula liya kunyathelelwa phantsi ukuze kuhlonitshwe ilungelo lalo mntu lenkululeko nokhuseleko, ukuba lisengozini. Abantu abanakusebenzisa la malungelo ukuze badlel’ indlala abanye ngokungeyomfuneko.
xh.snippet: Eli candelo likhusela abantu abanezithethe ezahlukahlukeneyo, unqulo okanye ulwimi.
xh.title: Icandelo 31: Abantu abaphila ngokwenkcubeko yabo, ngokonqulo lwabo nangokolwimi lwabo
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 31 loMgaqo-siseko likhusela abantu abanezithethe, unqulo nolwimi olwahlukileyo kolwabanye. Abantu abanjalo abanakuvinjwa ilungelo lokugcina izithethe zabo, ukunqula ngendlela yabo kwanokusebenzisa ulwimi lwabo. URhulumente akanakuphazamisana namalungelo abantu bala maqela okuseka imibutho ngokwezithethe zabo, unqulo neelwimi zabo.

xh.legislation: The State is furthermore obliged to enact national legislation to give effect to this constitutional right and the Promotion of Access to Information Act 2 of 2000 (PAIA) specifically gives effect to this right. A person who wishes to access information held by the State or a private institution will be required to follow the procedures set out in PAIA.
xh.snippet: Eli candelo liqinisekisa ukuba wonke umntu unelungelo lokufikelela nayiphi na inkcazelo egcinwe nguRhulumente okanye esezandleni zomnye umntu, ekuyimfuneko ukuba ayifumane ukuze kusebenze okanye kukhuselwe nawaphi na amalungelo anawo.
xh.title: Icandelo 32: Ukufumana ingcombolo
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 32 loMgaqo-siseko liqinisekisa ukuba wonke umntu unelungelo lokufikelela nayiphi na inkcazelo eselugcinweni lukaRhulumente okanye ezandleni zomnye umntu ekuyimfuneko ukuba ayifumane ukuze kukhuselwe nawaphi na amalungelo anawo.

Okubaluleke ngakumbi kukuba eli lungelo lingokomgaqo-siseko liyimbonakaliso yokuzimisela ukukhulula abantu kulawulo olucinezelayo lorhulumente wocalucalulo. Ilungelo lokufikelela  inkcazelo lingundoqo wokusebenza kwemithetho yomgaqosiseko njengokuphenduliswa ngezenzo zikabani (accountability), ukungabi nobugqubusha (transparency), nokungafihlisi nto (openness) ibe likwasisixhobo esinamandla sokusiphula nengcambu urhwaphilizo. Ilungelo lokufikelela inkcazelo lisekelwe, ngokomkhamo othile, kumgaqo othi mntu ngamnye umele avunyelwe afumane inkcazelo engaye siqu, naleyo uRhulumente ayisebenzisayo ukwenza izigqibo ezichaphazela  abantu ngabanye nesininzi.

xh.interpretation: Inkqubo yolawulo loluntu kukusetyenziswa kwegunya labantu ngamasebe kaRhulumente neminye imibutho yabantu. Ibhekisela kwindlela  abachaphazeleka ngayo abantu ngoko kwenziwa ngamagosa karhulumente kwimisebenzi yemihla ngemihla. Yahlukile kwinkqubo yokulawula, oko kukuthi, izenzo zamalungu esigqeba esilawulayo xa esebenzisa amagunya awo, nto leyo edla ngokubandakanya ukuphunyezwa komthetho othile nokuyilwa kwenkqubo ethile. Izenzo ezinjalo azithathwa njengenkqubo yolawulo, kodwa zisamele ziphononongwe ngokwenkqubo yenkundla.
xh.legislation: Die Staat is verplig om nasionale wetgewing uit te voer om uitvoering te gee aan artikel 33 van die Grondwet en die Wet op die Bevordering van Administratiewe Geregtigheid 3 van 2000 is uitgevaardig om uitvoering aan hierdie regte te gee. Sekere wette val nie onder administratiewe optrede nie en is nie hersienbaar ingevolge die Wet op die Bevordering van Administratiewe Geregtigheid nie. Dit sluit regterlike handelinge (soos die voorsit van sake) deur die regbank in; optrede deur die President wanneer hy sy inherente bevoegdhede kragtens die Grondwet uitoefen, soos om kommissies van ondersoek aan te stel of presidensiële kwytskelding toe te staan; optrede deur die wetgewer wanneer hulle hul primêre funksies uitoefen; en suiwer politieke besluite deur die kabinet.
xh.snippet: Eli candelo liqinisekisa ukuba wonke umntu unelungelo lokuxhamla kwinkqubo yolawulo loluntu esemthethweni, efanelekileyo nengenamkhethe.
xh.title: Icandelo 33: Ukwenziwa kwezigqibo ngobulungisa
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 33 loMgaqo-siseko liqinisekisa ukuba wonk’ ubani unelungelo lokuxhamla kwinkqubo yolawulo loluntu esemthethweni, efanelekileyo nengenamkhethe nokuthi abantu ngabanye banelungelo lokubuzisa xa amalungelo abo eye anyhashwa yile nkqubo. Eli lungelo liqinisekisa ukulandelwa kweenkqubo ezifanelekilyo xa kusenziwa izigqibo ezingolawulo loluntu, nokuthi ezo zigqibo zisemthethweni ibe zifanelekile. Okona kubalulekileyo kukuba kulilungelo labantu ukuba inkqubo yolawulo ihlolwe yinkundla yezomthetho.

Ukusebenza kwelungelo labantu kulawulo olungakhethi cala lukhuthaza ukuncitshiswa kwegunya lwesigqeba esilawulayo. Phantsi korhulumente wocalucalulo yonke into yayiphethwe ngurhulumente, Ngokwahlukileyo, phantsi kwenkqubo yomgaqo-siseko waseMzantsi Afrika, igunya likarhulumente limele livisisane noMgaqo-siseko lize lihambisane nomthetho, lifaneleke kwaye lilandele inkqubo engenamkhethe.

xh.interpretation:
Eli lungelo lomgaqo-siseko alithethi kuthi umntu angasa isimangalo sakhe noba kukweyiphi inkundla okanye ibhodi ezimeleyo yezomthetho, ekubeni imigaqo elawula iinkundla isasebenza (njengokuthi uhlobo oluthile lwetyala lichotshelwa kwinkundla efanele eso simangalo). Noko kunjalo, umntu unelungelo lokuya kumangala enkundleni okanye kwibhodi yezomthetho xa kuyimfuneko.

URhulumente unoxanduva lokwenza lula ukufumaneka kobulungisa ngokusetyenziswa komthetho nezinye iindlela.
xh.snippet: Eli candelo liqinisekisa ukuba wonke ubani unelungelo lokuba isimangalo sakhe sixoxwe kwinkundla engenamkhethe okanye kwiforamu esemthethweni.
xh.title: Icandelo 34: Ukufikelela ezinkundleni
xh.topic_meaning: Eli Candelo 34 loMgaqo-siseko liqinisekise ukuba wonk’ ubani onesimangalo esimele sichotshelwe enkundleni unelungelo lokuvela enkundleni okanye nayiphi iforamu esemthethweni ezimeleyo nengenamkhethe. Eli lungelo lingundoqo osisiseko kumgaqo wezomthetho. Eli lungelo lijongwa njengelibaluleke gqitha, ngokungafaniyo nento eyayisenzeka ngexesha lorhulumente wengcinezelo apho igunya lenkundla lalijongelwa phantsi. Eli candelo livumela ukusebenza kwelungelo lomntu agwetywe ngendlela eyamkelekileyo nengathathi cala. Noko kunjalo, nasiphi na isimangalo esiziswa enkundleni yamatyala simele sichotshelwe kusetyenziswa umthetho.

xh.snippet: Eli candelo linika amalungelo abantu ababanjiweyo, abavalelweyo nabatyholwayo.
xh.title: Icandelo 35: Abantu ababanjiweyo, abavalelweyo nabamangalelweyo
xh.topic_meaning:
Phantsi kwenkqubo entsha yomgaqo-siseko, inkqubo yobulungisa kulwaphulo-mthetho ihlaziywe ngamandla ibe ibekw’ esweni yaze yalungelelaniswa ukuze kuqinisekiwe uba igunya likarhulumente alisetyenziswa ngendlela ecinezelayo. Icandelo 35 loMgaqo-siseko lidwelisa amalungelo abanawo abantu ababanjiweyo, abavalelweyo nabatyholwayo ibe la malungelo aza kusebenza kuphela ngokwezigaba ezichazwe kweli candelo.

Ngokomzekelo iCandelo 35 (1) loMgaqo-siseko lichaza ukuba umntu obanjelwe isityholo esithile unelungelo lokuthi cwaka, kuquka namanye amalungelo amaninzi anjengeloba ibanjwa linganyanzelwa ukuba livume okanye lithethe izinto ezingasetyenziswa njengobungqina bokuba netyala kwalo. NgokweCandelo 35 (2) loMgaqo-siseko, abantu abavalelweyo, kuquka wonke umntu ogwetyiweyo, kulilungelo lakhe ukuba achazelwe zisuka nje isizathu sokuvalelwa kwakhe, ibe ngokweCandelo 35 (3) loMgaqo-siseko, umntu ongumtyholwa kulilungelo lakhe ukuba ityala lakhe lixoxwe ngokwanelisayo nto leyo equka namanye amalungelo anjengokuchazelwa iinkcukacha zetyala alibekwayo kwanamalungelo anjengokuvakaliswa emsulwa aze anganyanzeliswa kuvelisa bungqina obumbambisayo.

Icandelo 35 (5) loMgaqo-siseko linikela isicombululo xa ilungelo elikuMgaqo-siseko liye alahlonitshwa lize libalule ukuba ubungqina obufunyenwe ngokunyathelela phantsi naliphi ilungelo elikuMqulu wamaLungelo (Bill of Rights) mabungasetyenziswa ukuba ukwamkela bekuya kwenza ukuxoxwa kwetyala kunganelisi okanye kutshabhise ukuphunyezwa kobulungisa.

xh.interpretation:
ICandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko lisebenza kuwo onke amalungelo adweliswe kuMqulu wamaLungelo ibe anezigaba ezibini. Ilungelo elikuMqulu wamaLungelo linokulinganiselwa kuphela xa kusetyenziswa umthetho wamazwe ngamazwe. Lo mthetho wamazwe ngamazwe usebenza ngokulinganayo kuluntu ngokubanzi ibe awujoliswanga kubantu abathile. Kupnakama umbuzo enoba oku kusikelwa umda okanye ukurhoxiswa kwamalungelo kuyasebenza na kumthetho wamazwe ngamazwe wolawulo (legislation) okanye wemigaqo (regulations) Kwesi sigaba sokuqala ingongoma ayikho ekubeni ilungelo umntu analo limele lisikelwe umda kodwa isekubeni lisikelwe umda ngokwenene na ilungelo analo.

Ukuba kufumaniseka ukuba ilungelo likabani lisikelwe umda,  umele ajonge enoba isizathu soko sisengqiqweni okanye siyavakala na kubantu abanenkululeko nedemokhrasi ngokusekelwe kwisidima somntu, ukulingana nenkululeko: kujongwa nohlobo lwelungelo, ukubaluleka nenjongo yokulisikela umda: imiqathango ehambisana nako ukuze kufezwe injongo yako.

 

Kuphela kusemva kokuqwalasela zonke ezi nkalo kunye nezinye ezihambisana nazo ekuya kuthi iNkundla igqibe enoba kuyafaneleka ngokomgaqo-siseko ukuba ilungelo elo lingasikelwe umda kusini na. Okokugqibela, kumele kudandalaziswe ubungqina obuthethelela ukusikelwa umda ilungelo. Kungoko, kuye kufuneke umthetho unikele isizathu esivakayo sokuba umthetho olawula ukuhlalutywa oko kubukelwa kwiifilimu ubeka imiqathango kwilungelo lenkululeko yokuthetha.
xh.mechanism: Ngokomzekelo, umthetho ulawula ukuhlalutywa komongo weefilimu uze ubeke imiqathango yokubukelwa kwazo, usikela umda ilungelo lenkululeko yokuthetha. Noko kunjalo, ukuba injongo yale miqathango ikukukhusela abantwana ekubukeleni izinto ezinokubenzakalisa, ubani angazibuza enoba lemiqathango kwinkululeko yokuthetha isengqiqweni ibe iyathetheleka kusini na ngokwecandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko. Ukuba lo mthetho uvumelana ncam necandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko ngoko ukusikelwa umda kweli lungelo kuyathetheleleka ngokomgaqo-siseko.
xh.snippet: Eli candelo lichaza iimeko apho amalungelo adwelise kuMqulu wamaLungelo (Bill of Rights) anokusikelwa umda khona.
xh.title: Ukusikelwa umda kwamalungelo
xh.topic_meaning: ICandelo 36 lichaza iimeko apho amalungelo akuMqulu wamaLungelo anokusikelwa umda khona. Amalungelo adweliswe kuMqulu wamaLungelo awagqibelelanga ibe anokusikelwa umda. Ukuze oko kusikelwa umda kwamkeleke kumele kuhambisane neemeko ezichazwe kwicandelo 36 loMgaqo-siseko.

xh.legislation: It is also important to note that there is a difference between the declaration of a State of Emergency and the declaration of a State of National Disaster. The onslaught of the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020 caused the declaration of a National State of Disaster in terms of the Disaster Management Act 57 of 2002 whereas a State of Emergency may only be declared under the State of Emergency Act 64 of 1997, and section 37 of the Constitution, and only in very limited circumstances.
xh.snippet: Eli candelo lichaza ukuba imeko yonxunguphalo inokubhengezwa nini ibe phantsi kwaziphi iimeko.
xh.title: Icandelo 37: Imeko zequbuliso
xh.topic_meaning:
ICandelo 37 loMgaqo-siseko lichaza ixesha neemeko apho kunokubhengeza iimeko yonxunguphalo. Imeko yonxunguphalo inokubhengezwa kuphela xa sekuthatyathwe onke amanyathelo achazwe kweli candelo. Ukunqunyanyiswa okwethutyana kwamalungelo oluntu asisiseko kuyathetheleleka ukuba ubomi besizwe siphela busongelwa yimfazwe, uhlaselo, imvukelo, ukungazinzi, intlekele yemvelo okanye nayiphi na imeko yongxamiseko esongela uluntu kwaye isibhengezo esinjalo siba iyimfuneko ukuze kubuyiselwe uxolo nozinzo. Isibhengezo semeko yonxunguphalo sinokwenziwa yiPalamente , sithathe iintsuku eizngama-21 ubude ngaphandle koba iNational Assembly igqiba ekubeni izandise ezo ntsuku, phofu nokwandiswa kweentsuku kumele kuxhomekeke kwiimeko ezithile.

Eli candelo likwanikela uLudwe lwamaLungelo Angenakunyhashwa naphantsi kwaziphi na iimeko ibe nawuphi na umthetho ogunyazisa imeko yonxunguphalo awunakuwanyathalela phantsi la malungelo konke konke. Ngokomzekelo, ilungelo lokuphila alinakunyhashwa nokuba sekunjani na.

xh.mechanism: Ukuze umntu akwazi ukusebenzisa icandelo 38 loMgaqo-siseko, akunyanzelekanga ukuba abonise ukuba kukho ilungelo lomntu okanye labantu abathile eliye lanyhashwa okanye lasongelwa ngokunyhashwa kufuneka nje abeke isityholo sokuba ilungelo elikuMqulu Wamalungelo linyhashiwe okanye lisongelwe ngokunyhashwa aze achaze into exhasa eso sityholo.
xh.snippet: Eli candelo liichaza ukunyanzeliswa kwamalungelo adweliswe kuMqulu wamaLungelo (Bill of Rights)’ enkundleni yamatyala nokuthi ngabantu abanjanii abangafaka isimangalo  xa ilungelo labo linyhashiwe.
xh.title: Ukunyanzeliswa kwamalungelo
xh.topic_meaning:
ICandelo 38 lichaza ukunyanzeliswa kwamalungelo adweliswe kuMqulu wamaLungelo kwinkundla esemthethweni nokuthi ngabantu abanjani abangafaka isimangalo sokunyhashwa okanye ukusongelwa kwamalungelo abo siqu nawabanye abantu. Eli candelo lingena nzulu kunyhasho lwamalungelo naxa “esongelwa” libonisa ukuba umntu angafaka isimangalo enkundleni xa ecinga ukuba kukho amathuba okunyhashwa kwelungelo analo ngokoMqulu wamaLungelo.

Abantu abanokufaka isimangalo eNkundleni ngaba: nabani na olungelo lakhe linyhashiweyo: nabani na omela omnye umntu ongenakwazi ukuzimela: nabani na omela iqela elithile labantu: nabani omela uluntu ngokubanzi kunye nebhunga elithil elimela amalungu alo. Kwimeko enjengale, iNkundla yamatyala imele ilungise ingxaki  leyo, kuquka amalungelo omntu.

xh.interpretation: Ukusebenzisa umthetho wamazwe ngamazwe njesikhokelo ekutolikeni amalungelo kuvumela ukuzibophelela kuwo nokungazibopheleli .Ngokomzekelo, uMzantsi Afrika watyikitya waza wamkela  indlela yokucacisa amalungelo oluntu nezopolitiko ngokwe-ICCPR (International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights). Ukuba ubani ufaka isimangalo sokuba umthetho othile unyhasha ilungelo lakhe ngokomgaqo-siseko, njengekusingathwa kwengxoxo yabucala, iNkundla inoxanduva lokulandela ukhokelo lweICCPR ekusingatheni eso simangalo. Mayela nokusebenzisa umthetho welinye ilizwe ekucaciseni amalungelo, inkundla, isigqeba solawulo neforamu zimele zenze ngobuchule ekubeni inkqubo yeenkundla inokungafani.
xh.snippet: Eli candelo linikela ukhokelo ekuchazweni koMqulu wamaLungelo (Bill of Rights).
xh.title: Icandelo 39: Ukuchazwa kwentsingiselo yomqulu wamalungelo
xh.topic_meaning:
NgokweCandelo loMgaqo-siseko 39(1), xa kuchazwa uMqulu wamaLungelo, inkundla, isigqeba esilawulayo okanye iforam inoxanduva lokukhuthaza ukuphuhliswa uqheliselo lwenkululeko nedemokhrasi, ngokuphathelele isidima somntu, ukulingana nenkululeko lize linike inkundla, isigqeba esilawulyo okanye iforam imbopheleleko yokusebenzisa umthetho wamazwe ngamazwe, lize libonise ukuba ukusebenzisa umthetho welizwe langaphandle kumele kwenziwe ngobuchule.

 

NgokweCandelo 39(2) loMgaqo-siseko, xa ichaza nawuphi na umthetho, naxa icacisa umthetho ongabhalwanga (common law) okanye umthetho wesiNtu (customary law) inkundla, isigqeba esilawulayo, kunye neforamu, zinoxanduva lokukhuthaza umoya, umongo nezinto ezidweliswe kuMqulu wamaLungelo. ICandelo 39(2) loMgaqo-siseko lilawula ukusetyenziswa ngokungangqalanga koMqulu wamaLungelo lize livumele umthetho ongabhalwanga usebenze ngokuvisisana noMqulu wamaLungelo. Xa zisebenzisa icandelo 39 (2) loMgaqo-siseko, iinkundla zayama kwimigaqo exhasa uMqulu wamaLungelo zize zihlole enoba umthetho ungahlengahlengiswa ukuze uvisisane nale migaqo.

ICandelo 39(3) loMgaqo-siseko libonisa ukuba uMqulu wamaLungelo awuchasananga namanye amalungelo okanye inkululeko aqulethwe kumthetho ongabhalwanga, kumthetho wesintu nakulawulo ukuba nje zonke ezi zivumelana  nawo.

xh.interpretation: Kubalulekile ukuqonda ukuba iNkundla Yomgaqo-siseko iye yangqina kumatyeli ahlukeneyo umahluko ongayondelelananga phakathi kwabemi nabantu abangengobemi awuhambisani noMgaqo-siseko nokuba isininzi samalungelo akuMqulu Wamalungelo sinikwa bonke abantu.
xh.legislation: The State is obliged to enact national legislation to define citizenship and the South African Citizenship Act 88 of 1995 provides for how one can acquire, lose and regain South African citizenship. The recognition of the right to citizenship as a founding provision in the Constitution must be understood in its historical context. During apartheid, black South Africans were not recognised as citizens of South Africa and were made citizens of defined territories (known as Homelands) under the Bantu Homelands Citizenship Act 26 of 1970.
xh.snippet: Izinto ezenza abantu baseMzantsi Afrika babe ngabemi.
xh.title: Icandelo 3: Ubumi
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 3 loMgaqo-siseko lithi uMzantsi Afrika unabemi kwaye bonke abemi boMzantsi Afrika abaneli nje ukuba nemfanelo “ngokulinganayo yokuxhamla kumalungelo, kwiinyhweba neenzuzo zokuba ngummi” kodwa ngokulinganayo “banoxanduva lokufeza iimbopheleleko noxanduva lokuba ngummi”.

Phantsi kwenkqubo yomgaqo-siseko entsha yoMzantsi Afrika, ilungelo lokuba ngummi kuMgaqo-siseko lisekelwe ekuqondeni ukuba bonke abantu bayalingana. Ilungelo lokuba ngummi livumela umntu ukuba afumane amalungelo ahlukeneyo anjengelungelo lokumelwa kwezopolitiko nenkululeko yokuhambahamba neyokuhlala.

xh.snippet: Kuchazwa inkqubo edibene nomhobe wesizwe woMzantsi Afrika.
xh.title: Icandelo 4: Umhobe Wesizwe
xh.topic_meaning:
Ukuza kuthi ga ngowe-1994, umhobe wesizwe osemthethweni eMzantsi Afrika yayingu-Die Stem van Suid-Afrika, owawusekelwe kumbongo owabhalwa ngowe-1918 ngu-CJ Langenhoven. Ngowe-1994, owayesakuba nguMongameli uNelson Mandela wenza isaziso sokuba ukongezelela ku-Die Stem van Suid-Afrika, noNkosi Sikelel’ IAfrika wayeza kuba ngumhobe wesizwe. UNkosi Sikelel’ IAfrika ekuqaleni wayeliculo lecawa kodwa kamva waye wayanyaniswa neAfrican National Congress waza waculwa kakhulu xa kuqhankqalazwa nxamnye norhulumente wocalulo. Ngowe-1997, Owayesakuba NguMongameli uNelson Mandela wabhengeza umhobe wesizwe omtsha waseMzantsi Afrika, owawuluhlelo oludityanisiweyo luka-“Nkosi Sikelel iAfrika” no-“Die Stem van Suid-Afrika” (“Isimemelelo SoMzantsi Afrika”).

Umhobe wesizwe ubonisa ukuzibophelela ekungcibeni iintanda zexesha elidluleyo ngokweNtshayelelo YoMgaqo-siseko kwaye ubonisa ukumanyana kwabantu nangona bengafani.

xh.snippet: Kuchazwa inkqubo edibene neflegi yoMzantsi Afrika.
xh.title: Icandelo 5: Iflegi yesizwe
xh.topic_meaning: Icandelo 5 loMgaqo-siseko lithi iflegi yeRiphabliki inombala omnyama, nagolide, naluhlaza, namhlophe, nabomvu, nablowu, ngendlela ochazwe ngayo kwiSahluko 1 soMgaqo-siseko. Iflegi yelizwe yadizayinwa ngowayesakuba nguMthunywa KaRhulumente WoMzantsi Afrika, uMnu Fred Brownwell. Iflegi yelizwe yasetyenziswa okokuqala ngowama-27 kuEpreli 1994 ibe idizayini eyintloko yale flegi, emile ngathi ngu-‘V’ odibanayo abe libhanti elinye ngokuhambisana neempapasho ezisemthethweni zikaRhulumente, ingatolikwa “njengokudibana kwabantu abangafaniyo boluntu loMzantsi Afrika, bethatha uhambo oluphambi kwabo ngomanyano”.

xh.legislation: The Use of Official Languages Act 12 of 2012 has been specifically enacted to give effect to the constitutional obligations in terms of section 6 of the Constitution. The National Language Policy Framework was adopted in 2002 by Cabinet. Some of the aims of this policy are to promote the equitable use of the 11 official languages and to ensure redress for previously marginalised official languages.
xh.mechanism: Icandelo 6 loMgaqo-siseko likwayalela ukuba kusungulwe iBhodi Yeelwimi YaseMzantsi Afrika ekufuneka ikhuthaze ize idale iimeko zokuphuhliswa nokusetyenziswa kwazo zonke iilwimi zaseburhulumenteni kunye nolwimi lwamaKhoi, olwamaNama nolwamaSan kunye nolwimi lwezandla. Ukugqalwa koLwimi Lwezandla LwaseMzantsi Afrika (South African Sign Language [“SASL”]) njengolwimi lwaseburhulumenteni lwe-12 kudala kuyinto etshis’ ibunzi ibe ngowama-2017, iKomiti Edibeneyo Yokuhlola Umgaqo-siseko yasePalamente (Parliament’s Joint Constitutional Review Committee) yacebisa ukuba i-SASL igqalwe njengolwimi lwaseburhulumenteni lwe-12 nto leyo eza kufuna ukuba kuhlaziywe umgaqo-siseko.
xh.snippet: Ukugqalwa kweelwimi zaseburhulumenteni zaseMzantsi Afrika.
xh.title: Icandelo 6: Iilwimi
xh.topic_meaning:
Icandelo 5 loMgaqo-siseko ligqala iilwimi zaseburhulumenteni zeRiphabliki ngokuthi “sisiPedi, isiSuthu, isiTswana, isiSwati, isiVenda, isiTsonga, iAfrikansi, isiNgesi, isiNdebele, isiXhosa nesiZulu”. Eli candelo liphinda ligqale “imbali yokuncitshiswa kokusetyenziswa nokuthotywa kweelwimi zomthonyama” lize liyalele uRhulumente ukuba athathe “amanyathelo asebenzisekayo okuphakamisa nokuphuhlisa ukusetyenziswa kwezi lwimi”. Urhulumente kazwelonke nabamaphondo baphinda bayalelwe ukuba “balawule kwaye babeke esweni ukusebenzisa kwabo iilwimi zaseburhulumenteni” ngemithetho onangamanye amanyathelo nokuba zonke iilwimi zimele ziphathwe ngokulinganayo. 

Liqonda ukuba bekukho inkqubo yokunanzwa kwezinye iilwimi zomthonyama, icandelo 6(2) loMgaqo-siseko libeka imbopheleleko phezu kukaRhulumente yokuthatha amanyathelo asebenzisekayo okuphakamisa ezi lwimi. Ezinye iilwimi ezithethwa ligcuntswana eMzantsi Afrika, ezinjengesiHindi nesiGrike, azidweliswanga njengeelwimi zaseburhulumenteni. Isizathu kukuba zithethwa kwezinye iindawo zehlabathi ibe ukuqhubeka kwazo zikho akuxhomekekanga ekusetyenzisweni nasekukhuleni kwazo eMzantsi Afrika.
